QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON KWAKWEWLTH AGENCY

Education:

The following schools were opened on the proper date with full attendance. St. Michael's Indian Residential Schools, Alert Bay; Junior and Senior Classrooms Alert Bay Indian Day School; Campbell River Indian Day School; Cape Mudge Indian Day School. Campbell River Indian Day School has been decorated both interior and exterior. Miss Laura Fleming was appointed to the Cape Mudge Indian Day School, and Miss Anne Saunders to the Senior classroom, Alert Bay Indian Day School.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.
Alert Bay, B.C.,
Dec. 29th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

The Department will please note that Miss Saunders was away thirteen days during the Quarter ending December 31st. The reason for writing this letter is to explain why it was necessary for Miss Saunders to be absent so long.

Miss Saunders is a diabetic and although her health is good generally speaking, nevertheless, it is necessary for her to be admitted to hospital two days every two months for special treatment, and this has always been done during week-ends, Saturday and Sunday.

When Miss Saunders came to Alert Bay she was under the impression that she could get this special treatment when needed but later found out that owing to the lack of facilities and doctors it was not possible to have this treatment in Alert Bay. She then found it necessary to proceed to Vancouver and be admitted to a hospital for two days, and expected to return on the following boat but found it was impossible to get transportation home and was delayed in Vancouver until transportation could be arranged.

Since then we have had another change of doctors who are now permanent, and they have made the necessary arrangements to give Miss Saunders this special treatment she requires.

It is no fault of Miss Saunders but rather that of the Columbia Coast Mission, and in view of this I would strongly request the Department not to make any deductions in her salary as it is not anticipated there

p.t.o.
will be any more sick leave during the term, as we now have definite arrangements for her to get her special treatment during week-ends when the school is not in session.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 31st January, 1946.

Mr. M.S. Todd, Indian Agent, Alert Bay, B.C.

I am advised by Mr. Indian Agent Todd that Miss Anne Saunders, teacher of the senior room, Alert Bay Indian Day School, is ill in the hospital and on the recommendation of her doctor is going to resign from her position. Mr. Todd has not advised the date on which the school was closed, but I am writing him for this information and will advise you in due course.

For D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, March 8, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to Miss Anne Saunders. Please forward her resignation as soon as you receive it.

Miss Saunders was absent for 13 days during the December quarter, owing to the necessity of proceeding to hospital for medical treatment. This information was supplied to us by Indian Agent Todd in a letter dated December 29, 1945. We made no deduction from her salary and consequently she has already been allowed 13 days' sick leave with pay during the current academic year.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, March 8, 1946.

March 6th, 1946.

Dear Bishop Sexton:

I am advised by Mr. Indian Agent Todd that Miss Anne Saunders, because of illness, has submitted her resignation as teacher of the senior room at the Alert Bay Indian Day School. There is a very heavy attendance at this school, and as Mrs. Massey, teacher of the junior room, has an enrolment in her class of over fifty, she is unable to carry on alone.

It would be appreciated if you would endeavour to nominate a qualified teacher to replace Miss Saunders as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

For D. N. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Right Rev. H. H. Sexton,
Bishop of British Columbia,
912 Vancouver Street,
Victoria, B.C.

March 22nd, 1946.

M. S. Todd, Esq., Indian Agent, Alert Bay, B.C.

With reference to your letter of March 16th in connection with the resignation of Miss A.M. Saunders, teacher of the senior classroom at the Alert Bay Indian Day School, I am advised by Bishop Sexton that he is unable at the moment to nominate a suitable teacher to replace her. It is very doubtful if we will be able to secure a teacher for this classroom at this time of the year, particularly as the Easter holidays will soon be here which will leave only 2 teaching months. If, however, you should hear of a suitable qualified teacher please advise us immediately so that we can refer the matter to Bishop Sexton, secure his nomination and proceed with the appointment.

For D. N. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6383, file 800-1, part 2)
Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 22nd last, file #6-11-2, in respect to the resignation of Miss A. E. Saunders.

As we have upwards of fifty children wandering around on the streets here who should be in school, I am wondering if your office is taking any action to secure a teacher. It is most important that we have someone if at all possible, even if only for the remainder of the term. I would like to suggest that you put an ad in the Vancouver Paper to see if it would not be possible to obtain a teacher, so that this year's work will not be lost entirely.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding an exchange of correspondence between this office and Mr. Indian Agent Todd and Bishop Sexton in connection with a teacher to replace Miss Anne Saunders who resigned as teacher of the senior classroom at the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and would refer you to Mr. Todd's suggestion that we advertise in a Vancouver paper for a replacement.

It is understood that the United Church and the Roman Catholic Church have in the past advertised for teachers for the schools under their auspices and I would appreciate information from the Department with respect to our responsibility for securing teachers in this way. If the Department considers that this office should advertise for a teacher in this case will you please authorize me to do so, or otherwise I might suggest to Bishop Sexton that he advertise if he has not already done so.

D. E. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encls.
AIRMAL

Ottawa, April 3, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

Your letter of the 30th ultimo, regarding a teacher for the Alert Bay Indian Day School, reached me this afternoon.

In view of the fact that Bishop Sexton has been requested to nominate a teacher for this school and has been unable to do so, we cannot see why you should not advertise the situation in the Vancouver papers.

We have found it necessary to advertise on two or three occasions in the province of Ontario in the past four months and in each case have been successful in securing a teacher.

When submitting the account covering the cost of the advertisement, you should attach a copy of the paper showing the actual advertisement. Advertising accounts have to be taxed by the King's Printer and he always insists on having a copy of the newspaper showing the advertisement.

I presume you will offer the same salary as we were paying to Miss Saunders.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 25th last, file #6-11-2, advising Miss Iris Simpson has been appointed teacher of the senior classroom, Alert Bay Indian Day School.

I was very glad to learn that our teacher, Mrs. Massey was able to find someone for the school, but I must inform you Miss Simpson does not intend staying beyond June 30th, 1946. It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would kindly inform His Lordship, Bishop Sexton, that we will require a teacher for the senior classroom on September 1st next. As teachers are so difficult to obtain, I would suggest that he be notified immediately so he will have sufficient time to locate a suitable teacher who will commence her duties at that time.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 6th last, file #6-11-2, in respect to Mrs. Jane Massey's transfer to another Indian Day School.

It is noted you have recently received an application from Miss N. Skeftfeld and are considering appointing her to succeed Mrs. Massey.

As the housing accommodation for teachers in Alert Bay is very difficult it is necessary, if possible, to find teachers who can living together in the present building used for a teacherage.

For your information I have received a communication from another teacher who was with the Department for several years at Alert Bay before going into the Services, and as she is a very good teacher and would fit in with a Miss Findlay whom Bishop Sexton is nominating for the senior room, Alert Bay Indian Day School, I would kindly ask that Miss Skeftfeld's application be held in abeyance until such time as we are sure of this other teacher's decision.

Quarterly Report of M.S. Todd, Indian Agency, for the quarter ending.

June 22nd, 1946.

Education.

Resignations from all Indian Day School Teachers have been received and forwarded to the Commissioner's Office. I have located a good teacher for the senior room in the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and I understand she is being appointed to that position. To date no other teachers have been appointed for the other schools. All schools will be closing for the summer holidays on the date set by the Department. The lack of educational facilities in this Agency is becoming a serious matter and recommendations have been made to the Department in respect to Same.

M.S. Todd
Indian Agent.

Your File 156-29-1 (W.T.)

I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of July 26th approving the transfer of Miss N. Skaftfeld from the Kitwancool Indian Day School to the junior room of the Alert Bay Indian Day School. On approval of this transfer it was ascertained that Miss Skaftfeld would much prefer to teach at Massett and as I am in receipt of a telegram from Mr. Indian Agent Phillips advising that Miss Vivian Sing and Mrs. Ida Conroy have submitted their resignations as teachers at the Massett Indian Day School, this would be satisfactory. As the services of a teacher to undertake the work of the Junior Room at the Alert Bay Indian Day School are available we are now in the position of being able to provide for one of the rooms at Massett and two teachers for the Alert Bay Indian Day School in the persons of Miss Gladys Findlay whose appointment as teacher of the senior room has already been approved, and Miss Leanna Chemago whose application for the Junior Room is attached.

It will be noted that Miss Chemago holds a Second Class Permanent Certificate valid for life and has had 9½ years teaching experience and in addition to this as she is a personal friend of Miss Findlay and will have to share accommodation with her, her appointment would be most convenient. I would recommend her employment at a salary of $100 a teaching month plus bonus and would appreciate confirmation of her appointment by airmail.

It is anticipated that Miss Skaftfeld will visit this office shortly and in the meantime it would be appreciated if you would advise also by airmail if her transfer to the Junior Room at the Massett Indian Day School is approved. I may say that her appointment to Massett is approved of by Bishop Gibson.

[Signature]

D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Miss Leanna Chemago.

The work of this teacher shows little or no preparation and the methods used by her are poor particularly in reading. The pupils point to the individual words as they "read" them. The passages covered in this way are not understood by the pupils. No attempt is made to develop reading readiness with the beginners.

There is little to indicate any attempt at organization. If a timetable has been prepared it is not posted.

The discipline in the class is very poor. This condition results from the teacher failing to provide an adequate supply of seat work particularly for the beginners.

The attendance in this room is poor.

Some attempt is made to give instruction in phonics and oral language.

This teacher has a large class but she has made little effort to cope with the situation.

PP/MGD
All members of Agency staff were on duty during the past quarter. Accommodation for teachers and staff has become a serious matter in this Agency. Recently the old building housing the teachers and one member of the staff was destroyed by fire, leaving these employees homeless and with considerable loss to them. In this isolated place it has always been difficult to get accommodation for Department employees, and today the situation is impossible. I am bringing this to the Department's attention just as formally as I can because I know that unless we get some suitable accommodation for employees in this place we are going to have our schools closed and lose other members of the staff. An isolated place like Alert Bay is far different from a city or other centre where employees can either live at home or have a greater opportunity of obtaining accommodation.

In this place there is nothing. If it had not been for myself, with no authority from Ottawa, making an arrangement whereby we could get this old building which was just burned down for accommodation for staff members, our schools would have been closed long before this. I cannot afford to go on doing the things that I have been forced to do in order to get staff members reasonably housed. There is no reason why accommodation cannot be provided when we own the buildings and it is just a matter of having them moved to this location and suitably re-modelled for living accommodation. As far as I know now, all our teachers are assigned at the end of the term where they have no accommodation provided, as their present accommodation has only been temporary and they can no longer stay there. Teachers will not accept employment in outside isolated districts without accommodation being provided. This not only applies to the Indian Department but to the Provincial Schools as well. If the Department will provide the funds and give me authority and instructions I will have these buildings moved here from the Army Camp, Port Hardy.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Alfred:

I was very much surprised and concerned to have Mrs. M. Scanlon, Principal of Alert Bay Indian Day School, forward me your letter addressed to her, which read as follows:

"Alert Bay, B. C.,"
May 23rd, 1949.

"Just to let you know that all my children taking this afternoon off till after the holiday is over."

"M. K. Alfred"

Mrs. Scanlon informs me there was no good reason for your children not attending school. She pointed out that on the afternoon of May 23rd your children Philip and Moses accompanied you to the playground where they were just fooling around with the workmen employed there, and could have been in school. Mrs. Scanlon also informed me that four of your son Alvin's children were also absent.

As you are one of the principal as well as influential members of the Nimipish Band, you must readily see how difficult you are making it for the school where regular attendance is essential to the progress of the individual child. During past years when the Government (through no fault of their own) found it impossible to provide adequate educational facilities for the children here, you were one of the most critical members of your people. The Department has and is doing everything possible to give your children a good education. A new school has been built and efficient teachers employed, and there is no reason why every child of school age in Alert Bay does not attend school regularly. The Government by law requires every child to attend school each day unless he or she is ill, and it is my responsibility as Indian Superintendent to see that all children attend regularly.

p.t.o.
I wish to point out to you that you have no right whatsoever to dictate to the Government and inform the Principal that you are going to keep your children out of school just when you see fit. During the month of May your son Philip was absent 9 days, and the teacher reports "No good reason".

As this is a serious matter I felt it was best to write you fully so that you will know what the Government regulations are in respect to children attending school regularly. Please be advised no parents have any right to keep children out of school unless they are ill and this illness must be reported to the teacher; or special permission is given for a child's absence from school.

The Department feels that you should be one who is setting an example to others and I trust you will co-operate with the Principal and the Department in the future, so that there will be no repetition of what has taken place. Would you kindly give me this assurance.

Yours very truly,

Attached please find Monthly Day Returns for the months of May and June, 1949, respectively for the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

This special report is being made in respect to poor attendance of some children, part of which was blamed on the teacher by the parents. The teacher is now being transferred and insofar as these children are concerned I do not anticipate any difficulty in respect to attendance when the new school term opens September 6th.

In regard to the following children Louis, Jasper and Mary Joseph, we have reached the point where we do not know what to do. The family's home is at Turnour Island but live most of the time at Alert Bay. Because of poor attendance at the Day School I put them in the Residential School, thinking we could control them, but they have refused to stay in the school and ran away and upset the school so much that they were finally discharged. Since then we have been trying to force them to go to the Day School. The father and mother are very low type, both of them spend considerable time in Oakalla Prison. At the moment the father is just back from Oakalla but the mother is now there. To cut off their Family Allowance cheques would mean depriving these children of about the only means they have on which to exist; therefore, I have refrained from recommending their suspension.

These comments are made to justify why I cannot bring myself to the point of taking their Family Allowance away from them. We are still hoping now that we have more office assistance to improve their attendance.

In respect to the Alfred children listed on the May Report, I made a previous report under date of June 11th last, which evidently had the desired effect.

MEMORANDUM

Re: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

During a visit to my office today, Mr. Indian Superintendent Todd of the Kwawkewlth Agency, gave me the following information:

1. The two-room school now being built from prefabricated buildings of the Port Hardy camp will be used for some pupils from the Alert Bay Residential School.

2. To complete our requirements at Alert Bay, a four-room classroom block is required. This would give 10 classrooms as follows, and would provide adequate educational facilities for all pupils, both day and residential, at Alert Bay:
   - 4 classroom block, recently completed,
   - 2 classroom block, under construction,
   - 4 classroom block, as required.

3. On the mainland of Vancouver Island at Port Hardy, the Provincial School Board is having erected a four classroom building at a cost of approximately $140,000.00. This will give an indication of building costs in the Alert Bay region.

4. With this in mind, Mr. Todd and Mr. Westerlund, a local contractor, thoroughly examined the old girls' block of the former residential school. They found this building to be in fairly good condition and both agreed that it could be modernized and with a slight addition could provide 4 classrooms and teacher's apartment. The classrooms would be down stairs and the teacher's apartments upstairs.

5. The cost of this unit being modernized would be about $30,000.
6. It would be necessary to have a qualified architect or engineer from the Department thoroughly examine this old building and report as to the advisability of using it as a classroom block rather than the erection of a new building.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Canon Cook:

A contract has now been let for the moving over from Port Hardy of another building which will provide two additional classrooms to the Alert Bay Indian Day School. It is therefore likely that some of the children from the Alert Bay Residential School may be transferred to the Day School at a date earlier than we had anticipated.

I would also like to discuss with you the possibility of converting the girls' dormitory building into a Day school block. Mr. Todd had Mr. Westerlund thoroughly examine this building and he reports that it could be converted to classroom use at a cost much less than that involved in erecting a new building.

Sincerely yours,

In order to facilitate the consolidation of the classroom work at the two Alert Bay Indian Schools, it has been necessary to set forth certain procedures which will be followed. In order that all parties may be informed, I am listing these in this circular letter:

1. Pupils attending the existing classrooms at the Day School from the Residential School will be escorted.

2. Each morning the Principal of the Residential School will provide the Principal of the Day School with the names of pupils to be excused from class.

3. The classroom teachers will inform the Day School Principal of any absentees from their classes as soon as possible after the opening of the school day.

4. The classroom day will be from 9:00 o'clock to 11:45 in the morning and from 1:15 to 3:30 in the afternoon.

5. No child in the Primary Grades (1 to 3 inclusive) will be detained after the close of the normal school day and no other pupil will be detained longer than 30 minutes.

6. The Principal of the Residential School will be notified of the names of pupils from St. Michael's School detained after the close of the classroom day.

7. Teachers assigned to classes in the Residential School building will share in the supervision of the Day School pupils during the noon and recess periods.

8. The Principal of the Day School will be responsible for the grouping and grading of pupils for classroom instruction.

9. All village children will report to the Day School on the morning of Sept. 1st for class assignment.

10. These arrangements are of a temporary nature and will be changed as the operation of the plan indicates.

Ottawa, March 19th, 1934.

Sir,

Before the end of the current month, you will receive the March quarter salary cheque of the teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

Provided the teacher was on duty during the quarter, you can deliver his cheque and, at the same time, secure from him the March quarter return, which should be promptly forwarded to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Murray S. Todd, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.
Alert Bay, B.C.,
April 3, 1934.

Sir:

I enclose herewith Day School Return for the quarter ended March 31st which has been submitted by Mr. G.M. Luther, teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

The report appears to be in order, and in accordance with your letter of March 19th, file 156-29-3, I have turned over to him his salary cheque for the March quarter.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)
(Indian Agent)

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, July 31, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the appointment of a teacher to succeed Mr. George M. Luther, at the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and forwarding copy of an application from Mr. W. Percy Wickett for the position, in which he states the qualifications and experience which he possesses. It is noted that His Lordship Bishop Schofield has recommended Mr. Wickett's appointment.

The Department will approve of Mr. Wickett's appointment as from September third, next; the date the school re-opens after the present summer holidays, with salary at the rate of $80 per teaching month. I would request that you inform him of his appointment and arrange with him to begin duties on the date mentioned. Please give him every possible assistance in his work at this school.

Mr. C. C. Perry, Assistant Indian Commissioner, is being informed of the approval granted for the appointment of Mr. Wickett.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

M. S. Todd, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Approved by Minister -
see memo dated July 23/35.

Sir,

Enclosed herewith please find Day School Return submitted by Mr. Noel Stewart, teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, for the quarter ended June 30th, 1938.

Ottawa, May 8th, 1941.

Dear Madam:

The Department has not received the December Quarter Return of the Alert Bay Indian Day School. This Return should be forwarded immediately to the Department.

In future, at the close of each quarter, each teacher should prepare and forward her Return, thus precluding the necessity of further correspondence.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss D. Flick,
Alert Bay Indian Day School,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Sir,

Miss D. Flick, teacher at the Alert Bay Indian Day School, Division II, has handed me Departmental letter dated May 8th last in which enquiry is made re the returns from this school for the December quarter.

It is not understood why these returns have not been received by the Department, as the teachers of the two classrooms, Miss D. Benton and Miss D. Flick submitted them to this office on December 20th, and they were forwarded to Ottawa on the 30th of December, 1940.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of August 16, No. 156/29/4, I would recommend the purchase of a new stove for the Indian Day School at Alert Bay. I have had prices from Marshall-Wells and also from McLennan, McFeely & Prior of Vancouver, one offering a stove at $23.50, and the other at $23.75, F.O.B. Vancouver. In looking up the various stoves quoted, I am inclined to favor the one given by Marshall-Wells Company, as it is all made of riveted steel, and has no rods on the inside to burn out, and the price is slightly lower.

For your information, I may say that it is very difficult to get a heating stove or pipes that have any degree of durability in this climate. The chief reason is that the wood supplied has been in salt water for a longer or shorter time according to circumstances, a good deal of it being drift wood, and it becomes saturated with salt, and only takes a short time until the stove is completely rusted through, particularly one of a type which is fastened together with rods. The stove at present in use is not safe, and I would recommend the one offered by Marshall Wells B.C. Ltd..

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

The roof of the building requires reshingling previous to the opening of school next September. The roof should be stained and the outside of the school painted at that time.

One toilet was burned down years ago and the other has not been in a condition fit for use for a very long time. It is kept locked. Two new toilets are urgently needed.

Ottawa, May 18, 1931

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Schools for the Province of British Columbia, in a report on his recent inspection of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, states that the roof of the building requires reshingling, and that it should then be stained and the outside of the school painted. He also states that one toilet was burned down a number of years ago and the other has not been in a condition fit for use for some time, and that two new toilets are urgently needed.

Our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and it will not be possible to carry out the reshingling, painting, and erection of new toilets. The Department will, however, consider the authorizing of the minimum amount of work required in repairing the roof of the school building in order to prevent leakage during next fall and winter. You should furnish a detailed statement of the repairs needed and the approximate cost of same. You should also furnish an estimate of the cost of the material and labour in the erection of new toilets, if you consider same to be necessary this year. When we have full information, consideration will then be given as to whether funds can be provided or not.

The Inspector recommends that the teacher be paid for janitor services, in view of the good work done at this school. Please report regarding the Inspector's recommendation and state the amount per teaching month, if any, you would recommend be allowed the teacher for this work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. H. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Alert Bay, B.C.,
June 6, 1931.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of May 18, regarding the matter of the Alert Bay Indian Day School. Yesterday I examined the building, and I think that with very slight repairs, the roof could be made to last another year. The belfry requires entire new shingling, as many of the shingles have blown off, and the shingled cornice on the front end of the building need a few, but one thousand shingles would easily put the roof in condition for another year.

Regarding the painting of the School, seeing that the Department is so very short of funds, for the present time, the School could be easily left for another year. It is now twenty years since the building was erected, and it was well painted at the time, and so far as I can recollect has not been painted since, but the paint is still in reasonably good condition.

With reference to the toilets, I would recommend that two entire new toilets be built with a cess-pool underneath. The total expense for everything should not be over fifty dollars.

Regarding that portion of your letter referring to janitor services, I would recommend that the sum of five dollars per month be given to the teacher in connection with this work. He has done up to the present time, the bulk of the work himself, with a little help from the children, and he has purchased soap and washing powders at his own expense. I have talked the matter over with him, and he would be quite satisfied with five dollars a month for each teaching month to cover this work.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)
Indian Agent

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the repairs required to the roof at the Alert Bay Indian Day School building and the building of new toilets.

Sir-

In your letter No. 156-29-5 of September 20, 1933, the Department authorized the erection of a flag pole for the Indian Day School at Alert Bay. Today I am in receipt of an account handed me by Mr. Alvin Alfred of Alert Bay for the cost in connection with this in the amount of $26.00, and which I enclose herewith.

This arrangement was made before I took office and upon looking up the files it appears the Department did not expect this to cost very much. When this statement was rendered to me I made enquiries as to what arrangements Mr. Newnham had made and Mr. Alfred informed me that Mr. Newnham told him to go ahead and get the pole and present his bill. It is apparent that a misunderstanding has taken place, as I gather the Department thought the pole could be obtained close to the school, which, however was not possible.

I would, however, like to point out the pole was donated to the school as well as the pulley, and the entire cost is made up of labour getting the pole and preparing it for erection. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing account for $26.00, in connection with the flag pole for the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

As you will note from official letter of September 20th, last, Inspector Barry advised the Department that the expense involved for a flag pole would be almost negligible. It is realized, of course, that authority to proceed with the erection of the flag pole was given before you took charge of the agency.

The regulations of our Accounting Branch will not permit payment of the account in the manner in which it has been presented; and therefore the account is being returned. Receipts will have to be forwarded, covering the cost of the gasoline included in the item of $16.50. The account will also have to show the number of days the three men were employed and the rate per day. The Department does not consider it was necessary to give the flag pole five coats of paint. Before again submitting the account, you should arrange with Mr. Alfred to reduce it by a considerable amount, as it will not be possible to pay $26 for this service.

Sir,

In my Estimates for 1936-37 I requested an amount of $440.00 for repairs to the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and under date of May 6th the Department replied to my letter of April 23rd advising they had only provided a sum not exceeding $250.00 for this school, also advising owing to lack of funds it was not possible to consider any exterior painting this year.

Since receiving this letter I have gone to considerable trouble in obtaining prices from various sources as well as cost of labour for all the schools which require repairs. Recently while at Village Island I discussed the matter of the Village Island Day School with the teacher and it was decided owing to this building belonging to the Church and requiring more repairs than was possible to do this year, to let it stand over until another year. The teacher has agreed to leave the building thoroughly cleaned and we have definitely decided to get along at this school with just a good cleaning for this year, and we do not intend to ask the Department for any expenditure in connection with this school for the present year.

The Alert Bay Day School, as the Department knows, is one of the largest and most important schools we have in the Agency. It is located at the Agency headquarters and has a large attendance, a great many children also coming from the outlying districts and attending school for short time while their parents are in the village. This has necessarily caused the school to be used more than any other school in the Agency. The building itself is over twenty-five years old, and nothing has been spent on it with the exception of the roof being reshingled last year. The building has also been used for meetings and Church services, which has helped to hasten its deterioration.

At present we have old home-made desks in the school which I am arranging to replace with modern desks to be obtained from the Residential School, which are extra for their requirements, and I have arranged to have them put in the Day School as soon as the decorating and repair work is completed.

We feel this school should be one of our best kept schools and a credit to the Department in view of it being located in a central place, and would therefore like very much for the Department to approve of having the exterior of this building painted as well as the interior. As there will be some of the alterations new material will be supplied to the stoves and a portion of the building, and if we do not paint it it will be extremely unsightly as well as not being kept in a good state of preservation.

We have gone to a lot of trouble in getting various prices, and I wish to submit to the Department for their approval the prices as follows:-
To complete the interior decorating, new floor, steps, repairs to windows, new fence and labour, also including one coat of paint for the exterior and labour, it will cost in the neighborhood of $375.00.

Hardware prices were obtained from Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd of Vancouver, and came to approximately $75.00. Building materials were obtained from three different lumber firms, the cheapest being from Telegraph Cove Mills Ltd., a local concern, in the amount of $132.17, and the total cost of labour would be $170.00.

I would like very much to give the school one coat of paint on the outside, and for the Department's information the total cost of this including labour is $87.19. In my opinion it is well worth it as it will preserve the building and it was only through having other work done that I could obtain as good a price as this as the same man would be doing the work.

It is almost impossible to start the necessary work at this school without completing it, and in view of the fact that we have decided to leave the Village Island School for this year, I would urgently request the Department to approve of an expenditure of approximately $375.00 to complete the repairs to the Alert Bay Day School.

The price of building materials has gone up since a year ago when the Estimates were compiled, which is making it a little difficult to keep within our figures, but we feel $375.00 is a very reasonable figure for this work.

Would the Department kindly advise me of their decision in regard to this school. As it will take a little time to get the materials ordered and delivered, I would appreciate a reply by return of mail as we are anxious to have the work completed before the school re-opens at the first of September.

Sir,

Under date of July 9th, 1936, Departmental letter No. 156-29-5, approval was granted for repairs to the Alert Bay Indian Day School in the amount of $375.00.

We now submit all accounts in connection with this work, the total amount being $437.33, which as you will note, slightly exceeds the amount authorized but which work out almost exactly to our original estimate asked for in our letter of April 23rd, 1936. Every effort was made to keep the cost of the repairs as low as possible, but when repairing an old building it is almost impossible to estimate the exact figures as you invariably find other small repairs required which could not be determined before the work started, and I felt it was better to make a complete job rather than leave something undone just to keep within the amount specified for the sake of a few dollars.

My first plan was to repair the present fence, but when we started to work on it we found it was in such shape that it was not practical to do this, but rather build a new fence on three sides of the school grounds. We should have build a new fence entirely around the grounds, but I did not wish to go to any further expense without taking it up with the Department, it would cost approximately $30.00 to complete this fence, and if the Department would approve of it still feel we should build this fence this year; it could be done by Indian labour, and then the school would be in excellent shape. If the Department agree to this, would you kindly advise me and I will arrange to have the work done.

For the Department's information, I would like to give them a short report on the actual work done at the school and the changes carried out. When the building was originally erected the windows were placed on both sides as well as the end, and the classroom has always been arranged so that the children were facing the north side of the building with the light behind them. This has been very detrimental to their work and health, and it was deemed advisable when making the repairs, to remove all the windows on the north side and west end and place them on the south side of the building.

The entrance to the building was also at the west end, making it necessary to have about ten steps leading to the entrance. This made the building very cold. This entrance was closed up entirely, the steps removed, and an entrance put into the building at the rear of the south side of the school. A small porch was built over the doorway, and the classroom seats now face the west end of the building whereby the light comes over the children's left shoulder.
A new floor was put in the building, and as it was found the old blackboards were in very bad condition, these were all re-arranged. We now have on the west end of the building a blackboard 4 x 12' and along the north side a blackboard 3½ x 24'. When the Campbell River School was built I had one blackboard over which was not required, and I had that shipped to Alert Bay and this has been used in the Alert Bay Day School. It was found necessary to purchase one blackboard 3½ x 8' to match the one brought from Campbell River. These are some of the items which were not figured on in the original estimate but were found necessary to complete the work.

Some time ago I discovered in the Residential School some twenty-eight school desks which were not in use at that time, and the Principal, Mr. Anfield, offered to loan them to me for use in the Alert Bay Day School, but when I went to get them owing to the necessity of using extra desks in the Residential School this term I was only able to get about fourteen, and these were badly in need of repair. We repaired them and are using them temporarily along with the old wooden seats which have been in the school for the last twenty-five years.

Now that this school is properly equipped, I feel the Department should purchase modern desks as the building is going to be used for only school purposes from now on. The old hand-made desks are very dilapidated, which no doubt Mr. Phelan will remember from his visit to the school last year.

The building has been decorated inside and out, repairs have been made to the windows, and the building is now in first-class shape and a credit to the Department. I would appreciate if they would advise me if the $30.00 estimated to finish the fence around the school grounds could be approved.

It will be noted we are forwarding the charges for labour on one voucher in the total amount of $189.75, and if the cheque is sent to me, made payable to the Kwawkewlth Indian Agency Trust Account, separate cheques will be made from this office for the workers whose names appear on the time-sheet.

I trust the accounts will be found in order, and would recommend that cheques be forwarded as shown by the attached vouchers.

Your obedient servant,

(Mrs. S. Todd)

I am very pleased indeed that the Department are considering this purchase as we have a serious problem on our hands in regard to desks at the present time. The quarterly returns for this school are going forward today and the Department will note there are fifty-four pupils on the register. This year we had twenty-two beginners, something unusual for here, and it was necessary for us to get out again all the old forms and desks which had been previously used and put them back into use to accommodate these children, seating as many as four or five in one seat.

Kwawkwelth Indian Agency Inspection Report No. 6.

Dear Sir,

SCHOOLS: I inspected the Day School at Alert Bay. There were 34 children in the class on the date of my visit. The building has been greatly improved, with the installation of new windows and other improvements. They also have got new desks. The children were clean and tidy, which is more than can be said for the class room itself. Whilst I do not wish to condemn the teacher, a young man named Wockham, I think the name is, I am not quite satisfied that everything is as it should be. However, Captain Barry's report as School Inspector would show the true status of this school.

Geo. S. Pragnell,

May expend $200 in repairing damage caused by fire at Alert Bay Indian day school

R A Hoey

PH C
(Confirmation)
On December 9th a small fire took place in Alert Bay Indian Day School which was damaged to an extent of approximately $200.00. The matter was reported to Major D.M. McKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, at Vancouver, with a recommendation requesting authority to make the necessary repairs. On December 14th instructions were received from the Commissioner's office to proceed with the necessary repairs. Owing to our inability to get a suitable person to do the work, the repairs were not commenced until December 16th when Mr. George Skinner was employed as foreman. The work was further delayed on account of a large fall of snow and very severe weather. On December 30th Mr. Skinner informed me that he was unable to complete the job as his family were all ill at home, and it was necessary for me to arrange for someone else to finish the work. This was done, and the work again started on January 2nd and we hope to have it completed shortly. Owing to our difficulties it was not possible to re-open the school on January 3rd, but it is hoped that the building will be ready for use so that school may commence on the morning of January 6th.

M. S. Tode,

Dear Sir,

On your recent visit to the Kawkawlin Agency I drew to your attention the overcrowding of children at the Alert Bay Indian Day School. At that time there were 72 children on the register with only seating accommodation for 47, and this necessitated more than one child to a seat. Since then the attendance has increased, and today we have an impossible situation with 88 children on the register.

I have made a survey and find about sixty of these children can be definitely considered permanent pupils of this school. The balance or part of them will be returning to their own villages after the New Year, although some of these would remain here no doubt if accommodation were available as there is no school at their own village.

During our discussion you requested me to try and find some means of relieving the situation, and it was suggested that a portion of the school building, now used as a Dispensary, be altered to provide for an extra classroom. I have gone into this suggestion very carefully, and find it would take too long for the alterations to be made, too costly, and would only be when completed a temporary solution and not satisfactory for a permanent classroom.

There is no doubt the Department is faced with the necessity of providing a two-roomed Day School here, as our census shows the situation will be even more acute next year. The immediate situation is intolerable, and I am sure the teacher no matter how hard he tries, cannot do justice to himself or the school.

In order to find quick relief, I investigated other means of solving our problem and interviewed Moses Alfred, a member of the Nimpkish Band who owns a hall immediately across the road from the Indian Day School, which has been occupied by the Apostolic Faith Mission. He has offered to rent this building to the Department for Eight Dollars per month as long as we need it and might even make it less if the Department thought this rent too high. Personally I feel it is very reasonable and would recommend to the Department that they accept his offer and arrange to purchase the necessary supplies and equipment to establish this extra room at the beginning of the next quarter.

The building is ideally located, and would make just as good a classroom as our present school. I rather think Captain Barry knows the hall and could give you first hand information.

The teacher informs me there are 43 children in LC grade, and possibly these children could be transferred to this junior room; that of course would be a matter of Captain Barry's instructions.

Something should be done, as I am much worried over the health of the children when there are so many of them in the one room which necessitates them doubling up in seats.

This suggestion is a temporary step to get quick relief and in the meantime the Department could make a proper survey, submitting definite plans for another room to be provided for the future. Would you kindly write me your views on the matter and I will give you any further information you may require.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read a letter dated November 19, 1938 from Indian Agent Todd with reference to the present overcrowded condition of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, in the Kwawkewlth Agency.

In my report on the above school dated April 9th last I mentioned on page 3 that we should later have to consider the provision of a second classroom at Alert Bay.

In October and November of each year there are in Alert Bay itself a number of children who are registered at other schools, either Kingcome Inlet or Mamalilikulla; but it would appear from the figures in the Indian Agent's letter that there are now sufficient Alert Bay pupils to warrant the establishment of a second or Primary Division there.

During my next inspection in the Kwawkewlth Agency in March 1939 I shall go into the matter on the ground and report in detail with regard to the necessity for a second permanent classroom and the alterations which would be needed to the present Indian Day School.

Dear Major MacKay:

You have requested my remarks on a letter dated July 3rd from Mr. Indian Agent Todd with reference to the use of Moses Alfred's hall as a second schoolroom at Alert Bay.

The provision of a permanent second classroom at the Alert Bay Indian Day School where there will be around 80 children in attendance by October of this year has been suggested as Project 4 in a report dated June 6th 1939 dealing with a future building programme. Your attention is drawn to a letter from the teacher and my reply 15/6/102 & 104 dated July 4th last.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 15-6-9977 dated June 24th last, in which you request particulars in respect to the suggestion that Moses Alfred's hall be used as a second classroom in connection with the Alert Bay Indian Day School, I beg to give you the following information. The approximate cost to put the building in suitable repair for use would be as follows:

**Repairs**
- Reshingling - material and labour, approx. $80.00
- Incidental repairs - replacement of window panes, repairs to steps, foundation, painting, etc... $75.00

**Heating**
- Circulator heater, stove pipes and new chimney, approximately $100.00

This would be the outside figure, and it is possible the work could be done for less by employing local labour by the day rather than contract. I believe Mr. Fred Sharpe who built the Preventorium and who has done other work for the Department, could be employed, and I would strongly recommend that his services be obtained in this particular.

I would like to add in my opinion the Department is faced with building a second classroom at the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and it does seem a waste of money to spend too much on someone else's property when it can only be considered at the best a temporary arrangement.

This building sits on the foreshore of the Indian Reserve opposite the present Day School and is a very dangerous place for children coming out of, as they must step immediately on to the public highway. It is, of course, a means of relieving our present situation, but I feel the Department would be well advised in building a second classroom immediately even though funds would have to be transferred from elsewhere where possibly the need is not so great.

While I have not obtained an estimate from a contractor of the exact cost of enlarging the existing school, nevertheless I feel it would cost in the neighborhood of $2500.00, including labour and materials.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.
In addition to this, we are faced with providing a playground for the children. At the present time this large number of children attending this school have no playground and are continually out on the street even though the teacher does his best to prevent it. The ground is very hilly, and on the side of a hill, and I feel in order to make a playground for the children a retaining wall about four feet high should be built along the face of the playground and the grounds levelled off. This would give them a small playground and would keep them off the street and away from danger. I consider the total cost of this would be approximately $200.00.

In addition to this it will be necessary to move the building now used as a Drug Dispensary to a different location and that would cost approximately $150.00.

It seems to me all these problems should be faced and worked out at the same time, as we cannot do one thing without dealing with the others. If the Department would undertake immediately to build an extra classroom and move the Dispensary, I feel the same could be done and ready for occupancy by October 1st. Moses Alfred's hall could be utilized temporarily for a month without spending any money on it, as the weather would not be too cold before the new school would be ready for opening.

I am prepared to lend every assistance and take charge of the construction and purchasing of materials if the Department so desires, and would recommend in this case that the work be done by day labour and that Mr. Sharpe be employed as foreman.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Alert Bay Indian Day School, Kwawkewlth Agency and administered under Anglican auspices, which I inspected on June 15th.

Mr. Indian Agent Todd was with me for part of the inspection period and gave me considerable assistance. He and the teacher are certainly to be congratulated on the fine work that has been done in this school under very adverse conditions of overcrowding.

There are some sixty pupils on the school register at the present time and we may expect slightly in excess of eighty children to be in attendance during the academic year starting in September 1939. The present overcrowding is of course particularly bad for the children in the way of health and makes effective teaching a most difficult matter. I simply am at a loss to understand how Mr. Stewart managed to carry on the school in the fine way he did during the past year. The addition of the twenty-five schoolchildren in September makes the provision of a second Division, room and teacher, a most urgent matter, even if this was only possible by the closing of some less wanted school in another part of B.C.

I wish to draw your attention to the fact that there are only some twenty-five single crown desks in this school. To seat the remainder of the children at present in attendance Mr. F.E. Anfus, Principal of St. Michael's Residential School, was good enough some time ago to lend to the Indian Agent some dozen single desks. These desks are only here on temporary loan and will be needed at St. Michael's School later.

To seat the children expected next September we shall need in addition to the present ten No. 3 and fifteen No. 5 single crown school desks the property of the school the following:

| Crown Single School Desks Required |
|-----------------------------------|
| 2 only Teacher's Desks             |
| 9 only Single Desk Sections No. 5  |
| 16 only Single Desk Sections No. 4 |
| 14 only Single Desk Sections No. 3 |
| 16 only Single Desk Sections No. 2 |

I would strongly recommend the supply of the above desks by September 1st 1939. With the twenty-five desks now the property of the Indian Day School seating would then be provided for the expected eighty pupils, provided they be placed in the usual rows of eight desks and mounted on strips of wood at the regulation distance apart. Forty desks or five rows of eight should be placed in each classroom.
To provide the second classroom necessary at Alert Bay I would suggest that following work be carried out during the summer months:

(1) Removal from its present unsuitable position at the end of the school building of the small dispensary to a site some two hundred yards away on Departmental land.

The site near the Indian Agent's residence shown to me by Mr Todd appears to be highly suitable for the Dispensary. There is a roadway and possibly the St. Michael's School tractor could be used in moving the small frame structure.

(2) Extension of the present school building at each end for about twenty feet.

(3) Moving of windows and supply of six new large windows for new room.

(4) Provision of entrance hall in middle of reconstructed building, this hall to be at least fifteen feet wide Entrance to each classroom to be from this hall.

(5) On the end of the extended building next the village street where the ground falls away and excavation would be a minimum the provision of a Manual Training basement room

(6) The provision of a woodburning hot air furnace with pipes in partly excavated furnace room under building and next brick chimney lately erected.

In addition to the teacher's desk and school desks mentioned in an earlier part of this letter six eight foot lengths of four foot wide Asbestoslate Blackboard would be required for the second or new room.

Should the Department find it impossible to carry out the recommendations of the Indian Agent which will be along the same lines as I have suggested above, there is only one other possible plan, and a much inferior plan at that.

(a) The renting at not more than $10.00 a month of the hall located almost opposite the present school and owned by Moses Alfred (Indian)

(b) The provision of a wood burning circulatory heater of fair size for the rented room. This heater would remain the property of the school, if the rented room was later given back to Moses Alfred.

(c) The reshingling of the roof of Moses Alfred's hall.

In addition to the school desks and teacher's desk mentioned above only two lengths of Asbestoslate Board each 4 feet by 8 feet would be needed, should it be decided to rent this building in place of building additions to the ends of the present school.

Whichever plan is adopted, and I should most strongly recommend the first (the addition to the present building) a second teacher, an Anglican lady with special qualifications in Primary Work and experience in an Indian School, would be needed from the opening of school in September next.

The nomination of a teacher for the proposed second Division at Alert Bay Indian Day School would no doubt be in the hands of the Right Reverend H. Sexton, D.D., Bishop of Columbia Victoria, B.C. and I suggest that the Anglican Bishop's nomination be forwarded through the Indian Commissioner's office to insure that the Department may have a professional report on her qualifications before any appointment is made.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry Inspector.

AGENT'S REPORT ON KWA'KWAK'WEULTH AGENCY FOR AUGUST 1939.

The entire month of August has been spent at the Agency headquarters. Owing to a second classroom being established in connection with the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and the necessity of transferring children from the Residential school to the Day school and other places, it was necessary for me to remain here to supervise the repairs and changes which are taking place.

The second classroom which we are providing here will open on time, but we have had difficulty in completing same owing to the Department not approving of the full amount of money I estimated it would cost to put this building in repair. In this connection I should like to inform the Department Mr. Stewart, the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, returned earlier at my request in order that he could help us rearrange the equipment and supplies before school opened. Mr. Sharp, who assisted with the carpenter work, has offered to donate some of his services to the department if necessary in order to complete the work, but in my opinion this should not be necessary and it is my intention to put in his full time even though it does exceed the total amount of $205.00 approved by the department, and I hope any small expenditure beyond the approved amount will be paid.

The Residential school opened on August 28th with a full attendance.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

At a regular meeting of the Church Committee held on 2nd instant, the writer was instructed to advise you with further reference to your letter of August 21st addressed to the Secretary of the Church Committee, Christ Church, Alert Bay and the reply thereto under date of September 26th, that the following resolution received unanimous support:

"That the Church Committee, Christ Church, Alert Bay, in regular meeting assembled, endorse and approve the suggestion made by the secretary in his letter to the Indian Agent under date of September 26th regarding the "dispensary and platform" at the Indian Day School; with the proviso, however, that action by the Bishop and Synod in trust in connection with the disputed title be delayed until the title to the lot on which the Indian Day School is built be clarified, it being the conviction of this Church Committee that the lot in question is the property of the Synod in trust from the C.M.S. of London, England, to which Society this land was given before the Nimipish Reserve was established, such title being later confirmed in writing by Judge O'Reilly in 1887 whilst acting as a Reserves Commissioner."

Very sincerely yours,

4th October, 1939.
Sir,

For many years the Anglican Church have claimed an equity in the Department's Day School at Alert Bay, particularly in that portion of the building now used as a Drug Dispensary. As it is the Department's intention to erect a second classroom, it is necessary to have the situation clarified before any addition can be made to the building.

With this in mind, I wrote to the Church Committee of Christ Church, Alert Bay, and suggested to them if they wished to take this portion of the building and remove it from its present location, it be Church property. I would recommend to our Department that they relinquish their equity, with the understanding that the Church pay all expenses of moving this part of the School building to Church property. On the other hand, if the Church did not wish to do this, I suggested they waive their equity to the Department so that an unconditional title to the building could be obtained by either.

On October 4th, I received the enclosed copy of letter from Mr. F.E. Anfield, secretary-treasurer of Christ Church, in which you will please note the Church are now claiming to own the lot on which our Alert Bay Indian Day School is located.

This is rather a serious question the Church has raised, and if it is correct then the Department have build a school, representing an investment of approximately Three Thousand Dollars, on property which they do not own. I am of the opinion the Church are confused and believe the Department may have given the C.M.S. of London, England, only a letter of permission to build, and not a title to the lot.

Would the Department please have their files searched and advise me at their earliest convenience, as I am anxious to have this clarified at an early date. It is noted on the survey of Nimpkish Reserve No.1; no record is shown of any lot ever having been surveyed and transferred to anyone.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Sir,

Attached please find voucher No.281 in the amount of $40.00 in favour of Mr. Moses Alfred of Alert Bay for rent of a building used as a second classroom for the Alert Bay Indian Day School, for the months of September, October, November and December at the rate of $10.00 per month as per an arrangement with the Department at the time the building was taken over.

In this connection, I would point out arrangement was only made at that time for the academic year 1939-40, but as it is necessary to continue the use of the building, I presume the Department will be satisfied under these arrangements, and I would kindly ask that they write me giving approval of same so that our files may be complete.

In case the Department raise the question of not wishing to pay rental for the month of September, during which school was not in session, I beg to advise I discussed this matter with Moses Alfred, owner of the building, and he told me it was his understanding that the Government were taking the building over for the full academic term of ten months at the time the original arrangement was made, and that he was not prepared to accept rental for only nine months. Personally, I agree with him as the Department cannot expect him to lose money through the decision of keeping the school closed during the month of September; in fact, we have no other alternative than to pay it, or be ordered out of the building by Alfred. I would therefore recommend that the attached voucher be paid as submitted.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the payment of rental to Moses Alfred for the building used as a second class room at the Alert Bay Day School.

The Department feels that Alfred should not insist on being paid for the month of September. As far as the Department is aware the building was not rented at the time it was originally taken over for school purposes. You will also remember that we have spent a considerable sum of money in repairing the building and no doubt this improved it considerably. I, therefore, cannot agree with you that Alfred would be losing any money by renting us this building for a nine-month term during the current academic year. Payment of the account will be withheld until we hear further from you.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of January 25th last, file 156-29-5 in connection with the Department's use of the Alfred Hall for the Alert Bay Indian Day School, I beg to advise upon receipt of your letter I interviewed Alfred and explained the Department's views and was informed he was not prepared to accept rental for the building for only nine months in the year.

For the Department's information, Alfred had this hall rented to the Pacific Coast Missionary Society previous to the Department taking it over, and received his regular rent from them with the exception of three months in the year which he donated to this church as a contribution to the work.

I must point out the Department we have no lease on this building, and unless we are prepared to pay what Alfred asks, and what was agreed upon, he has the right to ask us to vacate the building although as he is a very sensible and reasonable Indian I do not think he would ask us to do so. However I believe the Department should carry out the original arrangement and pay for ten month's rental.

I should like to say I have tried ever since I have been here to economise wherever possible and more particularly since the War, but in this case I feel we are obligated to him and should pay ten month's rent for the use of the building.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Todd's letter of July 12th, with reference to proposed repairs to the junior room of the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

It will be noted that Mr. Todd has been able to secure the services of a contractor to decorate the interior of the room at a cost of $65.00, including material and labor and, although the detail provided by Mr. Todd is not considered sufficient, I would recommend that an accountable cheque for this amount be forwarded to him. In the meantime, I am writing to Mr. Todd requesting further details regarding what the Department will receive for the amount expended.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

In our estimates for 1944-1945 an amount of Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00) was provided for repairs to Indian Day Schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency. Since then I have been advised that this money is available, but Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) of same has been spent in cleaning the interior of the Campbell River Indian Day School, which leaves us a balance of Two Hundred Seventy-Five Dollars ($275.00).

I have been wanting to have needed repairs done at both classrooms of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, but until today I have not been able to find anyone, due to the scarcity of labour, who will undertake the work; and, therefore, no action could be taken before now.

We have in Alert Bay at the present time a Mr. J.W. Sanderson, who is doing some decorating for the B.C. Packers Ltd., and I interviewed him to see if he would be good enough to decorate the junior room, as a spare job to fit in with his present contract. Mr. Sanderson went with me to the classroom, looked it over, and stated he would undertake the work, providing he could do it evenings, and offered to supply material and labour, completing the job in full, for the sum of Sixty-Three Dollars ($63.00).

As the department is aware, this classroom is 26' x 46' with 12' walls. It being larger than the usual classroom, it will naturally cost more money to decorate.

I consider this offer to be reasonable, as he has agreed to repair the blackboards, decorate cupboards, etc., for the full price of Sixty-Three Dollars ($63.00). I consider we are very fortunate in being able to find someone to do this work and

P.t.o.
would recommend that the department accept his offer. I would appreciate if you would kindly forward me an Encumbrance Requisition to cover same at your earliest convenience, so that Mr. Sanderson may take advantage of any convenient opportunity to proceed with the work.

Extra c.c. enclosed.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

July 26, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant, arrangements are being made to forward Indian Agent Todd a cheque for $63 in connection with proposed repairs to the junior room of the Alert Bay Day School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

The senior room of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, which is the property of Moses Alfred, Indian of the Nimpkish Band, Alert Bay, has been rented from him at an annual rental of One Hundred Twenty Dollars ($120.00). This building is being used temporarily until such time as the department can build a second classroom.

When this building was taken over by the department for this purpose it was necessary for them to spend some money on it before it could be used, and at that time we felt the new classroom would be built in the matter of a few years. However, the war has intervened with the department's plans. It has been my views that we should not spend any more money on this building when it did not belong to us than was necessary, and for that reason I have refrained from asking the department to make any further repairs.

However, it has been known to me that the building is very cold in the winter time. In fact, so cold that the teacher and children have to wear their overcoats in school. The building itself is merely a shell built of two-inch lumber - drop-siding on the outside and V-joint on the inside. The lumber was evidently badly put on and has shrunk leaving cracks. This building is sitting on piles over the salt-water, and the damp cold wind makes it impossible to keep the rooms warm. There have been days when the teacher was forced to close school on account of not being able to heat the building.

If the department intends to continue using this building for some length of time it would be in our interests to re-line the building and put in another floor. At the present time we have available Two Hundred Twelve Dollars ($212.00), which could be used for this purpose, but I do not think it will quite complete the work, and there is no use starting it unless we can finish the job. I think that the necessary work could be done for Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00), and I believe I could get someone to do the work during the month of August, providing we are able to obtain the material.

The building should be re-lined with 3-ply veneer. This veneer could be of second-grade quality with one good surface, and then stained. The floor should be of 1"x4", #3 edge-grained flooring. It will require one thousand (1,000) square feet of 3-ply and one thousand (1,000) f.m. of flooring.

If the department could purchase the 3-ply this year and do this much and leave the floor for later on, it would help a great deal towards keeping the building sufficiently warm to get by with.

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

Further to my letter of July 12th last in respect to repairs to the senior classroom of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, owned by Moses Alfred and rented by the department from him; I beg to advise you I have discussed this matter with Moses and he has agreed to help the department to the extent of One Hundred Twenty Dollars ($120.00), towards re-lining and re-flooring the building.

This has put the matter in a new light and I would appreciate if you would do your best to obtain the material to carry out this work, as we will now have sufficient funds with which to complete the building properly.

Mr. Alfred suggests that we re-line the walls with Gyproc Wallboard, and in this I concur. I think this material could be purchased as there is no priority rating required. It will be necessary that we act immediately in order that I can take advantage of an opportunity to obtain the labour when it is available.

It will require, as stated in my last letter, one thousand (1,000) square feet of Gyproc Wallboard and one thousand (1,000) Tbm. #3 edge-grained flooring. If you could purchase the above and have it shipped, and leave other incidentals in my hands to look after, I will be glad to do so.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

In reply to your letter of October 23rd last, file #156-29-5, I beg to enclose, as requested, tenders for the complete wiring of both Indian Day Schools at Alert Bay.

I am informed that the Provincial Government are now using the new fluorescent fixtures rather than the old system for two reasons. The lighting system is much easier on the children's eyes and the consumption of electricity is about one-third, which would reduce our annual cost considerably, even though the original cost of installation is somewhat higher.

Under these circumstances I feel that in the long run it would pay the department to install this type of light. Ordinarily we would have to have two meters as these classrooms are in separate buildings with a public highway running between, but I have arranged with the Power Company to operate both schools under one meter which will mean quite a saving to the department each year.

This tender is being submitted by the Manager of the Pacific Power and Water Co. Ltd., Alert Bay, who supply the energy and the installation will be done by their own help. The tender calls for first-class installation and complying with Provincial Regulations.

It would be appreciated if the department could advise me at an early date, as I visited the schools only yesterday and found the dark rooms very difficult for all concerned.

(M. S. Tod)
Indian Agent.

Replying to your letter of November 21st last, file #215-6-7300, with reference to supplying adequate light for the Alert Bay Indian Day Classrooms, I wish to advise you as follows:

1. The school hours have already been adjusted to take advantage of daylight hours. This policy has been followed for years now on account of the poor visibility in the classrooms.

2. When the school building was altered several years ago I re-arranged the windows to obtain the maximum light, but this does not give sufficient.

It is, therefore, important that in the interests of the children's eyesight and their work, that artificial lighting be installed at an early date.

As requested, I have obtained new tenders for both rooms, without reflectors, which amounts to One Hundred Ten Dollars ($110.00). It is regretted that the original lighting system submitted could not be installed even though the initial cost was higher than the one now being submitted; as the cost of our consumption of power will be nearly four (4) times greater, and this spread over a period of years will run into a considerable sum of money.

However, I still feel we should have reflectors of some description to get maximum light properly distributed throughout the rooms, and as these will cost approximately Twenty Dollars

p.t.o.
($20.00) for the eight (8) lights required, I would recommend that the department authorize me to purchase these which would be in addition to the One Hundred Ten Dollars ($110.00) tender enclosed herewith.

Possibly the department would advise me on this and also let me have their decision in respect to the tenders enclosed, as I am very much worried about these dark rooms and want to see it rectified as quickly as possible.

Encs.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

If funds are available, I would recommend that an expenditure of $130.00 be authorized for this purpose.
