Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

We have received from Indian Agent Todd his report
for the year ended March 31, 1946. In this communication he
mentions the new schools which he considers are needed in his
agency. He refers particularly to Alert Bay Day School and points
out that although we have two rooms at this school we have only
the services of one teacher. He also states that three rooms
are really necessary to accommodate the number of pupils.

For your information I enclose copy of a letter
which I am writing to Mr. Todd, and you will note that if there
were another building available in Alert Bay we would be prepared
to rent it until such time as adequate provision could be made
for the children of that village by the erection of a new school.

Mr. Todd's reference to the Airport at Port Hardy
is as follows:-

"For the Department's information, I am told
unofficially that the large Airport at Port Hardy, now under the
jurisdiction of the Department of Transport, is going to be
dismantled. There are endless buildings on this Airport that
would be suitable for classrooms, and if the Department would
employ men, to be paid out of this $12,000,000.00 we have been
told about, and make arrangements to take some of these buildings
over, we could proceed at once with the building or the necessary
school and other buildings in this Agency. It seems this is the
best and most suitable procedure to get our building program
under way, and unless we act reasonably soon, these buildings will be torn down and the lumber shipped to Vancouver or some other large centre and used for various undertakings."

Are you aware who is handling the disposal of the building mentioned and do you think there is any opportunity of our obtaining it?

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, April 30, 1946.

Mr. H. S. Todd, Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

I have carefully read that portion of your 1945 report which refers to Indian education in your agency. We have noted the schools that you believe are needed and will give your recommendations every possible consideration.

However, I regret that no action can be taken this year in erecting any of the schools which you mention. Owing to the policy of encouraging the erection of private homes, our public building program has been somewhat curtailed and no provision was made in the current year's appropriation for buildings on the reserves to which you refer.

I am communicating with Indian Commissioner MacKay regarding your statement in connection with the Airport at Port Hardy. If there were any building available in Alert Bay, we would be prepared to rent it, but I note from your report that no building is available.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
EXTRACT FROM ANNUAL GENERAL REPORT OF M. S. TODD,
Indian Agent, Kwawkewlth Agency, for year ending March 31, 1946.

In the Indian Village of Alert Bay we have two classrooms - one being held in the Department Day School, and the other in a building rented from a local Indian. On the Quarterly Return ended March 31st, of the junior room, the Department will note there were sixty-one pupils, and in the senior room where grades 3-8 are taught, we have forty-six children. This is an intolerable situation. The senior room is now closed due to the teacher's health being broken down, and we have requested that a new teacher be appointed, but to date the school is still closed. Mrs. Massey, teacher in the junior room, cannot possibly carry this load much longer. It is not only unfair but unjust to allow this situation to continue. I have tried to find some building that we could use as a third classroom but there is nothing in Alert Bay available. We are faced with building a three-room modern Indian Day School to take care of the educational needs of this village. The place is growing year by year, and it seems a tragedy in the lives of these young children that provision is not made so that they can receive a proper education. Consideration should be given to the immediate erection of a three-room Indian Day School in Alert Bay, to be part of the Rehabilitation Scheme. As we are told funds are available, and with men out of work, I can see no reason why this project should not be undertaken at once.

For the Department's information, I am told unofficially that the large Airport at Port Hardy, now under the jurisdiction of the Department of Transport, is going to be dismantled. There are endless buildings on this Airport that would be suitable for classrooms, and if the Department would employ men, to be paid out of this $12,000,000.00 we have been told about, and make arrangements to take some of these buildings over, we could proceed at once with the building of the necessary school and other buildings in this Agency. It seems this is the best and most suitable procedure to get our building program under way, and unless we act reasonably soon, these buildings will be torn down and the lumber shipped to Vancouver or some other large centre and used for various undertakings.
EXTRACT FROM ANNUAL REPORT OF M. S. TODD, Indian Agent, Kwawkewlth Agency, for year ending March 31, 1946.

I will give you what I think is necessary to accomplish the desired results:

A new three-room Day School at Alert Bay, with teacherage, is necessary to properly educate the many children in this locality.

New classrooms for St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, are required.

A new School with Teacherage should be built at Turnour Island to provide education for the children in this village.

A new School at Cape Mudge to replace the present one is necessary, but could be left until other schools are built where there are no schools at the present time.

A teacherage should be built in connection with the Campbell River Indian Day School.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

This short report is being made in respect to conditions at our Alert Bay Indian Day School.

This school consists of two rooms; one building is owned by the Department and the other is an old building owned by an Indian which we have made some repairs on in recent years in order to make it usable, and for which we pay $10.00 a month rent. Two teachers are now employed.

Yesterday I had a visit from the teachers and was informed they could not carry on under the present conditions and stated that unless some new arrangement or assistance could be given them, they would have to resign. They pointed out that there were forty-seven children in the senior classroom, made up of grades 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8; and forty-six in the junior room of grades 1a, b, c and grade 2. Some of the children are sitting two at a desk while others are sandwiched in and using boxes, old fashioned long seats and benches where seven or eight children are sitting together. The teachers also pointed out every bit of available space was being used and there was no room for the individual grades to stand as a group at the blackboard and take instruction. They also pointed out this unhealthy condition and stated they could not do justice to their work. They also stated there were other children walking the streets who should be in school (which I am also aware of), but due to this condition they could not admit any more.

This condition has existed for several years and has been kept before the Department.

As it was necessary to take immediate action to relieve this intolerable situation, I instructed the senior teacher to arrange for grades 3, 4, 7 and 8 to attend in the morning, and grades 5, 6, 7 and 8 to attend in the afternoon. This new arrangement became effective today and will continue for the time being. The junior room will continue to be used as at present as it was felt due to fewer grades in the classroom some relief might be effected by re-grouping them. I hope the Department will approve of the action I have taken as there was not sufficient time to refer the matter to Ottawa for your approval.

In the Department's letter of April 30th last, file M56-29-5, they informed me that if I could obtain accommodation for another classroom somewhere they would agree to the third teacher. So far I have been unable to find any available room in Alert Bay where we could establish a third room.

Recently the department have taken over the Army Camp at Port Hardy and I understand some of these buildings are to be used for schools. These buildings will make ideal classrooms and now that we have the buildings available, it is a question of having them delivered, transferred and

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6384, File 800-5, part 3)
I feel no time should be lost in undertaking this program.

If the Department will give me the authority to go ahead, and provide the necessary funds, I will undertake to have these buildings dismantled, transported to Alert Bay and erected, and have them ready for occupancy at the earliest possible date. There are at the present time good Indian carpenters whom I can employ to help erect these prefabricated buildings on their present site, but it will have to be done and completed during this winter before the fishing season starts next Spring. There are also one or two good white carpenters whom I believe I could employ to assist. It would be necessary to have this whole undertaking based on the basis of day labour as it would be impossible to get anyone to take a contract. I am satisfied it would cost less by day labour rather than by contract - in any case there is no one available who will take a contract.

A few days ago I recommended that funds be provided to clear the site for the new school as well as burning refuse and gravelling the road. I hope the Department will approve of this so that we can take advantage of the bulldozer which is still here on the island before it leaves for Klickseewy Reserve to start lagging operations in a few days' time.

In a previous report I presented plans for the new school and estimated the same could be completed for approximately $6,000.00. I still feel this can be done, barring unforeseen circumstances.

As the matter of school accommodation is so serious it seems to me we should now take advantage of this wonderful opportunity and provide the necessary classrooms, and when doing so consider our own needs so that the question of sufficient accommodation will be settled for years to come. There are going to be many Indian families locate in Alert Bay on the Industrial School site as soon as the status of this Reserve is settled. These are young people with growing-up families who wish to get away from the settlement, and they consider it is the only chance they have in which they can do so. It is this custom which is holding back my young married Indians and I consider the Department should leave nothing unturned to make it possible for them to shake themselves loose from it so that they can prosper and become progressive, law-abiding citizens. The Indians realize most of their earning power comes from fishing and, therefore, it would be far better for them to live in Alert Bay where their children could enjoy good school facilities and receive proper medical care from our local hospital and medical officers. This they are deprived of living in isolated Indian villages elsewhere. We have a wonderful opportunity now to really help them.

At the present time we are paying tuition fees and board, etc., for Indian boys and girls to attend high school in Victoria and Vancouver, which is costing the Department considerable sums. If we had a proper day school here it would pay us to establish a boarding school with dormitories so that the children could combine work with education right up to grade 12 and still live at home. This year I have seven children attending high school and if it were possible for them to attend high school and remain at home I know there would be a great many more who would avail themselves of this opportunity. We would then be giving the Indians the very
thing they are pleading for. A high school in connection with this day school would serve my whole Agency, and now that we have the buildings that could be utilized at very little cost, provision should be made to that end.

I might mention that our present Indian Day School in Alert Bay is a very old building, but could be used for many good purposes, other than for school purposes, either by the Department or the Indians, after the new school had been built. It is felt that all classrooms should be in one unit whereby the principal would have immediate supervision and control at all times.

I, therefore, recommend that when we erect this new school, all these suggestions referred to be given due consideration. Possibly the Department would give my recommendations early consideration, as I am anxious to take steps to improve conditions here at the earliest possible date.

(Ms. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

June 4th, 1947.

Mr. Hoey

Referring to your memoranda of May 5th and May 29th and to our telephone conversation this morning, if the buildings referred to are those at Camp "A" near Port Hardy airport, a description of them and suggestions as to their dismantling are contained in my report of October 10th, last, to Mr. Jackson, a copy of which was supplied to you.

It would not be feasible to transport the buildings by water without tearing them down, but the thirty-one Loxstave prefabricated buildings, referred to in my report, are very amenable to dismantling and loading on barges.

Your Indian Commissioner, in co-operation with our Engineer, would have to make arrangements for the securing of the necessary barges and the settling of transportation rates with the tug or other boat that would be used for tow purposes.

When I was at Port Hardy, Mr. Keith J. Robinson, Airport Manager, was very co-operative and said that if he could get permission from the Department of Transport he would have time to exercise supervision over the dismantling and loading of the Loxstave buildings. He said the Department of Transport had a two-ton Dodge truck with stake body and a D-8 tractor with power winch that might be loaned. All arrangements in this connection could, it is believed, be made with the Department of Transport office at Vancouver, providing this equipment is still at the airport.
The watchman looking after these buildings, as well as the R.C.A.F. Hospital at Port Hardy, was Mr. F. Carrington of the Corps of Commissionaires, and he was quite anxious to co-operate in the dismantling and unloading of the buildings providing he could be paid suitable wages while on this work.

This is a project that will have to be organized and looked after by Mr. Webb's office in conjunction with Major MacKay.

There are two ways of financing this project but perhaps the better one would be for your Indian Commissioner to meet the expenditures involved on the certificate of our Engineer, or the foreman, rather than for funds to be transferred to our Engineering and Construction Service. There are so many operations that will be handled largely by your officers that it would be simpler if your Vancouver office handled all the finances.

Director.

T.S. Mills, Esq., Chief Engineer, Ottawa.

Re: Removal of Buildings from Port Hardy Military Camp,
Vancouver Island, B.C.

Your letter of June 25 advising that the above work is to be carried out under financial responsibilities of Mr. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia is acknowledged. We are, therefore, forwarding him copies of this letter and have contacted him regarding funds.

Pursuant to your letter of June 6 and subsequent teletypes and telegrams, Mr. K.J. McClure was employed as Construction Foreman to supervise this work of removing the buildings and of re-erecting them as required. Mr. Whyte accompanied by Mr. McClure left Vancouver by steamer on June 19th and visited Alert Bay and Port Hardy, returning on June 24th.

Prior to their going north, which could not be arranged by plane, a conference was held in this office with Indian Commissioner MacKay on June 18th as to what his branch has in mind and done with the use of the buildings. Subsequent to this Mr. Whyte held a further conference with the Indian Commissioner and the Indian Affairs school inspector and submitted tentative plans for schools and teachers' dwellings so as to obtain an idea as to where buildings of various sizes should be shipped.

The first priority seems to be for a four room school at Alert Bay with two teachers' dwellings - one 48 x 24 to house a married teacher, and one 60 x 24 to house three or four single teachers; also a stores building adjacent to the Agency office.

The second priority is for a single teachers' residence at Campbell River.

Third priority is for a combined one room school and teacher's residence at Tournour Island.

Fourth priority is for a similar structure at Gilford Island.

Fifth priority is for a one or two roomed school at Cape Mudge.

Sixth priority is for a combined single room and teacher's quarters at Village Island.

It is possible the sizes or some of these schools and other buildings may later be changed.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6384, File 800-5, part 3)
On Mr. Whyte's visit north he found it was not possible to secure labour due to the fishing season which is just starting. It will, therefore, be necessary to hire men in Vancouver and transport them north. No doubt Vancouver wage scale will be necessary. Arrangements have been made to have a new sod at Port Hardy airport at an advanced charge and they can find quarters in the camp although we may find it necessary to supply bedding. The Indian Commissioner is trying to arrange for their accommodation at the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay as the school will be almost empty during July and August. By making these arrangements, a cook will not be necessary until later in the programme.

Arrangements were made through the Department of Transport for use of their vehicles on a rental basis at Port Hardy and trucks and a bulldozer can be hired at Alert Bay. At Campbell River and possibly Cape Mudge it should be possible to hire a truck but at other points all material will have to be transported by hand. At some points this may be expensive.

The Canada Kelp Company at Deer Island, near Port Hardy, has a 52 ft. x 20 ft. landing craft with its own power and this has been arranged for at a cost of approximately $30.00 per day. The company is submitting the definite rate in writing as soon as the manager, Mr. R. Barker, can contact the captain of our craft. This tentative rate which includes fuel costs is considered reasonable as Mr. A. Borden, District Engineer, Dominion Public Works Department at New Westminster, stated that a scow might cost up to $100.00 per day and to this we would have to add towing charges and the time taken to move the scow to and from Vancouver. No scows could be located in the Port Hardy-Alert Bay area. The only other conveyance is a small unpowered landing craft at Alert Bay. The landing craft of the Canada Kelp Company has a capacity of 15 tons and should be able to carry 120 lin. ft. of 24 ft. Loxtave Prefab building per trip. It can be beached on any smooth shore for loading or unloading.

At Port Hardy there is an excellent loading dock with adjacent storeroom approximately two miles from the Army camp. This is on the Indian Reserve and was built by the camp contractors. At Alert Bay the landing craft can be beached at the foot of Park Street on which Lot 24 fronts where the school and teachers' dwellings are to be erected.

While complete estimates as to costs are not yet available, it is estimated that a building approximately 60 ft. x 24 ft. can be removed and re-erected at Alert Bay complete with new Duroid or similar shingle roof for approximately $1200.00. For a four room school using an "H" hut which is 38 ft. long with 40 ft. connection and 40 ft. wide which would mean a cost of approximately $5000.00. As the floors will have to be sawn, it is likely a covering of some kind will be necessary and this would add a cost of $500.00 to the above. The installation of plumbing and wiring and also repainting would be extra as well as cost of a central heating system if such is required. Cost of
blackboards, school seats and other fittings would also be extra. The two teachers' dwellings would cost approximately $2400.00. Painting, plumbing and wiring extra, also floor covering.

There are sufficient stoves available and equipment to fit all buildings with plumbing and wiring. Hot water tanks are also in supply and just need fitting which could be used in other than vacant dwellings. There are no suitable cooking ranges for dwellings at Port Hardy Bay. The cooking ranges there are all large camp type only suitable for institutional purposes.

The dismantling of the buildings does not appear to be a difficult problem other than the floors. It is suggested we secure still poles and cut them into sections. Such saw can be used at Port Hardy and at Alert Bay and would soon save its cost in labour time. In addition to the floors there will also be considerable cutting to fit in extra windows as all are desired on one side of school rooms.

At Alert Bay the area selected for the school has been cleared but about one-half days work of a bulldozer is needed to level ground which now has quite a slope to cut down or supporting posts required.

The stores building at Alert Bay could be approximately 30 ft. long and could be roofed with 3 ply rubberoid unless it is considered that shingles such as Duroid should be used due to its proximity to the Agency buildings. It would not require many partitions or the floor to be covered so cost of its removal and re-erection should not exceed $1200.00.

The above gives a figure of $7900.00 for removal and erection of buildings for 4 room school and 2 teachers' dwellings at Alert Bay. Installation of plumbing and electric wiring as well as painting could be left until later, also floor in residence is found necessary. An estimate covering these items will be submitted in due course.

A rough estimate of costs of other buildings re-erected less plumbing, electric wiring and painting would be as follows:

Campbell River - teachers' residence $1500.00
Turnour Island - 1 room school and residence $1800.00
Gilford Island - 1 room school and residence $1800.00
Cape Mudge - 1 room school $1500.00
Village Island - 1 room school and residence $1800.00

As it is evident from correspondence that it is desired we proceed at once with these projects, we have submitted an estimate for July of $5482.00 and Mr. McClure is securing labour and proposes to return north on Saturday, June 28th. If the above programme is concurred in, it is
essential we take full advantage of good weather and get as much done as possible by September 1st when it is assumed school buildings will be required.

Detailed plans and estimates for the several proposed buildings are being prepared and will be submitted as available.

At present and for the next month or so accommodation on boat or plane is very difficult so we have been forced to make plans in anticipation of approval being forthcoming.

C.H. Webb
District Chief Engineer

'Reference removal buildings Port Hardy Camp for school and Agency purposes Alert Bay approximate cost of removal and re-erection sufficient buildings for four classroom block and two teachers' residences eight thousand dollars central heating if required installation of plumbing electric wiring and repainting extra Stop Consider we would be fully justified in proceeding with this work and have advised local office Surveys and Engineering accordingly Stop Request covering Departmental authority by wire immediately Stop Also advance five thousand dollars to cover labour Stop Report of local Surveys and Engineering Branch giving detailed information being forwarded by airmail.'

The report referred to is enclosed.

You will note the arrangement made covering the use of the buildings required at the places mentioned and the order in which the work is to be carried out. The estimate of costs given to move these buildings and erect them ready for use less plumbing, central heating if required, wiring and repainting appears to me to justify our proceeding with the work without delay. A four classroom block at Alert Bay with sufficient living quarters for teachers could not be built at prevailing prices for less than $40,000 to $45,000 and if we can meet the school needs at Alert Bay which, I may say, are of a very urgent character, for the next ten years by using the buildings at Port Hardy even if the cost of doing so exceeds $10,000 we should, in my opinion, proceed. The estimate of the cost of providing our requirements...
at Campbell River and elsewhere in the Kwawkewlth Agency is set out in Mr. Webb's report and I would recommend that the necessary funds be provided to carry out as much as possible of this program while we are in a position to secure the men and equipment required. I should appreciate being advised how far we may go in carrying out this program.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

Mr. HESY

Fort Hardy Military Camp

I have recently had an opportunity of inspecting the army buildings which Colonel Randle has had moved to the Six Nations Reserve. They are progressing very rapidly in having these set up as school buildings and they should prove satisfactory for a period of 5 years or more.

The attached letter and report concerns the removal of buildings from the Fort Hardy Military Camp to be re-erected similarly as schools in the Commonwealth Agency at Alert Bay.

I had an opportunity of discussing this situation with Major MacKay during his recent visit here. This project will do a great deal to alleviate the present shortage of educational facilities for the Indians in this area. In all it will provide the following buildings:

(a) A four-room school at Alert Bay with two teachers' dwellings,

(b) A teacher's residence at Campbell River,

(c) A one-room school and teacher's residence at Toernour Island,

(d) A one-room school and residence at Gilford Island,

(e) A one-room school and residence at Cape Mudge,

(f) A one-room school and residence at Village Island.

Re: Port Hardy Military Camp Buildings

In a letter dated the 17th instant from Vancouver our Mr. Webb, under whose control buildings for the Indian Affairs Branch are being moved from Port Hardy, states that Commissioner MacKay hopes to have an outer finish of:

(a) Asbestos Shingles,
(b) Insul-brick Asphalt Siding,
(c) Cedar Shingles,

applied to the buildings when re-erected in their new locations.

Commissioner MacKay has cited the action taken by Superintendent Randall at the Six Nations Superintendency in covering salvaged buildings, in which operation he appears to have developed a preference for insul-brick finish.

If the salvaged buildings for the Six Nations area were of National Defence construction they were probably faced originally with asbestos shingles, and since the latter are not easily salvagable, were probably covered with insul-brick asphalt siding when placed in their new positions. However, since the Port Hardy buildings appear to be Loxstave type as handled by Prefabricated Buildings Limited of Vancouver, it is our opinion that the patented feature of their construction, whereby the locking system of wall members at the corners, causes a projection somewhat similar to log wall construction, satisfactory application of any covering material would not be possible.

Mr. Webb has requested us to obtain construction particulars of the buildings handled by Superintendent Randall, in order that he may form an opinion regarding their exterior finish to pass on to Commissioner MacKay.

Your reply as soon as possible will be appreciated.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In reply to your 156-29-5 WT.1 of the 25th ultimo enclosing copy of memorandum from the Surveys and Engineering Branch you are advised as follows.

The outside walls of the buildings on the former military training centre were originally faced with rolls of ordinary black 2-ply roofing, - a low grade type, much used by Indians and farmers as a cheap way of roofing small houses and buildings.

On siding the first school reconstructed from an army building, we used asbestos shingles, but as only second grade were obtainable, the job when done did not look first class, as the shingles disclosed cracks after being on a few days, and some corners broke off.

Then with children playing around, more get cracked and damaged, and it is doubtful if even first grade would really stand up.

On the other hand, the insul-brick siding placed on the remaining schools, is neater looking in every respect, much more difficult for the children to damage, and in this damp cold climate will be a much warmer siding.

Also, in spite of what is commonly said, - it looks as if after all in a year or two we shall have to paint the asbestos shingles, and they appear already to be darkening up, and also show dirt marks easily.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Painting, electrical work and necessary plumbing will be a factor but the estimated cost of this is not excessive under present costs. It is proposed to install water in all buildings and cess pits as a temporary measure to handle drainage water. All buildings are to be painted inside and out.

Bulldozer costs have been much in excess of original estimate. Some of this was due to work instructed to be done when Mr. McClure was at Port Hardy.

The buildings at Alert Bay school will be finished to a greater extent than covered by the original estimate in that they will be completely repainted, floor covering will be supplied on school floors, electrical outlets will be installed as well as water and temporary drainage. The roofing is of double construction consisting of a sheathing overlaid with asphalt shingle. The walls will have a heavy saturated paper inside outer cedar covering and a dry paper sheathing outside inside walls. New paper will be laid between the two floors. Concrete footing for the treated cedar posts have been installed. The result will be a first class building which will have a life of many years.

While the present estimated cost of the Alert Bay school and residences will be very much above original estimate, they will still be actually much below ordinary present day costs. The school and teachers' residences have a floor area of approximately 844.8 square feet so that on the present estimate of $15,000 the cost will be $1.77 per square foot. Considering height as 10 feet (floor to ceiling) the cost per cubic foot is only 17.7 cents.

In addition to the four room school and two teachers' residences under construction at Alert Bay other work as follows has been carried out:

General costs chargeable to all work has amounted to $553.61 divided into supervision and expenses, $214.49; Camp equipment, $37.04; Tools, $276.28, and Miscellaneous, $25.80. This amount will be divided between the several jobs on completion.

Re: Buildings - Port Hardy Military Camp

Costs to end of August indicate that our estimate of June 27, 1947, as to expenses of moving buildings to other points on the B.C. coast and erecting them as schools, teachers' residences, etc., was seriously in error.

Proportion of costs of labour, material and supervision shows that the Alert Bay four-room school and two town-hall residences has been approximately $5745.00 to date and to complete the two residences now erected and to erect and complete the school will cost approximately a further amount of approximately $9655.00, or a total of $15,000.00. See attached appendix I.

In analysing the costs shown in Appendix I it will be seen supervision will be about 15% of total cost.

Labour costs have been much in excess of the original estimate due to bad weather, difficulty in securing and keeping efficient carpenters and other labour, and also due to the fact that buildings were nailed in excess of expectations. Owing to the numerous nails in the floors it was finally necessary to give up the plan to cut them in sections and to pull them up. Original estimates for labour costs were based on information secured in Vancouver to effect that a crew of five men could assemble a 60-foot hut in one day. Actually it has been found that it takes a perfect crew of six men at least a week to do this. Erection time was also in error as instead of ten man days per 60-foot hut it takes several times that number of man days.

Trucking charges have been above estimate due in part to fact that labour crew was not large enough to load and unload without some loss in time.

Barge costs to date have exceeded estimate but with experience gained future charges should be lower per trip.

Roofing costs will be above original estimate due in part to non-delivery of materials when promised and the construction of a better roof than originally contemplated.

Due to condition of much of floor, it was necessary to secure a floor covering which will cost slightly above original estimate.

Nails and all other materials have cost much more than estimated due in part to necessity of paying excess costs to secure delivery.

Re: Four Room School and Teachers' Residences - Alert Bay

Further to my letter of September 11, Mr. Whyte visited the above project on October 18th and advises that he is not all satisfied with the work accomplished in the past five weeks. In discussing the matter with Mr. McClure he was advised that weather conditions (confirmed from other sources) had been adverse and that the labour is not very satisfactory despite the high wages which we have had to pay.

A summation of expenditures for which accounts have been submitted, including payrolls, to October 19th shows cost of work to that date as $14,239.50. Other commitments will bring the total expended to at least $15,000.00 for which we have one 48 ft. teachers' residence practically completed less plumbing and second outside coat of paint and trim and some minor work, one 60 ft. teachers' residence erected but top floor not laid and partitions not erected, and one wing of school erected but final roof not laid, partitions and interior not completed.

Under present conditions I have no lead how long it will take to complete the work at present under way but with favourable weather, it might be possible to have 48 foot residence and two school rooms ready by end of this month at a possible additional cost of $5,000.00.

It must be pointed out that practically all supplies for the whole job are on the ground and the end of the work at Alert Bay is in sight, although probably costs may run to a further $5,000.00. This would include the store-room at the Agency Office.
There seems to be three alternatives:

1st - To carry on work to completion with present crew.

2nd - To complete 48 ft. residence and 2 school rooms with present crew and then close down for balance of this fiscal year.

3rd - To complete 48 ft. residence and 2 school rooms with present crew and then organize crew of local labour and carry on to completion.

Which of these alternatives is decided on will, of course, depend on funds made available. If there are funds still available, I would suggest that alternative 3 be followed. The cost of completion should be less as after the fishing season is over (October 31) it is stated there is a good supply of first-class local labour available at local pay rates or less than we are paying now. With better skilled labour and lower labour costs, it is reasonable to suppose we could complete the work for much less than the total of $25,000.00 now apparently required to complete all work at Alert Bay. It must, however, be pointed out that the necessary labour might not be found to carry out proposal 3 expeditiously but it is believed that it would be worth while taking that chance. As a further alternative we could well contract certain portions of the job to local men, white or Indian, advantageously.

In conclusion, I may say that Mr. Whyte considers that Mr. McClure has done as well as possible under the circumstances but has been up against a most difficult problem from the first with the labour which it has been possible to secure. Actually we had to take any which offered and with high wages in the lumber camps and fishing industry in Alert Bay area, the class of labour we obtained was naturally much below standard, and the same applies to the labour we were able to recruit in Vancouver for work up there.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The attached copy of letter forwarded me from the Commissioner's Office by Inspector Coleman in the absence of Commissioner MacKay, will create such a serious situation if the orders are carried out that I felt I should immediately place this whole matter before you for your personal attention, and as there are some pertinent things responsible for this situation, which you should be fully aware of, I am taking the liberty of writing you a strictly confidential letter.

It is my understanding the reason given for not completing the construction of Alert Bay Indian Day School and Teachergages, which the Surveys and Engineering Branch have been working on for the past four months, is due to the fact that the estimated appropriation is expended. First let me say I feel very sorry for Col. G. W. Whyte, Assistant Director, Chief Engineer, Surveys and Engineering Branch, who is in charge of this project, as I consider the Superintendent of Construction under him has let his men down badly - indeed, so much so that it must be extremely embarrassing to Col. Whyte. Mr. McClure, the Superintendent in charge, is an old Army acquaintance of Col Whyte's and served under him Overseas in the last war. I know for a fact that Col. Whyte is terribly disappointed in the results of four months' efforts in dismantling Army Camp buildings at Fort Rupert and rebuilding them into a four-room school and teachergages at Alert Bay.

The first month that McClure was on the job he seemed to make good progress. Then suddenly a French lady arrived here by plane from Paris, France. Her arrival appeared totally unexpected by Mr. McClure. A month later he introduced me to her as his wife. Since then she has lived in a hotel room with him and followed him around no matter where he went. I believe her presence has been a great handicap to him in his work as he seems to spend all his time with her in the hotel room and thus is very seldom on the job supervising his men or the work at hand.

The principal of our new Alert Bay four-room Indian Day School has just arrived with her furniture and wishes to take up residence in one of the teachergages. I went to look for Mr. McClure this morning at the school buildings under construction and was told by the men he was not there. I then went to the hotel about a mile and a quarter from the job and found him still in bed at 10:45 in the morning. He promised to come and see me at the office this afternoon but failed to do so.

I have watched his carryings-on for three months but felt it was not my business to interfere with another Department when they had been charged with the responsibilities of building this school. I do, however, feel, in view of the contents of the attached letter, that it is now my duty as well as other officials of the Indian Affairs Branch to give some direction and see that this school and teachergages are completed as originally planned. It appears to me that it is only a question of money that has caused Col. Whyte to recommend the work stopped, leaving this school and teachergages in a half-finished condition.

p.t.o.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 634, File 800-5, part 4)
In order that you will get a complete picture I think it is best that I should give you a complete report as to the actual conditions and what we are up against. At the present time one 48' teachersage is practically completed and the principal could move in tomorrow if the plumbing was installed. All the plumbing fixtures are laying in the building ready to be installed. The other teachersage is about two-thirds completed. Two rooms of the four-room school are pretty well completed. The foundations are in for the rest of the classrooms, lavatories, assembly room, furnace room and teachers' office. All the building material to complete the entire school is here on the grounds, eleven having been transferred from the Alert Bay Camp or purchased from wholesalers. It is stacked around the school yard, some of it covered up by tarps while the rest is laying unprotected in the rain. Two or three weeks more work would complete the shell of the school and all that would remain then is the inside finishings, plumbing and sewerage. If it is left as it is, half of this lumber and supplies will be stolen or ruined by weather.

Our teachers are refusing to move into a teachersage where there is no plumbing or water. Arrangements were made whereby we could run a line from the Residential School water supply to the Day School, which is only a matter of a few hundred feet; or they could hook onto the Church supply which is about five or six hundred feet away.

I can understand that these buildings have cost more than the original estimate, the way it has been carried on. Anytime you dismantle a building whereby you take the boards down, piece by piece, remove the nails, bundle the lumber for shipment, as has been done in this case, it is bound to run into a lot of money. Nevertheless, the work that has been done so far is good and when this school and teachersages are completed we will have a well-built structure that will last for twenty-five or thirty years, if given ordinary care. There is nothing wrong with the construction work so far - it is just that it has cost more money than it should.

At the present time the organization is complete, the material on the ground and labour employed which could complete this school and teachersages in a very short time if allowed to continue. In my opinion, irrespective of cost, the work on these buildings should be continued and no let-up until the whole project is completed in every detail. To stop work now means setting up a new organization which takes time and costs money. Our materials laying around the school grounds, particularly 3-way, will deteriorate when exposed to weather, and there is no place to store them. Our Department are going to sustain a serious loss if we allow this work to be discontinued now. There should be no let-up but rather instructions go out insisting that the work be speeded up here, and that not only the Alert Bay Schools and Teachersages be completed but the Campbell River Teachersage, Cape Mudge School and Turnour Island School and Teachersage should also be got under way at the earliest possible date. While it is true we have had some real bad weather of late; nevertheless, the men can work inside on bad days and on the exterior of the buildings in the good weather.

The Surveys and Engineering Branch promised they would have the principal's teachersage completed by September 1st so that we would have a place for our teachers to live. One teacher was able to get a room in an attic of a private home and has been living there and eating at restaurants. We could find no place for another teacher and so we have only been able to open one classroom, and this classroom accommodating grades 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, has
been on a half-day system, part of the grades coming in the morning and the other half in the afternoon.

Over fifty children in the junior room have not been attending school as we had no accommodation for them which they could not open the classroom. The Indian parents and the Native Brotherhood in particular are getting very much upset at these children walking the streets of Alert Bay waiting for this new school to be completed. To me it is a tragedy and it is up to the Indian Affairs Branch to insist that the Surveys and Engineering Branch complete the Alert Bay Indian Day School and Teachergate at as early a date as possible, and that we provide whatever money is necessary to do so. As stated before there is a great deal of work stacked on the Alert Bay side to complete the construction of the school and teachergate including plumbing, electric wiring and sewers etc. Sufficient labour is available and it seems the height of folly to stop in the middle of the building program for the want of a few more dollars to complete the job.

I am sending this letter Airmail and would kindly ask you to give it your personal attention. Our Branch will lay ourselves open to the utmost criticism if we do not complete this school and get these children in the classroom and off the streets; and our teachers will not move into a building where there are no ordinary conveniences. We must complete this one teachergate by immediate installation of all plumbing, as the principal is here with her furniture and ready to move in but cannot do so without water in the building.

Major Davey, School Inspector, and myself have been laying plans to open the new school on January 5th, 1948. We had hoped that the whole project would be completed and ready for occupancy. It was my plan to move the present two classrooms and our present equipment into the new school during the Christmas holidays. Major Davey has the teachers employed to start the four classrooms at the beginning of the new year. All these plans will go by the boards if the Surveys and Engineering Branch are permitted to stop the work now, and the children will lose the better part of a school year.

I have written you at some length so that you will have the whole picture before you. As far as I am aware it is just a question of funds. It is my understanding the estimated appropriation has been expended and that is the reason why the engineers are closing down construction work.

Immediate action is necessary as I understand it is the engineers' intention to close down the whole project in the course of the next few days, and if this is permitted to take place it means our schools will all be closed down in Alert Bay, as our teachers are going to resign. They are insisting that the Department give them reasonable accommodation, and do not intend to live in a building where there is no water or ordinary conveniences. If there is anything I can do to assist I shall be very glad to do so. I only wish my health was such so that I could take a more active part.

It must not be overlooked that the expenses contracted to date are not all chargeable to the Alert Bay Indian Day School. The teachergate for the Campbell River Indian Day School is all dismantled, bundled and on the dock at Fort Rupert ready to be shipped to Campbell River. Material for the Agency warehouse is on the site here ready for construction. I do not know how the Superintendent of Construction is handling matters insofar as

I also believe the engineers are looking for an excuse to shut down construction work during the winter months. Out here on the coast the weather is mild and construction never ceases from one end of the year to the other, and in our case there is sufficient work to permit the men to work inside on bad days and to work outside on good days; so there is no hold-up or any extra cost incurred.

Word has got out that the engineers are closing down work on this school and the Indians are extremely upset and others very much disgusted. It is up to us to see this entire project completed properly at the earliest possible date.

Editorial.

We are very pleased that the first edition of our paper gained so many favourable comments, and further that our effort should have been mentioned at a meeting of the Alert Bay & District Board of Trade. There is no news-sheet in Alert Bay, and an advertisement was sent to the Board of Trade for display, together with the sum of $1.00. This has been given to us and will help pay for the cost of stencils for our paper. This advertisement is set out in the notices. Perhaps one of these days as we improve we may be able to ask for paid advertising.

Another landmark has left Alert Bay. The totem pole which stood for so many years outside the Drabble house has been sold to the University of British Columbia.

JUNIOR ROOM. We welcome Mrs. Scanlon as our teacher in the Junior Room which opens on 3 November. She is not a stranger to us nor to our parents as she was teaching for several years at the Regional School. Everyone is glad that this room has been opened for the children will go to school all day. We are glad that they are off the streets. If only the new buildings were finished more children would be off the streets. The housing shortage in this village is awful and we think Mrs. Scanlon a sport to come here and put up with the discomforts she is doing. We thank her for this. She thinks of the children before herself.

NEW SCHOOL. For many months now we have all been waiting patiently for the new school to be opened. We now hear that the men who are working on the building will not be able to continue with the work. It is a shame to hear this. We sometimes wonder how our teachers can teach without proper equipment, or how they can manage all of us alone when we are so crowded. Amazing things these teachers can do. We know it is hard on them. It will be a disgrace if they stop the work now when they have gone so far, and we hope it will be possible for them to keep on working until it is finished.

THANKSGIVING DAY. On the Friday before Thanksgiving Day we all drew pictures to represent our thanksgiving. Some pupils drew pictures of people at table giving thanks to God for the good things to eat. Many of the drawings were very good. We liked it very much. Some of us went to Church. Some of the people decorated their houses and invited others in to eat with them.

GEORGE LUTHER. We appreciate the work George Luther has done. As all of you older people in this village know he was one of the first teachers in Alert Bay. We are very sorry to hear that he is quite sick in the Hospital and that he has been suffering for a long time. We thought it would make him happy if we put a few lines about him in our little paper. He is a good man for all that he has done in this village among his Indian people. Let your some of our boys sang in his choir. This year he should go to sing to him.

HALLOWEEN. Before Hallowe'en we made decorations, cats, masks, paper chains, witches and baskets. These baskets were filled by the senior girls with good things to eat. On the afternoon of Hallowe'en we had a party and played many games. Mrs. Scanlon was invited to our place so that she could meet us all. After the games the children were given the decorations which had apples, candy, peanuts and other things in them. We thanked Miss Lucas for giving us the party and everyone said they had a wonderful time. We are sure they enjoyed the party too. After supper we went out to hunt for ghosts, go to houses or rowboats, and nobody got hurt.
BUS STOP. What a strange sign to see in Alert Bay! Yet there are twenty of them between the Residential School and Skinner's Corner. Yes! we have a regular bus service. Fare 10¢. The bus runs every day except Monday. Some of the pupils come to school by bus, and it is very nice of Mr. Dalgarno to stop at the school door on wet days. This is a novelty to the children and on the first day some were late at school because they were joy-riding and did not get off the bus when they should have done. All the children have been warned about riding on the back of the bus. Two young boys were doing this between 11:30 and 11:45 p.m. on Saturday night. This is a very DANGEROUS thing to do. We would ask the parents to remind their children about this, otherwise we may have a serious and perhaps FATAL accident. These young boys should not have been on the street at that hour without their parents.

WEDDING NEWS. Lena Mary Alfred, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kasas Alfred was married to Thomas Leon Brown, son of Mr. Harry Brown, on 24th October at Christ Church, Alert Bay, by Rev. Canon Hatfield. The bride wore a lovely white dress and looked beautiful. She was attended by three bridesmaids, Kitty Beams, Elsie Abraham and Jessie Alfred who wore dresses in pastel shades. Shirley Alfred was flower girl. A reception was held at 9 p.m. in the Parish Hall which was attended by many friends. On 21 October, Mrs. Dora Alfred gave a shower for the bride at which she received many useful gifts for her new home.

ITS AN ILL WIND THAT BLOWS NOBODY ANY GOOD. For months we had an old stove at our school. It smoked and smoked and smoked, and sometimes it was so bad we had tears rolling down our cheeks and we used to go home until it had stopped smoking. This year when we started school our stove was even worse than last year. Nothing was done about it as we were supposed to be going to go into the new school. But one Monday when we came to school we found that a storm had blown our chimney down. How we hoped we were now going to get a new stove! Well, up went something new. Yes! new pipes! But we got another old stove, little better than what we once had. It was missing one leg and when it was put in the school three brick were put under this leg to hold up the stove. However, the smoke is not quite so bad; it only smokes occasionally! On Wednesday another leg fell off the stove, so we have had to prop this side up now. In the Junior Room the same day, the front fell off the stove!

(Teachers Note - Who wouldn't teach in an Indian School? Don't we have fun!)

Re: Day School - Alert Bay

I am today in receipt of advice that the two classrooms in the west wing of the above school are now ready for occupancy.

At the present time it will be necessary to have the pupils hang their coats in the classrooms and if immediate occupancy is desired clothes racks can be knocked up pending the completion of the connecting hall between the west and east wing. It is hoped to have this portion of the building while not completed in shape to hang clothing in it during school hours by the end of the month.

No doubt some shelving and possibly cupboards may be needed in the classrooms. There are about three sets of suitable shelves for schools at Port Hardy which can be moved to Alert Bay but few if any of the cupboards salvaged at the Port Hardy camp are suitable for re-erection and new ones will have to be built as desired.

Should it be desired to have a carpenter install desks, etc. in the classrooms please advise and I will instruct Mr. McClure to detail a man to do this.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch.

Re: Buildings at Fort Hardy being demolished and transferred to Alert Bay for construction of buildings at Alert Bay.

I do not believe that we have received any report from your Branch as to how this matter stands although a great deal of work has been accomplished under the direction of Mr. Whyte of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau. Would it be possible for you to furnish a report at a fairly early date.

Most of the material I believe is being used in the construction of school buildings but we did encumber $1200.00 and send to you a copy of the Encumbrance Requisition under the Agency Vote. This was for the construction of a warehouse and possibly an office. I should be pleased to be brought up to date on this matter. If Col. Whyte has not reported perhaps it would be possible to secure a report from him and forward it to me.

We are also particularly anxious to know whether any of the Fort Hardy buildings are being set aside for the building of an office. From a report from Indian Agent Todd, addressed to Dr. P.B. Tennant, of the Indian Health Services, it would appear that there is some difference of opinion between Mr. Whyte and the Indian Agent as to where the office should be located. The Indian Agent apparently thinks that the office could be erected between the present office and a vacant lot. Mr. Whyte apparently believes that the office should be built on the vacant lot. If this decision is arrived at, the Indian Agent states that there will not be room for any medical buildings.

The Encumbrance Requisition for $1200.00 to which I refer is dated July 30th, and the number of it is 935. It sets aside $1200.00 for
the purpose of providing a storage building by using materials from the Fort Hardy Military Camp. I am wondering just what progress has been made, particularly in this connection.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 8, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 3rd instant, file 6-11-3, reporting on the progress made in connection with the Alert Bay Indian day school construction. We note that recently progress has been slow but we hope that the work will progress more quickly and that the buildings at Alert Bay will be completed before the end of March.

We presume that no progress has been made on the other buildings which it was understood would be erected this year. In this connection I refer you to the list forwarded with my communication of October 4th. As just intimated, we were under the impression that the other buildings would be completed this year and consequently have not made any provision for them in the appropriation for the year 1948-49. If we are correct in this assumption it will mean proceeding with the unfinished buildings next year and this would involve using funds which we hope could be used for new projects.

We would also like to know why it was apparently considered necessary to provide one building as living accommodation for two teachers and a second building to provide similar accommodation for four teachers.

Colonel Whyte's report which you forwarded is enclosed.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Following receipt of Mr. Neary's letter of November 25th the Surveys and Engineering Branch was requested to report on the progress made in connection with the Alert Bay Indian Day School construction and the work necessary to prepare the school for occupancy.

Copies of Mr. C.E. Webb's letters of December 2nd in this connection are enclosed, together with a memorandum dated November 27th from Mr. G.H. Whyte.

While it is regretted that the cost of this project has been greatly in excess of the estimate and while considerable less progress has been made to date than was anticipated for the reasons set out in Mr. Whyte's report you will note from his summary that from now on with a reasonable labour force and favourable weather more satisfactory progress should be seen than has been apparent to date, but at the same time the Engineering Branch has made no definite commitment with respect to completion of the project prior to March 31st. In the absence of any further information to the contrary it is presumed that the Engineering Branch's recent estimate of the cost, $25,000 still stands. It is thought that the Department can secure a copy of Col. Whyte's report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Ottawa, in which case I should appreciate the return of the report enclosed.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: School Construction - Commonwealth Agency

This will acknowledge your letter of 18 December 1947 re the above question.

At present we have under construction the teacher's residence at Campbell River. This we hope to complete by the latter part of January. The cost of this building less plumbing and furnishings will be approximately $2500.

We are arranging to proceed with a combined one classroom school and one teachers' quarters at Turnour Island about the latter part of January. It is expected we will have it completed by the end of February using Indian labour which Mr. L.J. Todd advised us would be available as soon as we had a contract to supervise. While we haven't yet seen the site or made final arrangements to transport material it is contemplated cost will be approximately $4500.

At the same time we will arrange to start work at Cone Mudge on the two classroom school using the men now employed at Campbell River. This school should be finished in March at an estimated cost of $7500.

Arrangements will also be put under way to construct a combined one classroom and one teacher residence at Village Island, and while we hope to complete by the end of March this will depend on what arrangements can be made to secure local labour or to board imported labour, also the availability of such labour. If the whole job cannot be completed we should be able to have materials delivered to site before the end of March so that if necessary work could proceed when it is possible to put labour under canvas. The estimated cost of this building would be approximately $3500.

It is assumed work at Gilford Island is dependent on decision as to site. We will, however, arrange to have material ready to transport there before the end of March. This combined one class room and one teacher residence can be dismantled and made ready to ship for an estimated cost of $3000. If desired all new material could be delivered to Alert Bay by March 31 for a further $1500. This would only leave cost of transportation to Gilford Island and erection to be paid next fiscal year, and this should not exceed a further $6500.

In connection with all the schools it will be desirable to paint exteriors in the next dry season and with this in view it would be well to secure the necessary paint before March 31st. Unless otherwise instructed this will be done.

"C.E. Webb"
District Chief Engineer.

With regard to your inquiry as to why it was necessary to provide one building as living accommodation for two teachers and a second building to provide accommodation for four teachers, I would advise that we have in mind the eventual employment of a manual training instructor to this school in addition to the four classroom teachers and in view of the size of the school will likely have to employ a caretaker. I may say that the two buildings are not the same size, one being 40' in length and the other 60'.

Re: School Construction - Kwawkewlth Agency

Further to my letter of February 6 in connection with the school construction program in the Kwawkewlth Agency, we have recently reviewed the progress and expenditures made to date and find that by spending the entire appropriation we will be able to complete the four classroom buildings at Alert Bay and the two teachers residences, the teachers residence at Campbell River and the Turnour Island school and teacherage. The cost of the Nlakatla Indian Day School and the second classroom at the Nanaimo Indian Day School will also be met from the $47,500 appropriation although work at these latter schools was not carried out under the supervision of Mr. Webb's office.

My object in writing now is to find out on what date the Department will require an accounting of the funds advanced to meet labour costs in connection with this construction program as information received from Mr. Webb's office indicates that in order to complete the construction at Turnour Island it may be necessary to continue the work during the first week in April. Apart from this there is an unavoidable delay between the time paysheets are prepared on the job and the time they are received at this office, with the result that it might be towards the end of the first week in April before we receive the necessary information in this office on which to issue cheques covering labour costs during the period March 16th to 31st.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would advise:

(1). The latest date on which an accounting of advances received for school construction labour costs must be made.

RE: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Further to my letter of June 19th last in respect to the heating of this school, I wish to give you more particulars as to the manner in which the engineers left that portion of the building where no provision was made for heating. There is no chimney built in the Assembly Room; therefore, we cannot set up a stove. In addition no chimneys were built in the portion of the building where the plumbing is installed, which includes teachers' office, wash room, store room, etc., and there is no room in this portion of the building to set up a stove.

I am afraid if we wait for the Surveys and Engineering Branch, this installation will not be done in time for opening of the school this September. I am recommending that the Department make a decision as to the method of heating this building. My recommendation is that an oil-burning hot water central heating system should be installed. If the Department decide on this, I will immediately have a reliable firm submit a tender for the installation, which would cover materials and labour. This is the only method I can see of getting heat in the school and have it ready for September 1st.

At the present time we have drilled and provided an excellent well for the Alert Bay Village, which well will supply the Alert Bay Day School. We have the pipes laying here on the ground ready for installation, the tank purchased, and all we need is someone to make the installation. Why can't this be proceeded with now? We could at least have the tank erected and pipeline built from the pump to the tank and from the tank to the school which would have this much of the installation completed and thus provide water and sewerage for the school and teacherages.

This pipe has been laying here since last March. When the pipe arrived I suggested to Mr. McClure that for the time being until the installation was made they could store the pipe on the lawn at the Agency.

p.t.o.
under shade trees where it would be protected from the sun and also from being stolen. This was done at the time but later he hauled a lot of it away and piled it on the school grounds and along the road where it is exposed to the sun and the tar is running out of the pipes and not doing them any good. Certain ditches were dug and as far as I know this pipe line which has been laid is now complete but the ditches have never been filled in with the result that the pipes are still exposed to the sun. This work should be finished.

I understand our Department have transferred $10,000.00 to the Surveys ad Engineering Branch to have this work completed.

I also understand Mr. Unsworth of the Surveys and Engineering Branch claims he does not get co-operation from the Indians. With all due respect to Mr. Unsworth I must say he does not seem to know how to handle Indians or get work out of them. He was here three weeks and accomplished very little - in fact, when he was called to Vancouver he dropped his tools where he was working and left them laying all over the place. He also left connections and materials, which we had to wait months in order to purchase, laying around for anybody to pick up. As soon as I learned this I had Mr. Scanlon go down the next morning, gather up all the tools and parts and put them in the warehouse under lock and key so that we would have them when required.

The method of doing things by representatives of the Surveys and Engineering Branch is not satisfactory and the Indian Affairs Branch is being criticised generally for delays and the conduct of the work. The Department have enough difficulty in obtaining necessary funds to do the work, and now that we have the funds we want this work completed.

Indian Superintendent.

Mr. M. S. Todd,
Indian Superintendent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Dear Sir:

I submit herewith tender for painting the Alert Bay Indian Day School and two Teacherages. After examining the buildings I find the present paint is peeling and in order to do a first-class job it will be necessary to scrub the surface with a wire brush.

This tender will guarantee the following work:

**Teacherages**

One coat of outside "Bapco" light cream.
Two coats of outside "Bapco" green for trim.
Two coats of outside "Bapco" brown for base and porches.

**School**

Two coats of outside "Bapco" light cream.
Two coats of outside "Bapco" green for trim.
Two coats of outside "Bapco" brown for base and porches.

I guarantee to do a first-class job for the full sum of Fourteen Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($1450.00). I agree to commence work immediately my tender is accepted and complete same within thirty days, weather permitting.

Yours truly,

(D. T. Utley)
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Reference is made to my letter of today's date regarding school construction wherein I mentioned that the question of completion of the Alert Bay school buildings would be the subject of a separate communication.

Supt. Todd has secured a tender covering material and labour required for painting the Alert Bay Indian Day school buildings and the two teacherages and this tender, together with Mr. Todd's letter of June 16th and enclosures referred to therein is attached hereto. While Mr. D.T. Utley has submitted the lowest tender, in the amount of $1450, his submission does not clearly indicate that it covers both the provision of material and labour. This was pointed out to Mr. Todd but a subsequent tender does not clarify the matter to any extent although you will note from Mr. Todd's letter that he states definitely that the tender covers both labour and material.

In my letter above referred to I recommended the transfer of funds for completion of schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency and would now recommend that Mr. Utley's tender for painting the day school building and teacherages at Alert Bay be accepted. If the tender in its present form is unacceptable will you please advise by Army Signals when a new form will be prepared in this office and forwarded to Mr. Utley for his signature.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Alert Bay, B. C.,
June 16th, 1948.

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

As requested I called for tenders for painting the Alert Bay Indian Day School and the two Teacherages, and attach hereto tenders covering labour and materials, which will be self-explanatory.

You will please note that Mr. D. T. Utley's tender of $1450.00 is the lower and as he is a painter by trade and has a good name here in Alert Bay for work he has done, I would recommend that his tender be accepted. Mr. Utley informed me he had plenty of other work to do but if the Department accepted his tender he would work long hours and take advantage of the present good weather and get the job completed as quickly as possible.

I would therefore ask that this matter be dealt with by Airmail and the Department's approval received at the earliest possible date. An accountable cheque for this tender could be forwarded this office later, but the important thing is to obtain a decision so that we can get started without any delay.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Alert Bay Indian Day School, Kwawkewlth Indian Agency, Electoral District of Comox-Alberni, Province of British Columbia.

The erection of a new school at Alert Bay is practically completed and it will be necessary to paint the buildings. Indian Superintendent Todd has obtained a tender from D.T. Utley, Alert Bay, B.C., who tenders on the painting at a cost of $1,450.00, this amount to cover both material and labour.

Mr. Todd states that Mr. Utley is a painter by trade and his work in the vicinity of Alert Bay has always been satisfactory. Acceptance of the tender is also recommended by Indian Commissioner Arneil.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of this tender so that we may have the buildings painted before the school opens in September.

Director.

Re: Alert Bay Day School

Mr. Superintendent Todd has informed me that the Principal of the above mentioned school has requested that the Department purchase a piano for use in the school. Mr. Todd states that a good second-hand piano may be purchased for $250.00 from a local resident who will be moving away from Alert Bay in about two months time.

As the Department is aware, the present Day School has an enrolment between 120 and 130 pupils and operates four class-rooms. It is also anticipated that this enrolment will be greatly increased when the pupils from the Residential school attend the Day School, which it is expected they will do at the beginning of the new academic year. Even if this plan does not go into operation the present enrolment at the school would justify the provision of a piano.

I would strongly recommend that the Department authorize the purchase of this instrument.

Date: March 31/49
During 1948 the Department forwarded an accountable advance, same to be used for various improvements in connection with the Alert Bay Indian Day School. Every effort was made to employ local labour on a daily rate to complete this work but it was realized near the end of our fiscal year that the work was not going to be completed by this method. I, therefore, went to Mr. T. Westerlund, local contractor, and asked if he would consider a contract to complete the work and at the same time finish it by the end of our fiscal year.

Mr. Westerlund agreed to supply the necessary materials and labour to complete the work by March 31st. I, therefore, had him submit a tender covering all the work required to be done and he agreed to do it for $417.14. The signed tender is attached to Voucher No. 353.

We had a balance on hand of $183.51 from the accountable advance forwarded by the Department. When the work was completed on March 31st, 1949, we paid Mr. Westerlund $183.51 by cheque against his tender, which left a balance of $233.63. We are submitting herewith voucher #353 in favor of Mr. Westerlund in the amount of $233.63, which will pay the tender in full.

The work which we have completed was most essential in providing a playground with equipment for the children in this school. Prior to this they had no playground equipment or place to play. I am requesting the School Inspector to make a report to the Department on this work when he inspects the school.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Alert Bay Indian Day School

On the occasion of my recent inspection of the above mentioned school I was informed by the staff that there had been considerable difficulty in maintaining normal temperatures in the class-rooms during the winter months. Temperature readings were kept by the teachers in 3 of the 4 rooms and I secured a copy of these from the principal, which I am attaching herewith. It is obvious that something will have to be done concerning these conditions in the summer months of this year in order to ensure that they will not re-occur in the next year.

Although the school has been kept very clean, due to the efforts of the staff, it is the normal practice to provide the services of a janitor in schools of this size and I strongly recommend that such an employee be engaged for the next academic year.

You will recall that the water piping has already been installed in this school but this has not been connected to the water main. Some of the plumbing for waste has also been installed but is not connected to a sewage system. It
is most desirable that this work be completed in the current fiscal year, particularly in the case of the teacherage. It is unfortunate that our teachers have not at least as good facilities in this respect as many of the Indian homes in Alert Bay.

No fire protection is provided for this frame building and I feel that the Department should protect its considerable investment by providing at least a hose for the existing fire hydrant located on the school grounds. I feel that there should also be at least two hand extinguishers located in the school itself.

During my inspection I noted that a number of the desks provided were not suited in size to the pupils who were occupying them. The following adjustments should be made:

In the senior room- 4 desks size No. 3 should be removed and 6 desks size No. 1 should be installed.

In the Intermediate room- 7 desks size No. 5 and 4 desks size No. 4 should be removed and replaced with 11 size No. 1.

In the Junior room- 6 desks size No. 5 should be replaced with 2 primary tables and 10 chairs.

In the Primary room- 7 No. 5 desks should be replaced with 3 primary tables and 10 chairs. The replacement of the 28 desks as indicated above will release them for the school at Village Island which we hope to open in September.
Several of the doors in the school will not latch, apparently due to the shrinkage in the lumber. This applies in particular to the main entrance door on the front of the building and the doors opening from the class-rooms to the large entrance hall.

There also appears to be something wrong with the electric light circuits in the senior and intermediate rooms as the teachers concerned have been unable to get certain of the globes in these rooms to light.

R.F. Davey,
District School Inspector.

Attached please find tender received from Messrs. Westerlund
and Westerlund covering all labour and materials necessary to insulate
all ceilings in both teacherages and Indian Day School, Alert Bay.
It requires approximately 8,500 sq.ft. of Donnacorns and 20 rolls of
blow-in paper to complete this work. Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund
will supply all this together with sufficient nails and pay for all
charges of wharfage, trucking, freight and total wages, for the full
sum of $1,152.50.

When the insulation of the ceilings of the school and teacherages
was first recommended we thought rock wool would be the answer. However,
when we thoroughly examined the structure of the rafters and ceiling
joists we found they were constructed in such a manner that it would
be impossible to make a tight job by laying rock wool on top of the
ceiling panels. I have since obtained expert advice from several
people including Mr. A.H. Hargreaves, Heating Engineer, Ottawa, who
was here a few days ago. He crawled up into the attic with me, examined
the structure and then informed me that in his opinion Donnacorns with
paper between it and the ceiling panels would be the answer to our heat
losses. It is for this reason that we have changed from rock wool to
Donnacorns and consider we will have a tight job and remove heat
escapement by using this material.

There is going to be considerable work in addition to actually
putting the Donnacorns on. All our electric lights will have to be
disconnected and boxes lowered and reassembled. In addition to this
all strips on the present ceilings will have to be removed as well as
moving school equipment in the school while doing the work.

We are fortunate in getting Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund
to undertake this work as they have a contract at present with the
Department of Transport in Alert Bay but have promised me they will
undertake the work and have it completed before school opens if the
Department would give them a reply reasonably soon.
