Attached please find tender received from Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund covering the installation of an automatic hot water heating system in the Alert Bay Indian Day School as per blueprint and specifications attached. The total cost sum is Forty-One Hundred Eighty-Four Dollars ($41,844.00), which Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund have agreed to complete subject to the Department's approval and within sixty (60) days following the Department's notification to them that their tender has been accepted.

The Department is aware that a proper heating system is necessary in this school. At the present time we have only four classrooms heated with old Army Camp coal-burning stoves, which must be replaced at once. There is no heat in the Assembly Room nor in the wing which was used for 'girls' and boys' washrooms, teachers' offices, 'boys' and 'girls' wash room and store rooms. The fact that this building has been up for a year with no heat in this portion of the building has permitted dampness to deteriorate the structure, and this will become serious unless heating is installed within the next few months.

When this building was built by the Surveys and Engineering Branch it was planned for a central heating system and cannot be heated otherwise. In addition to this we have been unable to install any plumbing to date for lack of heat as the pipes would only freeze during the cold weather and destroy the installation.

Recently Mr. Hargreaves was here from Ottawa inspecting the Residential School heating system and I asked him if he would inspect the Day School and also examine the plans and specifications which I had had prepared for the heating plant, pointing out to Mr. Hargreaves that I was not personally qualified to make a recommendation without technical advice. Mr. Hargreaves informed me that he had not been sent here to deal with the Indian Day School but now that he was here he would look over the plant and also the specifications and then if the Department wished any advice upon his return to Ottawa, he would be very glad to assist them in any way he could. I would therefore request the Department to call Mr. Hargreaves on the phone and ask him to come over and give you expert advice on the recommendations which I am submitting in respect to the heating of this school. I am sure he will be glad to help you.

I called for local tenders for this work but there is nobody in Alert Bay or district other than Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund who is capable or able to undertake this work, and if it is necessary to bring someone in from say Vancouver, the cost of this installation will be a great deal more than Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund's tender. Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund built our Health Centre last year and installed a similar heating plant there, the only difference it being a smaller unit, and Mr. Hargreaves informed me the installation was exceptionally good.

p.t.o.
Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund are repairing and modernizing the Federal Department of Public Works' building here in Alert Bay at present and will be through in about two weeks' time, and will then be available to undertake our work, providing their tender is accepted. This work must be done during the summer holidays when school is closed and, therefore, there is some urgency in getting the work under way.

Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund are submitting tenders for other work that has to be done at our Day School during the holidays and they inform me the amount of each tender is based on the Department accepting all their tenders. They pointed out that they have a complete crew of men such as plumbers, electricians and heating experts, and if their tenders are accepted, wish to move their crew and fill their equipment to the Day School to be used on the various projects simultaneously. This is the only way they can complete the work before the opening of school and at the amounts offered in their tenders.

We are fortunate in having local men able to undertake this work and guarantee to finish it quickly, and I would recommend that all their tenders be accepted. They are very capable men and have had extensive experience working on Government projects.

I regret the time seems short but we have had to overcome many difficulties and delays before I have been able to prepare and submit plans, specifications and necessary data in connection with all the work that I have been asked to have done. I would, therefore, request the Department to give immediate consideration to the various tenders being submitted and wire this office immediately their decision is reached in respect to all tenders, so that Messrs. District School Inspector Davey recently brought to our attention certain improvements which were required at the above-mentioned School and additional work necessary for completion of the buildings. Through communication with Superintendent Todd, we endeavoured to arrive at the cost of this work and to secure from him proposals covering the best method of having the work carried out. All the information necessary was not immediately forthcoming, but having in mind that the work was necessary and in an attempt to clarify our construction program and the necessary allotment of available funds, in my letter of June 17th, I estimated that $6,500.00 would be sufficient to meet the cost of the work.

I now have Mr. Phelan's letter of June 27th, advising that certain transfers of funds, including the amount estimated for the Alert Bay Day School, were being proceeded with, but in the interval, additional information secured from Mr. Todd indicates that the amount requested will be insufficient to meet the entire cost. It is not intended to go into any great detail at this time, my purpose in writing being to secure, if possible, approval of certain specific expenditures, details of which are as follows:

1. New floors.- When these buildings were erected, the old flooring from the Army Camp which necessarily had to be cut up, was in poor shape, was covered with a material known as Tuflex, which has since been found to be quite unsuitable. It is proposed to recover the entire floor with edge grain fir
flooring, a requisition for which is attached, together with a quotation from the Inkster Lumber Company, Courtenay, B.C. The price quoted by the Company works out at $192.00 per 1000 delivered, which is in line with Vancouver prices, plus freight and cartage and as the Inkster Lumber Company is the only source of supply in the Alert Bay district, I would recommend that the Purchasing Agent be requested to place the order with them for immediate delivery. With regard to labour, you will note from Mr. Todd's letter of June 20th and enclosure attached, that Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund have tendered in the amount of $440.60, to provide all labour, trucking charges from the wharf, nails, etc., and guarantee to complete the work to the satisfaction of the Department. I have discussed this matter at some length with Mr. Todd and although we feel that it might be desirable to secure competitive tenders, he assures me there is no one in Alert Bay or vicinity other than Mr. Westerlund who would tender on the work. Under the circumstances, I would recommend acceptance of their tender.

2. Installation of an automatic hot water heating system.- You will note from Mr. Todd's letter of June 20th and enclosures attached, that Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund will undertake the complete installation of an automatic hot water heating system, for the sum of $4,384.00. I am unable to comment with regard to the suitability of the system proposed or the amount of the tender, but as Mr. Hargreaves apparently went into the matter in some detail while at Alert Bay, I would suggest that the proposal be referred to him and if acceptable to him both with regard to design and price, an attempt be made to have the tender accepted.

3. The installation of a master sewage system for the school building and two teacherages.- Mr. Todd has submitted a design for a sewage disposal system and a tender from Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund in the amount of $5,269.00, for material and labour. specifications are not available.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of July 11th bearing your notation of the 13th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

As mentioned in the memorandum referred to, our Mr. Har- greaves on a recent visit to Alert Bay, examined the heating plans which were prepared by the Crane Company Limited for the above school, and commented in detail to Indian Superintendent Todd.

It is felt that the price submitted by Messrs Westerlund and Western Ltd. for the installation of this work is fair and reasonable, and if the work is installed according to the plans, bearing in mind several points brought to Mr. Todd's attention, there would seem to be no reason why this system should not prove satisfactory. It might be well to stress the importance of using circulating pumps equal to those made by Bell and Gossett, S.A., Armstrong Company, or Minneapolis Honeywell Company.

Pumps made by any one of the above mentioned firms are specifically designed to positively operate against the required head which is an important consideration in forced hot water heating.

It should be pointed out that the ceiling of the Day School is anything but tight. During his visit to this building, our officer climbed through an access door into the ceiling space and found that the ceiling was very porous, full of cracks and admitted a great deal of light, which is a true indication that the heat loss through this ceiling would be abnormal at best. At times Rock wool either in loose or batt form should be laid between the ceiling joists over the ceiling or its equivalent in fibre board applied directly to the ceiling.

Since Mr. Todd had no specific data at the time of our officers visit with regard to the sewage disposal system, we are unable to offer worthwhile comment. It is felt however, that if the scheme verbally outlined by Mr. Todd to our officer and referred to in Major Mackay's memorandum is followed, this part of the work would be satisfactory.

Comment on matters dealing with the Residential School, will be furnished separately.

RE: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 2nd last, file #6-11-3, in which you informed me as follows: "With regard to the automatic hot water heating system proposed, owing to the cost the Department is unable to favorably consider the tenders submitted, and consequently it will be necessary to heat the buildings with oil stoves for another year as was done previously."

It is regretted that a special effort was not made to provide a proper heating system for this school. With regard to heating the buildings with oil stoves for another year as you suggest, I must point out this school has never been heated with oil stoves but rather with four old, rusty, worn-out Army Camp coal heaters, which no longer can be used and must be replaced as the grates in the stoves are no longer safe. All the heat we have had in this school to date is the four stoves, one in each classroom. The assembly room, wash rooms, teachers' office and storeroom have no heat installed and there are no chimneys in the building whereby individual stoves can be set up without building a chimney.

We are now proceeding with the installation of the plumbing and this end the sewerage system cannot be used unless heat is provided in this building, as the plumbing would freeze up. There is another bad feature. Unless heat is installed in the rest of the school, that part of our building is going to deteriorate so badly that we will have a major repair job on our hands. The V-joint is already bulging. All I can do is report these matters as they are.

It seems to me that for the sake of economy and to protect this new building from deterioration, where we have a very large investment, we should go all out and provide adequate heating and complete the construction of this school, even though we had to transfer funds from some other source. When Mr. Hargreaves was here from Ottawa, I asked

p.t.o.
him to give me a rough, approximate estimate of what he thought it would cost to put a proper heating system in this school, and he informed me it would be in the neighbourhood of $7,000.00. When we obtained a figure from Mr. Westerlund of $4,984.00, I felt we were getting an installation at a reasonable price.

Unless a central heating unit to heat this school is installed before the cold weather sets in we are going to be faced with replacing the four present stoves with oil burners at an approximate cost of $400.00, which will only provide heat for four classrooms and not for any other part of the school.

I am again recommending that the Department reconsider the installation of a central heating unit as recommended, but failing this I am requesting authority to purchase four new oil burning heaters for the four classrooms, and also authority to build chimneys on the rest of the school to take care of three more oil burners, and authority to purchase the oil burners for this part of the school. This will mean that we will have seven oil burners operating in the school, and the cost is going to be definitely very high, and even with this number of stoves there is no way that I can assure that the plumbing will not freeze due to being unable to distribute the heat owing to the plan of the building.

We have submitted through School Inspector Davey a daily report of the temperatures in the various classrooms where we had these old Army Camp heaters during last term; and this report alone should indicate to the Department that the building is not adequately heated, nor is it safe in the interests of the children's health to have them sitting in classrooms under these conditions.

I have now reported the matter as it is and cannot take any further responsibility should we be faced with a lot of illness in this school during the next term through lack of adequate heating.

Indian Superintendent.

RE: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 2nd last, file #6-11-3, in which you informed me as follows: "With regard to the automatic hot water heating system proposed, owing to the cost the Department is unable to favorably consider the tenders submitted, and consequently it will be necessary to heat the buildings with oil stoves for another year as was done previously."

It is regretted that a special effort was not made to provide a proper heating system for this school. With regard to heating the buildings with oil stoves for another year as you suggest, I must point out this school has never been heated with oil stoves but rather with four old, rusty, worn-out Army Camp coal heaters, which no longer can be used and must be replaced as the grates in the stoves are no longer safe. All the heat we have had in this school to date is the four stoves, one in each classroom. The assembly room, wash rooms, teachers' office and storeroom have no heat installed and there are no chimneys in the building whereby individual stoves can be set up without building a chimney.

We are now proceeding with the installation of the plumbing and this and the sewerage system cannot be used unless heat is provided in this building; as the plumbing would freeze up. There is another bad feature. Unless heat is installed in the rest of the school, that part of our building is going to deteriorate so badly that we will have a major repair job on our hands. The V-joint is already bulging. All I can do is report these matters as they are.

It seems to me that for the sake of economy and to protect this new building from deterioration, where we have a very large investment, we should go all out and provide adequate heating and complete the construction of this school, even though we had to transfer funds from some other source. When Mr. Hargreaves was here from Ottawa, I asked

p.t.o.
him to give me a rough, approximate estimate of what he thought it would cost to put a proper heating system in this school, and he informed me it would be in the neighbourhood of $7,000.00. When we obtained a figure from Mr. Westerlund of $4,984.00, I felt we were getting an installation at a reasonable price.

Unless a central heating unit to heat this school is installed before the cold weather sets in we are going to be faced with replacing the four present stoves with oil burners at an approximate cost of $400.00, which will only provide heat for four classrooms and not for any other part of the school.

I am again recommending that the Department reconsider the installation of a central heating unit as recommended, but failing this I am requesting authority to purchase four new oil burning heaters for the four classrooms, and also authority to build chimneys on the rest of the school to take care of three more oil burners, and authority to purchase the oil burners for this part of the school. This will mean that we will have seven oil burners operating in the school, and the cost is going to be definitely very high, and even with this number of stoves there is no way that I can assure that the plumbing will not freeze due to being unable to distribute the heat owing to the plan of the building.

We have submitted through School Inspector Davey a daily report of the temperatures in the various classrooms where we had these old Army Camp heaters during last term; and this report alone should indicate to the Department that the building is not adequately heated, nor is it safe in the interests of the children's health to have them sitting in classrooms under these conditions.

I have now reported the matter as it is and cannot take any further responsibility should we be faced with a lot of illness in this school during the next term through lack of adequate heating.

Indian Superintendent.
Alert Bay, B.C.,

RE: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Under date of August 10th last I submitted a further report in respect to the heating of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, pointing out we used four old Army Camp coal-burning heaters during last term to heat four classrooms only. I also pointed out that the rest of the building had no heat in it.

The present stoves are worn out and must be replaced. The rainy, cold weather is now with us and some decision will have to be made in respect to heating this school. A great deal of time was spent to ascertain the best method of heating this school. Plans were drawn, estimate of the cost obtained, and the equipment to make the installation is available and could be installed within four weeks, after approval was received from Ottawa.

Possibly I have not given the Department as much information as is necessary to assist them in arriving at a decision, and as something must be done to heat this school, I am writing you more fully. If the Department cannot see their way clear to install a central heating plant as recommended, it will be necessary to provide the following as a temporary measure. Purchase seven large circulating oil-burning heaters and erect three temporary chimneys at an estimated cost of $1100.00. This could only be considered a temporary measure as the seven stoves will not adequately heat the school due to the plan of the building.

There has been no adequate heat in parts of this building for two years with the result that the V-joint is beginning to bulge in places and I am afraid unless a proper heating system is installed, this fine new building will be damaged through lack of heat. Here on the Coast the climate is very damp and any building requires heat to keep it from deteriorating.

p.t.o.
On the other hand, if the Department proceeds with the installation of a central heating plant it will be a permanent installation and the money spent as a temporary measure for oil-burning heaters would go a considerable way towards reducing the cost of the permanent installation. We have also purchased most of the materials for the furnace room which is extra expense and will be of no value to us unless the central heating plant is installed in the furnace room we are providing.

In addition to this it is going to be very costly to operate seven oil-burning stoves whereas if we had a central heating unit one furnace would heat the whole building and thus reduce our cost of operating at least half.

I mentioned in my report of August 10th that Mr. Hargreaves had seen the plan as well as the building, and although he informed me he had no instructions from his office to make any recommendation in respect to the heating of the Day School and, therefore, could not officially do so without being requested but, however, felt as he was here he should give us any assistance he could under the circumstances, and stated he would be very glad to advise our Department if they wished to refer the matter to him upon his return to Ottawa. Knowing that Mr. Hargreaves was an expert on heating, I asked him what his opinion was as to cost of this heating plant. After he had examined the plan and visited the school he informed me privately in all probability it would cost the Department roughly $7,000.00 for a complete installation. Later when I was able to obtain a tender from Mr. Westerlund for an amount considerably less than this, I felt we were getting an exceptionally good offer.

Four classrooms are now in full session with an attendance of some 125 children. There is no heat in the school. Some children are walking approximately a mile to the school, and on cold rainy days it is not in the best interests of their health to have to sit in school with wet clothes and no heat. I cannot purchase fuel pending the Department's decision as to what type of heating is to be used.

It would be appreciated if the Department could give us a definite answer, preferably by wire. If you decide to install the central heating system as recommended and accept Mr. Westerlund's offer and would wire me accordingly, we could have the installation completed in approximately four weeks' time. It would be more economical to make the permanent installation and at the same time preserve the structure and provide adequate heating for this large enrolment of students.

Would the Department please consider this matter urgent and advise me their decision at the earliest convenience.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

Further to my letter of August 17th, I am enclosing for your information Supt. Todd's letter of September 14th wherein he outlines the alternative to the installation of the central heating system for the above-mentioned school building. I have previously recommended and would again recommend that the Department approve the installation of an automatic hot water heating system. An early decision would be appreciated.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources,

RE: ALERT BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Under date of August 10th last I submitted a further report in respect to the heating of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, pointing out we used four old Army Camp coal-burning heaters during last term to heat four classrooms only. I also pointed out that the rest of the building had no heat in it.

The present stoves are worn out and must be replaced. The rainy, cold weather is now with us and some decision will have to be made in respect to heating this school. A great deal of time was spent to ascertain the best method of heating this school. Plans were drawn, estimate of the cost obtained, and the equipment to make the installation is available and could be installed within four weeks, after approval was received from Ottawa.

Possibly I have not given the Department as much information as is necessary to assist them in arriving at a decision, and as something must be done to heat this school, I am writing you more fully. If the Department cannot see their way clear to install a central heating plant as recommended, it will be necessary to provide the following as a temporary measure. Purchase seven large circulating oil-burning heaters and erect three temporary chimneys at an estimated cost of $1100.00. This could only be considered a temporary measure as the seven stoves will not adequately heat the school due to the plan of the building.

There has been no adequate heat in parts of this building for two years with the result that the V-joint is beginning to bulge in places and I am afraid unless a proper heating system is installed, this fine new building will be damaged through lack of heat. Here on the Coast the climate is very damp and any building requires heat to keep it from deteriorating.

p.t.o.
On the other hand, if the Department proceeds with the installation of a central heating plant it will be a permanent installation and the money spent as a temporary measure for oil-burning heaters would go a considerable way towards reducing the cost of the permanent installation. We have also purchased most of the materials for the furnace room which is extra expense and will be of no value to us unless the central heating plant is installed in the furnace room we are providing.

In addition to this it is going to be very costly to operate seven oil-burning stoves whereas if we had a central heating unit one furnace would heat the whole building and thus reduce our cost of operating at least half.

I mentioned in my report of August 10th that Mr. Hargreaves had seen the plan as well as the building, and although he informed me he had no instructions from his office to make any recommendation in respect to the heating of the Dry School and, therefore, could not officially do so without being requested but, however, felt as he was here he should give us any assistance he could under the circumstances, and stated he would be very glad to advise our Department if they wished to refer the matter to him upon his return to Ottawa. Knowing that Mr. Hargreaves was an expert on heating, I asked him what his opinion was as to cost of this heating plant. After he had examined the plan and visited the school he informed me privately in all probability it would cost the Department roughly $7,000.00 for a complete installation. Later when I was able to obtain a tender from Mr. Westerlund for an amount considerably less than this, I felt we were getting an exceptionally good offer.

Four classrooms are now in full session with an attendance of some 125 children. There is no heat in the school. Some children are walking approximately a mile to the school, and on cold rainy days it is not in the best interests of their health to have to sit in school with wet clothes and no heat. I cannot purchase fuel pending the Department's decision as to what type of heating is to be used.

It would be appreciated if the Department could give us a definite answer, preferably by wire. If you decide to install the central heating system as recommended and accept Mr. Westerlund's offer and would wire me accordingly, we could have the installation completed in approximately four weeks' time. It would be more economical to make the permanent installation and at the same time preserve the structure and provide adequate heating for this large enrolment of students.

Would the Department please consider this matter urgent and advise me their decision at the earliest convenience.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

PART IV SPECIFICATIONS

(1) Scope of Work

The work to be done includes; the excavating of 1310 lineal feet of trench, the laying of 580 lineal feet of six inch diameter vitrified tile pipe and 730 lineal feet of cast iron pipe and backfilling of these trenches, the construction of four man holes and one septic tank.

(2) Excavating

The Contractor shall excavate to the dimensions and depths indicated or required. The trenches for pipe line shall be open cuts excavated along straight lines; these shall have a minimum of six inches between the outside of the pipe body and the side of the trench or bracing, with a minimum width of trench of two feet. Additional excavation shall be made under bell ends to allow for caulking and to give the pipe a uniform bearing.

Excavations below depths indicated without specific directions shall be refilled to the proper grade with thoroughly compacted suitable fill. All additional work of this nature shall be at the contractor's expense.

(3) Backfilling in Trenches

The backfilling of trenches shall progress as rapidly as the construction and testing of the work shall permit. Approved fill, free from vegetable matter, shall first be compacted firmly and evenly on both sides of the pipe in six inch layers to a depth of one foot over top of the pipe. In tamping around pipes, care shall be taken to avoid unequal lateral pressure. The earth to the height specified above shall be carefully thrown in with shovels and not dumped. The remainder of the trenches shall be backfilled in dry well-rammed one foot layers. Trenches shall be crowned to allow for settlement.
(4) **Filling Against New Concrete**

Filling against the septic tank and man holes or other new concrete shall not commence until 14 clear days have elapsed from time of pouring. Backfill shall be free from vegetable matter or large boulders and shall be thoroughly consolidated by ramming in one foot layers.
1. Concrete Work

a. Cement - The type of cement used shall be normal Portland cement and shall be in good condition.

b. Water - The water for mixing shall be clean and fresh and free from oil, acid, salt, alkali, and organic matter.

c. Aggregate - (i) Fine aggregate shall consist of natural sand having hard strong durable uncoated particles.

(ii) Coarse aggregate shall consist of broken stone or natural gravel having hard strong, durable pieces free from adherent coatings and vegetable matter. The maximum size of coarse aggregate shall be one inch.

d. Proportions and Mixing of Concrete - All concrete shall be proportioned by volumetric measurement to the proportions of one sack (Canadian) Portland cement to two cubic feet of fine aggregate and four cubic feet of coarse aggregate. In order to obtain proper workability and a smooth, dense, homogeneous, plastic mixture free from segregation, the exact division of the total aggregate between fine and coarse may be varied from the approximate ratios above specified. In any event, however, the sum of the volumes of the fine and coarse aggregate, measured separately, used for each sack of cement shall not be greater than the volume of the total aggregate specified. The amount of water used per sack of cement shall not exceed seven imperial gallons.

e. Mixing - All concrete shall be machine mixed. The contractor shall provide at the site of the work an improved type of batch mixer and measuring device for the accurate measurement of water and the aggregate
ingredients. The minimum time of mixing, after all materials including water are in the mixer, shall be one and one-half minutes.

2. Reinforcing

All reinforcing shall, when placed, be free from scale, grease, clay, and other coatings, and foreign substances that would reduce or destroy the bond.

a. Reinforcing bars shall be corrugated round of intermediate grade structural steel.

3. Forms

Forms shall be built true to line and grade; they shall be of wood and shall be mortar tight and sufficiently rigid to prevent displacement or sagging between supports. Responsibility for their adequacy shall rest with the contractor. Knot holes and broken pieces on wood forms shall be covered with metal patches. All form work shall be provided with adequate clean-out openings to permit easy cleaning after all reinforcement has been placed. All forms shall be constructed so that they can be removed without hammering or prying against the concrete.

4. Placing Reinforcement

All reinforcing bars shall be placed as indicated in the plan together with all necessary wire ties and other devices required to install and secure the reinforcing properly.

a. Reinforcement shall be formed to the dimensions indicated. Cold bends shall be made around a pin having a diameter not less than four times the least diameter of the bar. Heating of reinforcement for bending shall not be allowed. All reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured and shall be supported by concrete or metal chairs or by spacers or by metal hangers.

b. Splicing - All splices shall overlap by at least one foot. Adjacent bars shall not be spliced at the same point. The lapped ends of the bars shall be separated to develop the entire bond strength of each bar.
5. Conveyance and Placing

a. Conveying - Concrete shall be conveyed from the mixer to the forms as rapidly as practicable by methods which will prevent segregation and loss of ingredients. It shall be deposited as nearly as practical to its final position to avoid rehandlings. The concrete shall not be discharged directly from chutes into forms. All concrete shall be deposited as soon as practical after forms have been set up and reinforcing placed. It shall be placed before initial set, and in any event, not later than 20 minutes after mixing. In no case shall concrete which has partially set or concrete which has been remixed with the addition of cement or water be used in the work. Concrete which has been segregated in conveying shall be wasted.

b. Placing - All concrete shall be placed in the dry. It shall be deposited in approximately horizontal layers. The method of depositing concrete shall be such as to avoid displacing the reinforcing. The concrete shall be compacted by tamping or puddling either manually or by machine in an approved manner. Concrete shall not be poured through the reinforcing steel as in walls of septic tank and/or manholes in such cases, hoppers or other approved means shall be used to prevent segregation.

6. Protection and Curing

a. General Requirements - Concrete shall be adequately protected from injurious action by the sun, heavy rains, flowing water, frost and mechanical injury and shall not be allowed to dry out from the time it is placed until the expiration of the minimum curing period specified in these specifications.

b. Curing - Wood forms shall be left in place for a period of seven days and they shall be kept sufficiently damp at all times to prevent opening at the joints and drying out of the concrete. The temperature of the air in
contact with the concrete shall not be less than 50° F. for a period of not less than seven days after placing. Heating of the concrete in place shall be affected by salamanders or steam coils under canvas covers or by other approved means. The temperature shall not exceed 100° F., and adequate moisture shall be applied to the concrete surface during the heating period to prevent its drying out.

c. Removal of forms - All form work should be left intact for a period of 14 days after placing of concrete.

7. Construction Joints

All construction joints in walls or floors shall be constructed to ensure strong, dense concrete at the joint. The surface shall be cleaned and roughened and shall be broomed with a neat cement grout immediately before the new concrete is deposited. All reinforcing steel shall be cleaned and in good repair before pouring is resumed.
Laying Tile Pipes

(a) General - All vitrified tile pipe used shall be hard burned clay and salt glazed. It shall be free from cracks or blemishes and shall be of the bell and spigot type.

(b) Laying - The bottom of the trench shall be to grade for at least 25 feet ahead before laying of pipe is commenced. The bell holes shall be dug at least eight or ten feet in advance of pipe laying and shall be of such size that the jointer can pass his hand entirely under and around the front of the bell. Each pipe shall be set accurately to grade and line and the laying shall commence at the low point of grade and proceed upwards.

(c) Jointing - Before a pipe is laid the lower part of the bell shall be plastered on the inside with a stiff mortar of equal parts of Portland cement and sand of sufficient thickness to bring the inner bottoms of the butting pipe flush and even. After the pipe is laid the remainder of the bell shall be thoroughly filled with similar mortar and the joint wiped inside and finished with a smooth bevel outside. Water shall not be allowed to stand in the bell-hole after the pipe is cemented. If liable the bell-hole shall be filled with sand and well tamped. Water shall not be allowed to run through the pipe for at least three days after the last joint has been made.
Cast Iron Pipe and Fittings

(a) General - All cast iron pipe and fittings shall be uncoated, sound, cylindrical, and smooth, free from cracks, sand holes and other defects and of uniform thickness and of the grade known in commerce as medium. All cast iron pipe shall be of the bell and spigot type. Pipe, including the hub, shall not weigh less than an average of 14 pounds per foot.

(b) Laying - The bottom of the trench shall be to grade for at least 100 feet ahead before laying of pipe is commenced. The bell holes shall be dug at least three pipe lengths in advance of pipe laying, and shall be of such size that the fitter can pass his hand entirely under and around the front of the bell. Each pipe length shall be set accurately to grade and line and the laying shall commence at the low point of the grade and proceed upwards.

(c) Jointing - Before jointing the pipe the bell and spigots of all joints shall be thoroughly cleaned, two rings of jute shall be placed around the spigot, the ends of the jute shall be butted together on opposite sides of the pipe and not on top or bottom. The pipe shall be centered and the end of the spigot shall be solid against the hub of the bell. The jute shall be caulked in an approved manner with a yarning iron and hammer leaving a uniform depth to the hub of 2½ inches.

Before placing the runner the joint shall be thoroughly cleaned. The joint shall be poured with lead or similar approved jointing material and finished in an approved manner.
Man Holes, Vents, Cover Plates and Vent Caps

The man hole covers shall be cast iron, uncoated, sound free from cracks, sand holes, and other defects, and covers shall be well fitted to frames. All man holes shall have circular openings of minimum of 20 inches diameter, fitted to a square frame. The weight shall be of the grade known to commerce as medium.

All man hole frames shall be well embedded into concrete and shall be plumb and true to dimension as indicated on the plans.

Cover plates shall be of medium grade structural steel and shall be fitted as designed and dimensioned on the plans.

Vent caps shall be of cast iron free from defects and of the grade known to commerce as medium. Caps shall be firmly fitted with a set screw to the vent pipe.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Alert Bay Indian Day School - Heating.

This is a four-room day school which is housed in buildings formerly used by the Army at Fort Hardy. At the present time these buildings are heated by the old stoves which we obtained as surplus items from War Assets Corporation. These stoves are rusty and worn out army camp coal heaters which we can no longer use with safety. There is one in each classroom and no heat is provided in the assembly hall, the wash-rooms, teachers' office and store-rooms, nor are there chimneys in the building whereby individual stoves could be set up in these rooms.

Therefore, in order to properly heat this school, we have two alternatives:

(a) The installation of a central heating unit;

(b) The installation of four oil heaters for the four classrooms; the building of three chimneys and the installation of three additional oil burners.

We were fortunate in having our heating engineer at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School at the time the heating of this school was under discussion. You will find his report attached hereto. I also attach the tender received from Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund for the installation of this automatic hot water heating plant. You will note that this is in the amount of $4,984.00 which we feel to be a reasonable price.

We have thoroughly investigated the heating of this
school and while the oil burners may seem cheaper, it will mean seven stoves to maintain and the amount of fuel oil consumed will be very high.

Therefore we would recommend, for the acceptance of the Minister, the tender of Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund. This company has recently repaired and modernized the Department of Public Works building in Alert Bay and is competent in every way to handle this contract.

Re: Alert Bay Indian Day School,
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of July 11th bearing your notation of the 13th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

As mentioned in the memorandum referred to, our Mr. Har- greaves on a recent visit to Alert Bay, examined the heating plans which were prepared by the Crane Company Limited for the above school, and commented in detail to Indian Superintendent Todd.

It is felt that the price submitted by Messers Westerlund and Westerlund for the installation of this work is fair and reasonable, and if the work is installed according to the plans, bearing in mind several points brought to Mr. Todd's attention, there would seem to be no reason why this system should not prove satisfactory. It might be well to stress the importance of using circulating pumps equal to those made by Bell and Gossett, S.A. Armstrong Company, or Minneapolis Honeywell Company.

Pumps made by any one of the above mentioned firms are specifically designed to positively operate against the required head which is an important consideration in forced hot water heating.

It should be pointed out that the ceiling of the Day School is anything but tight. During his visit to this building, our officer climbed through an access door into the ceiling space and found that the ceiling was very porous, full of cracks and admitted a great deal of light, which is a true indication that the heat loss through this ceiling would be abnormal in the wintertime. Rock wool either in loose or batt form should be laid between the ceiling joists over the ceiling or its equivalent in fibre board applied directly to the ceiling.

Since Mr. Todd had no specific data at the time of our officer's visit with regard to the sewage disposal system, we are unable to offer worthwhile comment. It is felt however, that if the scheme verbally outlined by Mr. Todd to our officer and referred to in Major Mackay's memorandum is followed, this part of the work would be satisfactory.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Alert Bay Indian Day School - Heating.

This is a four-room day school which is housed in buildings formerly used by the Army at Port Hardy. At the present time these buildings are heated by the old stoves which we obtained as surplus items from War Assets Corporation. These stoves are rusty and worn out army camp coal heaters which we can no longer use with safety. There is one in each classroom and no heat is provided in the assembly hall, the wash-rooms, teachers' office and store-room, nor are there chimneys in the building whereby individual stoves could be set up in these rooms.

Therefore, in order to properly heat this school, we have two alternatives:

(a) The installation of a central heating unit;

(b) The installation of four oil heaters for the four classrooms; the building of three chimneys and the installation of three additional oil burners.

We were fortunate in having our heating engineer at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School at the time the heating of this school was under discussion. You will find his report attached hereto. I also attach the tender received from Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund for the installation of this automatic hot water heating plant. You will note that this is in the amount of $4,984.00 which we feel to be a reasonable price.

We have thoroughly investigated the heating of this
school and while the oil burners may seem cheaper, it will mean seven stoves to maintain and the amount of fuel oil consumed will be very high.

Therefore we would recommend, for the acceptance of the Minister, the tender of Messrs. Westerlund and Westerlund. This company has recently repaired and modernized the Department of Public Works building in Alert Bay and is competent in every way to handle this contract.

Dear Judge Young:

As requested in our recent conversation regarding establishing an Indian school here, I will now give you the most important facts in connection with this matter. The Indians have for the last two years been anxious to send their children to the Public School here. This is contrary to the School Acts of B.C. and would not be tolerated by the white residents.

Taku Jack (Chief) has written several letters to the Department asking them to look into the matter of educating the Indian children. When at the coast a short time ago I several times interviewed the Revd. A.E. Green, Inspector of Indian Schools and he is of the opinion that the Indians should be educated and advised me to lay the matter before Mr. Sloan M.P.

I have ample time to teach the Indians, either in the afternoons or evenings as I am free.
after 3 o'clock in the winter & 3:30 p.m. in the summer.

I should be very glad of the appointment as my present salary as teacher is only $5.00 a month whereas in the neighbouring schools of the Yukon Territory no male teacher receives less than $20.00 per month or female $17.50.

As you personally are aware the living here is exceptionally high, even higher than the Yukon Territory.

It may say should a school be opened the Indians have promised to leave their children here all the year round and to make Athi their headquarters.

This would be of great benefit to the town as previously our Indians would sell their furs & trade in White Horse & Juneau, and very little benefit was consequently derived by the Athi store-keepers.

They also state as soon as word was sent to the Teslin Indians that a school was to be opened many of them would also come and make Athi their headquarters.

The Indians at present residing here are of the Wolf & Bear tribes of Canadian Indians.
and number about 130 souls including about 40 children.

Apparently although Canadian Indians up to the present time have not been under any Dominion jurisdiction.

The Indians of the adjoining Yukon Territory I believe are looked after by the Mounted Police.

Unfortunately I missed seeing William Sloan Esq M.P. both in Athabasca and I should be very much obliged indeed if you would personally lay the matter before him.

Thanking you in anticipation and regretting troubling you. I am,

Yours very truly,
Malcolm R. J. Reid

P.S. It would not be necessary for the Govt. to build a school, as I have no doubt our schoolhouse could be used after regular hours, on payment of a nominal sum for rent & fuel.

He thinks a Day School should be established at Teslin Lake, whose Indians are Canadians and live say 100 miles from the international boundary. This school should be at Teslin not at Atlin. While at Atlin there are American Indians from Juneau and at times Teslin Lake Indians there are no others, the domicile of the former being Juneau, of the latter Teslin Lake.

(November 1937.)
Accompanied by the Indian Chief, Taku Jack, we visited the School House, which was opened early last summer in the Indian Village, by the Rev. Father Ollard. We found the Rev. Father superintending the education of eight boy pupils in the primitive but well-appointed school room; everything was in order, maps and instructive pictures and black board hanging on the walls, and desks and benches occupied by the pupils studying English. The boys looked clean, cheerful and intelligent; they average between six and sixteen years of age. To our surprise 'six years old' with class book in hand, stood forth, and distinctly spelt and recited a sentence to the effect that 'the cow did eat the grass' and then the big boy of sixteen gave a good example of his more advanced learning in the English tongue. All of which is highly creditable to the industrious young teacher. During part of the summer there were 30 children under tuition, but owing to funds being very limited, most of them had to go out in the woods for the winter.

We would observe that Father Ollard for the present is entirely dependent upon local support for the maintenance of the school and board of the pupils. The Atlin Indians belong to the Hlinsit tribe, which is a branch of the Taku tribe. Hlinsit, in the native language, is synonymous with Gentlemen in English, and from all we can see and learn the Indian inhabitants of Atlin do not belie their appropriate nomenclature. Chief Taku Jack's knowledge of ancient history extends to the memory that his Grandfather was the proud possessor of a flint-lock-gun, this might account for a period of three generations, as the gun takes to make a Hlinsit (gentleman) amongst ourselves. We hope that Father Ollards Home and School for Indian children will ere long obtain support from the Dominion Government. These Indian children, the representatives of a race which inhabited the country long before the "pale-face" set foot upon its shores call forth the sympathy of their rulers, and under the Dominion Government protects an Indian population of 108,000; and has established 279 schools for their benefit in different parts of Canada, of this number 104 are conducted by the R. C. Church; 86 by Anglicans; 49 by Methodists; 16 by Presbyterians; and the rest are undenominational. Canada recognizes that the Indians have a claim to land, she protects their lands and promotes their welfare, and the reward for her humanity will be amply found in the honest upbringing and civilization of her Indian subjects.

We wish Father Ollard all the success he deserves in his meritorious efforts to guide and educate the promising young Hlinsits of Atlin.

re Establishment of School at Atlin.

In August, 1906, Mr. Superintendent Vowell forwarded a letter from Mr. Green, Inspector of Indian schools, B.C., respecting the advisability of establishing an Indian school at Atlin, in reply to which he was informed that, before this matter could be considered, the Department would require to be in possession of definite information regarding the need of a school at this point, the number and character of the Indians, etc., it being a question whether these Indians are Canadian or American.

In October of that year Mr. Sloan, M.P., forwarded a communication from Mr. H.J. Reid, teacher of the public school there, on the same subject. Mr. Sloan was advised that this matter would receive consideration.

Another letter in this connection was received from Mr. J.A. Fraser, Government Agent at Atlin, informing the Department that Mr. Reid, above referred to, would be willing to undertake the education of the Indian children at Atlin after hours, provided he was paid. Mr. Fraser says that he was always under the impression that they were American Indians, although they claim to belong to the Bear and Wolf tribes of Canadian Indians. He thinks it would be a pity not to assist and encourage them even from a humanitarian standpoint. This letter was also forwarded through Mr. Sloan.

On the strength of these communications Mr. Vowell was requested to forward the information asked for as soon as possible. He replied that he had no opportunity of visiting the locality but that he intended to do so as soon as practicable, accompanied by Mr. Inspector Green. The Superintendent was told that the Department approves of his suggestion to make a joint visit with the Inspector and that it would await his report before taking any definite action; and we are in receipt of a letter from him dated the 13th instant in which he states that upon inquiry he learns that sometime about the first week in June is the earliest date upon which it would be practicable for himself and Mr. Inspector Green to start.

Only last month a letter was received from the Secretary of the Atlin District Board of Trade, stating that in accordance with a resolution adopted by that body he submitted to the favourable consideration of the Department the following urgent appeal:

"That the Atlin Indian school, under the superintendence of the Rev. F. J. Allard, be granted assistance by the Dominion Government from the appropriation fund allowed for Indian schools."

The Board give the following reasons for making this application:

(1) That the school was opened in the Indian village, adjacent to Atlin, on the 2nd of July, 1907, by the Rev. F. J. Allard.

(2) That the maximum number of 20 and an average of 14 pupils attended the said school until September 1, 1907.

(3) That since September 1, 1907, eight pupils have been housed, fed and instructed in the said school, as they continue to be at present.

(4)
That the Board is satisfied the Indian school is carried on in a highly creditable and efficient manner and that it will prove in every respect beneficial to our Indian community.

That the said Indian school acquired its building, furniture, food, fuel, etcetera entirely from local contributions.

That, in the opinion of this Board, the aforesaid institution is well worthy of support from the Dominion Government; and respectfully submits the citizens of Atlin be relieved of the expense devolving upon them for its maintenance.

You will see that Father Allard's venture contemplates the establishment of a boarding school with a per capita grant from the Department.

The first point to establish is whether these are American or Canadian Indians; if the former, they have no claim on the Department; if recognized as Canadian Indians and they have enough children to justify the establishment of a school, their needs should be attended to. Then the question of the class of school to be established there arises, whether a boarding or day. If the former, a higher per capita grant than is usually made would be necessary to meet the increased cost of supplies and if a day school a higher salary than is usually paid would be needed to secure the services of a teacher. The Department has no information as to the religious belief of these Indians, whether Protestant or Catholic, and it would require to know definitely what denomination should have control.

Atlin Indian School.

(1) Considering that on the 2nd day of July last, a school was opened in the Indian village adjacent to the town of Atlin, by the Rev. F. J. Allard:

(2) Considering that a maximum of 30 and an average of 14 pupils have attended the said school during two months:

(3) Considering that at the end of these two months (that is since the first part of September) eight pupils have been housed and fed in said school.

(4) Considering that a visit to the said school has demonstrated that the work carried on there is most efficient:

(5) Considering that the said school acquired its premises and so far obtained its many wants, such as food, fuel etc., merely from local support:

(6) Considering that the said institution is worthy to be maintained and that such a burden, or right, devolves not upon the citizens of Atlin, but upon the Dominion Government:

Therefore, we the undersigned citizens of Atlin, respectfully request our Hon. Member, Mr. William Sloan, to urge the Dominion Government to provide the Atlin Indian School with its much needed support.

Sir,

ATLIN RANG:

On the 15th. ulto we proceeded by steamer en route to Atlin, B.C., arriving on the 17th.; where we learned that in July, 1907, the Rev. Father Allard had taken charge of some sixteen pupils. (The Indians of that place being particularly desirous for the education of their children.) The school was carried on in a small cabin, under many difficulties, during the summer months. The children proved to be amenable to discipline, and by their industry and close attention to their studies, making very satisfactory progress.

During the winter the Rev. Father at his own cost maintained nine of these pupils. Not only attending to their instruction personally, but also attending to the cooking, etc., with very good results.

Owing to the nomadic habits of these Indians a Day School would be of little use, and we would strongly recommend that the Rev. Father Allard's praiseworthy efforts in the direction referred to, be supported by the Department and that a grant be made for the erection of a Boarding School at this place.

A.W.Vowell,
Supt. Indian Affairs,
Victoria, B.C.

Sir,

The Atlin Indians whom you visited on the 17th of July last numbered 84 persons. There are 43 adults and 41 children of whom 24 are of school age. The Testlin Indians inhabiting 80 miles from here are of the same tribe and are blood relations to the Atlin Indians. The Testlin Indians number 64. There are 40 adults and 24 children of whom 13 are of school age. You are aware, Sir, of the Atlin Indians' desire to have a Roman Catholic School. Now I have just returned from a trip to Testlin, and I am glad to say that it is a rather easy matter to get the few Testlin children to attend the Atlin school. Already the Great Chief of the tribe and the Testlin Chief's only sons both residing in Testlin have been intrusted to my care for the next school year. Now, this is the situation which calls for immediate government help. There are in this district 37 children of school age. Last year in July I opened a school for them, a maximum of 24 pupils and an average of 14 attended school for the first three months. When the first three months were over in September, the Indians went to the woods for trapping furs. Most of them remained in the woods the whole winter, many even did not come back till June. Under such conditions, school is impossible unless the pupils are taught, fed and cared for in the school itself. This is what I have done in September last year. I took nine pupils with me. I taught and fed them, and cared for them during the whole year. To maintain such an institution, I begged for alms in and out of Atlin. The same school system is the only practical

practical one for the coming year, and this time it is not only nine pupils but at least 20 pupils that must be taught, fed and cared for. Such work must be carried on in a convenient building. Such work cannot be carried on without the cooperation of two teachers and a cook. I therefore entreat you, Sir, to provide the Atlin and Teslin Indians with a school and some support. The erection of a school in which over 30 children can be taught and cared for, would cost in this country at least three thousand dollars, provided yet the Indians helped in doing the work. The season is too far advanced to put up such a building in time for school opening this year. Therefore, I beg your department to allow at least two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.) for school rent this year. With regard to school support, I wish to inform you that at least 20 pupils will this year be taught, fed and cared for in the Atlin school. Now since sixty dollars per capita is considered a reasonable support where provisions can be had cheaper, I hope a special and greater allowance shall be made for Atlin where victuals cost nearly twice as much as in south western British Columbia. Remark, there was in Atlin last winter a teacher who many a time begged the white people to lend him their dogs in order to send one of his pupils after some wild meat. The same teacher also many a time stretched out a beggar's hand entreating white people to help him buying flour, beans, etc., for himself and his pupils. At last the white people universally signed a petition urging the government to support the Atlin Indian school & its teacher. I hope, Sir, you will attend to this matter & provide us in time with a rented school and a reasonable support for 20 pupils this year. Meanwhile, Sir, I want the subject to be laid before your department for the grant of an Indian Reserve in this district, and the erection of a convenient school if not this fall, at least early next summer.

Yours, J. Allard O.M.I. Atlin B.C.

A.W. Vowell,
Victoria B.C.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Supt. Vowell has forwarded a letter from the Rev. J. Allard, of Atlin, B.C., asking for the recognition of the Indian school he has established there as a boarding school, with a suitable per capita grant for at least 30 pupils, in addition to which he requests that a convenient school building to accommodate this number of children as boarders be erected.

He also asks to be allowed at least $250 for rent of the building they are at present occupying.

Mr. Superintendent Vowell states that in looking over the joint report of himself and Mr. Green, which he considers Father Allard's request most reasonable and recommends it to the favourable consideration of the Department.

No stated amount is given for either the building or the per capita grant, but Father Allard says, that as everything costs twice as much there as in the other portions of the province, a much larger grant would be necessary. Mr. Vowell gives the cost of rough lumber at $32 per M and dressed lumber at $40 per M at Atlin.

Mr. Vowell and Mr. Green state in their report that

that owing to the nomadic habits of these Indians a day school would be of little use and they strongly recommend that the Rev. Father Allard's praiseworthy efforts be supported by the Department and that a grant be made for the erection of a boarding school at that place.

I find, on referring to previous correspondences on File 296776 that a similar application was made through Mr. Sloan, then member for this district, upon which you made a memorandum to the Minister, setting out that the first point to be decided was whether they are American or Canadian Indians and also as to their religious belief, whether Protestant or Catholic. These two points are not referred to in the joint report, although it may be taken for granted that had they been American or Protestant Indians, they would have mentioned the fact. If the Department allows Father Allard to continue receiving and maintaining Indian children, he will expect to be paid for their support, but before going to any expense in the erection of buildings it would be well for the Department to decide whether these Indians are ripe for boarding school education. Mr. Vowell remarks that he knows of many Indians in British Columbia who are doing fairly well in their uneducated state. The confinement and change of life might have a serious effect upon their health and it would be well to consider this fully before the Department commits itself.

I think two files on this subject are likely to cause confusion.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General,

I think it is sufficiently clear that Canadian Indians resort to Atlin and receive tuition in the School established by Father Allard at that place, and with this understanding I made my recommendation of the 13th instant. We can, however, when corresponding with the Victoria Office about the proposed grant emphasize this point. I would propose, if this grant is approved of, to write a letter that will preclude any claims for a Boarding School Grant; which I am convinced should not be paid for this School. If we have a Roman Catholic Day School at Atlin and a Church of England Day School at Teslin Lake the needs of that district will be fairly met.

Chief Accountant.
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

Pursuant to the conversation which I held with the Minister the other day as regards the School at Atlin, B.C., I beg to report that if you think it advisable to give any assistance to this School it might be accorded the most favorable treatment that we would give to a Day School, namely, a salary of $500.00 per annum and say $200.00 for the rental of the building in which the School is now conducted. This grant could be made for the current year without pledging the Department as to what course will be taken next year. I think at the same time you should give Father Allard to understand very clearly that we do not favor the establishment of Boarding Schools in these outlying districts, and cannot consent to give anything toward the erection of buildings for a Boarding School nor any assistance in the way of a regular per capita grant. It is most important that we should be firm with these Missionaries, who are endeavoring to force their views of Indian education upon us.

Chief Accountant.
Ottawa, March 5, 1909.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of August 20, last, forwarding a copy of a communication addressed to you by the Rev. Father Allard, of Atlin, B.C., asking for the recognition of an Indian Boarding School there and the erection of a suitable building to accommodate twenty pupils, with a sufficient per capita grant to maintain them, I beg to say that the Department cannot entertain this proposition, and you should inform Father Allard that it has no intention of recognizing or contributing towards the maintenance of a boarding school at Atlin and that this decision is final.

The Department is, however, prepared to afford the most favourable treatment to a day school there and will allow a salary of $600 per annum and $300 for the rental of the building in which the school is conducted.

The continuance of this grant will be contingent upon the results obtained at the school next year.

This arrangement may go into effect from January 1, last, and payment will be made quarterly upon receipt of the usual day school returns and a voucher for the quarter's rent.

Your obedient Servant,

A.W. Vowell, Esq.,

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the following report on enrollment and attendance at the Ottawa Indian Day School together with the cause for both enrollment and attendance being reduced during winter months.

All the Ottawa Indians are trapping fur during winter months. They take their children along with them. These are left in the school practically only those whom I can afford to board, for if the trappers ever come to town during these months they remain here but a short time thereby allowing only a few days of school to their children. In summer days the Indians stay here most of the time. But if they are out of fish or meat, they go to the woods with their children for a week or two. In the latter case is the cause for irregular attendance. In the former case is the cause of reduced attendance in winter.

Report of the Attin Indian Day School

Attin B.C.

From June 1909 to June 1910, 26 pupils have attended school.

They are divided into four general classes:

1) The A.B.C. class
2) The Spelling class
3) The Spelling & Reading No. 1
4) The Spelling & Reading No. 2

It has 4 pupils. 2 of them, Jackson John and Ward Julia know their letters, write them fairly well on the slate. The other two, Jackson Louis and Jack Jackson Daisy know their letters but imperfectly. Like the preceding ones they have a greater facility for learning what is taught in the class standing, namely the names of the different parts of the body, the objects in the school, etc.

2) The Spelling class

It has 18 pupils of whom 6 succeeded and 2 are fair and 2 poor. The pupils who succeed are Bean Arthur and Ward Julia who have seen all their Primer during the year. The other 4: Jackson Andrew, Jack Eaton, John Williams, Frank and Jackson George have learned their Primer as far as page 15. The former as well as these can not only spell the words but read without much hesitation and come up with a relatively natural tone the whole sentence contained in their books. They can also copy well the ones from their Primer into their scribbled pages of the book, counting and figuring as far as a hundred is also part of their knowledge, etc. The two fair ones are Paddy Anna and Paddy Mary. They have spelled their Primer as far as page 19. They begin to write words and orally they know very near as much.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Moreover having accepted that charge, I must convey to the Department the incessant request of the Atlin Indians for a day school. They want to learn how to read and write. Their constant dealings with white people make them realize this need. They claim they feel ashamed to appear so ignorant. In fact they have more reasons for that feeling now than they had in the past. Atlin has become a Summer resort of considerable importance. The numerous tourists who come there inevitably visit the Indian Village, inquire about their school, deprecate the want of it &c. Hence, I hope, that a school that will cost so little and satisfy so many will readily be granted by the Department. It would be sufficient to run it 6 months in the year, viz: from the 15th of April to the 15th of October, the period of time when most of those Indians stay in their village at Atlin.

Respectfully yours,

E. M. Bunoz, O.M.I.

Telegraph Creek, August 31st, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report for the month ending August 31st, 1926.

On my return from the Liard and McDames quarter, on August 1st, I heard that Taku Jack, Chief of the Atlin Band had died (July 7th) and a note from his son requested that I come over and adjust matters in connection with the estate. I also heard that the School Master in charge of the summer school was delinquent in his duties, so after closing accounts for July, I left Telegraph Creek on the fifth and arrived in Atlin on the evening of the tenth, inspected school on the eleventh and found that the attendance had dwindled from twelve to three, and after careful investigation I concluded that the fault lay entirely with the School Master who did not keep regular hours and closed the school whenever he desired an outing, but in his report he claimed to have had the school open every day during the past month. I visited the different families with children and induced them to send their children back assuring them that the matter would be submitted to headquarters and a proper teacher substituted as I did not wish to close the school owing to the fact that it would take such a long time to get a new master in and the term would close on October fifteenth. The result was that when I left there were eight children in attendance and I hope that matters may improve until a better man can be found.

W. Scott Simpson.

Sir,

On my arrival in Atlin on August 11th, I visited the Indian Day School established April 15th, on recommendation of the local Catholic Bishop. The number in attendance had dwindled to three, and the school master, Kenneth Mungier stated that the Indians had gradually withdrawn their children from school and that most of them had moved away to Takla Arm with their families. But on visiting the Indians I found that there were nine children then living within one hundred yards of the school and on questioning the parents I was informed that frequently the master left the school unopened and at times they would not see him before 3 P.M., and then he would leave his house and go to town and would not return until 8 A.M. I said nothing to him for the moment but requested him to submit a report on instructions from the opening day April 15th to end of first quarter, July 15th. This statement I am enclosing herewith for your perusal. After doing this there were 64 days in the quarter - School opened for 6 days and four days holiday. After receiving this statement I confronted him with the information given by the Indians, and he then admitted that he was ill at the time and kept the school closed for a week, but would not admit that he did not keep proper hours. I told him that I would bring the Indians before him if he wished to hear them repeat the accusations, but he said it was not necessary. I told him that I would have to report the matter to the Department but he made no plea in defense, and when I talked to the Indians and assured them that a more suitable master would be sent in the coming year if attendance justified the keeping up of the school, they agreed to let school continue just as they are now and that they would attend education, and for the past week all of the Indians in the vicinity, the number of nine are in regular attendance.

I am leaving tomorrow for Telegraph Creek as the School opens on the 1st of September under the management of a new teacher Miss Turvey and I am anxious to have as many as possible enrolled. Kenneth Mungier in my opinion is unfit for the duty of teaching the Indian children; he is inclined to slack and will not keep regular hours but unfortunately the season is so far advanced that we will have to let him complete the second quarter which ends October 15th, as there is no time in which to secure a proper teacher to relieve him. He is owing a number of merchants for supplies and states that he has not received a salary cheque to date from the Department as they have practically closed down on his activities further credit and they have refused to make inquiry as to the true state of this situation as they say that he has already received his cheque and has cashed it in some other quarter. Possibly after my reconnoissance he will make an endeavour to follow out the rules as he has been told that the Indians are instructed to keep account of the attendance and report if he fails in his duty during my absence.

I am surprised that a mere boy should have been sent to fill the position where functionality should be the outstanding feature.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W. Scott Simpson
Indian Agent.

Sir:

As I told you yesterday, the Atlin Indian Day School can be re-
opened next summer. Three years ago, in the spring of 1929, the Department
of Indian Affairs at Ottawa informed me in their letter to the Right Rev.
Bishop Dunne, of Prince Rupert, that they would grant $90.00 a month for
teacher's salary during the few months of the year that the school could
be attended to in Atlin.

But I found conditions in Atlin in 1929 did not permit me to open
the school that year. The reason is that the Indians having been deprived
of their school for nineteen years - since I had left them in 1910 - they
had become so discouraged in their waiting that many of them had departed
from Atlin.

I have spent the four last summers in Atlin, with the result that
the natives are now hoping to see me again doing the good work which I did
from the year 1907 to 1910, have come back to Atlin and are expecting me to
teach their children during at least four months of the year.

Trusting this request will meet your approbation and that of my
old friends in the Department at Ottawa - I hope to remain for many years
to come a friendly collaborator of our Canadian Indian Department,

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Allard

Sir,

The Rev. Jos. Allard, O.M.I., who is a brother of the Rev. Father E. Allard of the Cassiar R.C. Mission, is in charge of the Atlin R.C. Mission located in Indian Town Atlin.

Practically all the Indians here belong to his Church, and as usual, a call is always paid the Rev. Father when this end of the Agency is visited.

Yesterday it was discovered he has started a small Mission Day School of his own, and has a Miss Conroy, whose parents live in the Town, in charge of same, and the children are receiving some benefit from the schooling.

Enclosed is submitted a letter received from the Rev. Father requesting aid for the school, and that he might be granted permission to take two of the children, i.e., Helen age 16 and Louis age 13 of the David Johnson Indian Family, to Skagway this winter for further schooling there, under the Sisters care.

The question of taking Canadian Indian Children to Skagway, S.F. Alaska, for schooling purposes, came up for attention last Fall, and the Rev. Father was instructed to obtain the Department's permission, ere such steps were taken, and this he seems to be now doing in the attached letter.

Therefore the matter is submitted for your consideration, as there will be no expense attached to these children going to Skagway perhaps it might be considered possible for them to be schooled at that point. The parents were interviewed, and they of course, were only too glad for their children to attend a school no further away than Skagway, and it is expected that if these children are allowed that privilege, other families will claim the same favour.

The new idea of using a local School mistress is very good, and his request of $100.00 for the year (summer) is reasonable.

May the Rev. Father be written to direct, as my visit to this end of the Agency is now drawing to a close, and there will not be time enough to receive your reply ere leaving.

I am,
Sir,

Your obedient servant,

"Harper Reed"

Allard, O.M.I., Atlin, B.C., for a grant toward the salary of a teacher to conduct a day school for the benefit of the Indians at Atlin. In this connection I now beg to transmit herewith copy of a letter received from Mr. Harper Reed, Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, Stikine Agency, dated July 20th, ultimo, the same being accompanied with original of a letter addressed to the Secretary, Indian Affairs, Canada, by Rev. Father Allard, this letter being sent herewith, and both communications will be self explanatory. Perhaps the Department would be kind enough to consider the representations made in these letters and advise me of its decision so that I may be in a position to reply to Mr. Agent Reed's communication. I may say that if it can be made possible I would like to support the effort which Father Allard is endeavoring to make in connection with his work in the Atlin district. The Department will be aware that there is very great demand for some progressive civilizing work in the northern part of British Columbia in the vicinity of the Yukon, particularly in the Stikine Agency, and I feel if at all possible we should do everything possible to encourage the promotion of organized life amongst the nomadic Indians of that northern territory, where conditions are anything but satisfactory. It is greatly to the credit of the Roman Catholic Church authorities that they are endeavoring to take hold of a very difficult situation in that area and I feel I should lend every reasonable support where the prospective work shows promise of success.

Dear Sir:

Father to refer them to the Agent first.

This expenditure was made and was necessary, and the two children mentioned are now in Lejac School, this being the nearest Catholic School to Atlin. The charge for expenses paid by Father Allard to the local school mistress is also quite in order, and the same was good and necessary work, as otherwise these children had no possible chance of any schooling, there being no room available at Lejac School for such numbers, and in addition the cost of sending them there would have been very high, there being so many.

The fare mentioned of the Atlin Girl, Nancy Johnson, from Juneau, was also a necessary expenditure as this girl's mother had deserted her husband and was in bad company at Juneau, and would probably have prostituted the girl. I therefore recommend that Father Allard be reimbursed in all three cases.

Yours truly,
