The Hon. the Super't General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,-

I have the honor to submit a brief statement of the educational needs of the Indians of Bella Bella, B.C., and to request the aid of the Government in meeting the same.

Bella Bella is an important point on the North West Coast of British Columbia, centrally located; population 319, with 52 children on the roll of the Day School — 26 boys and 26 girls. At certain seasons the attendance is good, but the work of the teacher is seriously handicapped by the frequent and prolonged absence of the children, who accompany their parents to the salmon fishing and other employments. In fact the Day School may be said to be in effective operation only about three months in the year.

Under these circumstances it is felt that the only way of dealing with the problem is by means of a Boarding School, where the children will be under continuous instruction for at least nine months in the year. I beg, therefore, to make respectful application for a grant of $3000 (three thousand dollars) toward the erection of a suitable building, and a further grant of $60 (sixty dollars) per capita for thirty pupils. As the case is an urgent one it is important that these amounts should be in the supplementary estimates to come before the ensuing Parliament.
I have been given to understand that Mr. Todd, the Indian Agent, will endorse a grant of $30. per capita from the Government and $30. per capita in provisions, etc., from the Indians; but I respectfully submit that this is an impossible proposition at Bella Bella, sandwiched in as it is between Metlakatla and Alert Bay, each with its $120 per capita, although the distance to either place is very considerable. I have elsewhere expressed the opinion that the Indians could be induced to contribute something in food and clothing toward the support of their children; but to lay so heavy a burden upon them at the start would defeat the very end we have in view.

This application will be forwarded by the Rev. Dr. Sutherland, General Secretary of Missions, with such endorsement as he may be disposed to give, and I trust it will receive the favorable consideration of the Superintendent General.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

(signed) Robert Whittington.
The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

The enclosed statement and request from the Rev. R. Whittington, D.D., Superintendent of Indian Missions in British Columbia, is respectfully commended to the favorable consideration of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Having had personal knowledge of condition of affairs at Bella Bella, and other points on the Coast, I can unhesitatingly endorse Dr. Whittington's statement as regards the inadequacy of Day School work, and the necessity which exists for a Boarding School to meet the needs of children of school age.

It will be seen that the amount asked for buildings is very moderate, and it may be supposed the building would be very inferior. I shall take the liberty, therefore, of submitting to the Department, in the course of a week or ten days, a suggested plan of a building to accommodate from 30 to 50 pupils, and hope it may meet with approval.

With the earnest hope that provision can be made in the present years' estimates for this urgently needed Boarding School.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

To the Honorable

Hon. Sir:

I have applied to the Honorable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, for a Boarding School Building Grant of $3,000.00 for Bella Bella, and for a further annual Grant of $80.00 per capita for 30 pupils.

Bella Bella is an important point, as you know; its population 310, with 53 children on the Day School roll. The Day School is efficient for not more than three months in the year, the children being compelled to accompany their parents in their hunting, fishing and berrying work the other nine months. The only solution of this problem is the establishment of a Boarding School to care for the children in the absence of the parents.

The Indian Agent (Mr. Todd) endorses this application to the extent of two-thirds of the building grant and 30 pupils at $80.00 or $2400.00.

There is no school of any kind at Bella Bella, as the Indians have moved from the old to the new village. The Day School Building Grant might be merged into the Boarding School Grant.

I respectfully request your valuable assistance in securing this grant and have it put into the supplementary estimates coming before the coming session of Parliament.

I am,

Yours obediently,

R. Whittington

Sir:

I have the honor to report that I have often been impressed with the thought that of all those who work for the betterment of the Indians, no one is doing a greater or more self-sacrificing work than the conscientious teacher of Indian schools.

While no one is likely to contradict a statement of this nature, it is nevertheless true that the compensation paid to teachers by church or state is less than what is paid to others.

The Bella Coola Agency is fortunate in its only school teachers; and of these I desire to bring to the attention of the Department Miss Kate Treiter of Bella Bella. For more than twenty years she has now labored in the schoolroom, and, I understand, that she besides is doing work as a field-nurse. If the Department could increase her salary to $60.00 per month or $720 per annum, I know that the recipient would be most deserving.

It may be in place, as a basis of comparison, to mention that here in Bella Coola are three public schools, whose average attendance is below 15 pupils; the Province pays each teacher at the rate of $80.00 per month or $960.00 per annum.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I sincerely appreciate your letter of September 22nd, containing extracts from the report of Inspector Barry on his visit to Kitamaat Residential School and the Bella Bella Day School.

With regard to Kitamaat: I understand from the Executive Secretary of the Woman's Missionary Society that a new Principal and a completely new staff have gone in there this fall and we may hope for much greater harmony in the work of the school.

As you are aware, the Woman's Missionary Society have hesitated to spend any large sum of money in repairs to this school as long as there was a possibility of a new Indian Residential School going up in Northern British Columbia. I feel certain, however, that they would be prepared to meet the Department half way in any expenditure on improvements which may be decided upon following Inspector Barry's reports of the last two years.

Re Bella Bella: I may say that I was in the village just three or four days before Inspector Barry's visit. I would like to have the privilege of discussing this case with Mr. Sutherland and yourself when I next visit Ottawa. I have been looking over my engagements and expect that I shall be in Ottawa sometime about the middle of November. I do not hesitate to say, however, that the report is extremely biased and that if Miss Green's work is as satisfactory and shows as much improvement in this academic year as it did in the last one, we certainly will not dismiss her in June, 1934.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth Beaton

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, ON HIS VISIT TO THE BELLA BELLA DAY SCHOOL, ON MAY 13th, LAST.

NAME: Miss Marjorie Green

HEALTH: Stated to be excellent. Seems to me to be suffering from strain now, and was in tears several times during my inspection.

SUCCESS: A complete failure in my opinion. The teacher has too many children to reach in the first place, and with only an Interim Second Class Certificate and no Summer School work, is in a very poor position to deal with what is admitted to be a very difficult situation.

I suggested to the teacher that she should attend the Indian and Rural Course as well as the Primary Course at this year's Provincial Summer School. This she did not do, and I now am given to understand that the local Missionary does not approve of my suggestion that this young teacher should attend a Summer Course. My advice, which is the same as that given by all School Inspectors in such cases, was given in the interest of the girl herself in order that she might have some chance of remaining in the teaching profession. As it is, I am not prepared to recommend her for her Permanent Certificate in this Province.

I must recommend a change of teacher here, the present teacher, Miss M. Green to be given plenty of notice that she will not be required after June, 1934. This girl belongs to the Young People's organizations, plays games, and teaches Sunday School, Etc. here, and is reported to me by the Missionary to be the best teacher they ever had. Unfortunately, she does not know how to teach Indians and has, from a professional point of view, been a complete failure here. The Missionary, Mr. Gibson, is now elderly and does not quite understand that we require in our schools. I would ask that the United Church Mission Officials, the Rev. Mr. Benton or other responsible person, be asked to nominate a teacher with the required qualifications to open school here in September, 1934.

Dear Mr. Fougner:

I am enclosing the report for March in order to get the quarter straightened out.

On Monday April 14th, I visited the school here and found an attendance of 26 pupils. I vaccinated 24 of them. The other two were successfully vaccinated last year. The general health was good. One child had discharging ears and three had hypertrophied tonsils. One child of school age is sick at home with pulmonary tuberculosis, following a severe attack of pneumonia. During the winter, she had a very severe attack of influenza. The children seem to appreciate their new teacher and are attending better than they have for a long time.

On February 29th, I visited the school at China Hat and examined 17 children present. The general health and condition of the children was good. One child had some eye trouble and is quite deaf. Several would be better for having their tonsils removed. One was suffering from tonsillitis at the time. Fred Brown, who was in the hospital so long is in fine shape. Every sinus has closed and his skin is quite whole. Benjamin Brown who went to Vancouver to have his foot straightened is in very good condition now. Polly Brown is in good condition. All the openings have healed but one gland has enlarged and will require treatment. Alice the oldest girl was married last winter and was away with her husband when I was there. I understand though that she is quite well. I am very much gratified to see such good results in these very difficult cases.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith the original of a duplicate letter received from Captain Gerald H. Barry, District Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., covering copies of correspondence had between himself and Miss Marjorie E. Green, teacher of the Indian Day School at Bella Bella in the Bella Coola Agency.

I shall be pleased to be advised if there is any question occurring to the Department in connection with this correspondence.

I may say it is my own view that where teachers located at remote schools in the province are required to attend Summer School, some provision should be made whereby at least a portion of their expenses should be covered by Departmental appropriation. I may say I am fully aware of the advantage to any teacher in attending the provincial Summer School at which a special course is given by our Inspector with the approval of the Department. There is no doubt that these courses have decided beneficial effect both on the teachers themselves as well as the pupils, but the cost of steamer transportation, room and board and other incidental expenses should not, in my opinion, be a burden of any teacher especially when he or she has giving up a portion of their vacation period which should be devoted to relaxation from teaching and other mental strain for which such vacation is undoubtedly designed.

Moreover the expenses of teachers from their homes to remote villages are not paid by the Department but from the salaries of the teachers which are not too high in any event. I am emphatically opposed to any measure of coercion in the matter of attendance of our Indian school teachers at Summer School unless financial provision is made to that end. Were such provision made, however, the Department would be in a better position to require its teachers to attend the Summer School.

I feel that Captain Barry is actuated by the sincerest motives to advance efficiency of our schools and teachers. However, I think that something should be done, if possible, to encourage attendance of teachers at Summer School under more favorable conditions than they are called upon to attend at the present time.

BELLA COOLA AGENCY REPORT FOR MONTH OF JUNE, 1936.

The Agent visited Bella Coola, Bella Bella, Klemtu and Kitimat Indian schools. The Bella Bella and Kitimat schools are overcrowded. Suggestions in this regard will be presented to the Department at a later date. I have not been able to make my usual monthly report on each school, as I did in the Queen Charlotte Agency, as there were no forms for that purpose in this office, and none have so far been received, although I requisitioned for a supply. Perhaps the Department does not require them in this Agency, as I understand that Mr. Founger did not send any in. The children in all the schools responded very well, and a great improvement was noted in the Bella Bella school, where on the Agent's first visit the children were evidently too bashful to answer questions. The attendance at all the schools dropped during June as the people began to leave for the various canneries.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Mrs. Brenda Campbell's letter of May 30th, 1939, requesting Residential School accommodation for various children of Bella Bella and expressing dissatisfaction with Miss Jessop, I enclose herewith a report on the subject by Mr. Inspector Barry, and would advise that some time ago the Department laid down a very definite principle that, where a Day School was in operation on an Indian Reserve, no Indian child within reasonable reach of same was to be admitted to a Residential School without first referring the applications to the Department and my understanding was that same would only be entertained under very unusual circumstances, in which it would have to be shown quite clearly that the child was likely to suffer morally or physically in its existing surroundings.

A little reflection will show that there are many Indian children remote from any educational centre and those most decidedly under-privileged, and it is the desire of the Department to preserve existing Residential School accommodation for them. Also it is my opinion that only a portion of a child's training can be carried out in a school and that, not the least important part of their upbringing, is that part played by the parents in training them at home out of school hours in the actual art of earning a livelihood according to the opportunities offered by the locality, and the loss of such training is extremely difficult to compensate in the best of Residential Schools.

I trust this will make my attitude clear in respect to this particular question.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read a letter from the parents of certain children at Bella Bella forwarded to you by Mr. Indian Agent Gillett under his 3758 of the 19th instant.

I may say that I believe that Inspector Coleman who spoke to me on this matter has taken some action.

In general I am aware that Mr. Indian Agent Gillett is in favour of sending children to Indian Residential Schools even when home conditions are good and there is a day school on the Indian Reserve. I have explained the policy of the Department to him a number of times, but he appears very loath to accept my own suggestions.

I understand that St. Michael's Indian Residential School has a long waiting list. The homes at Bella Bella are in the main quite good. There may be some orphans who should go to residential schools, but those with good homes should certainly attend the new Indian Day School at Bella Bella.

The people at Bella Bella are members of the United Church of Canada. The parents however do not care for Coqualeetza School and would much prefer to send their children to St. Michael's Alert Bay, an Anglican school.

The question of the ability of the present teacher of the Bella Bella Indian Day School has been reported on previously, in April 1938 and again in September of the same year. Miss Jessop has a rather weak personality, but is an experienced teacher. She holds good qualifications, and should certainly not be deprived of her school because some parents wish to have the Department look after the children for them. My suggestion is that the Department should establish a Home School or small Residential School in the village for pupils over 10 years of age is ridiculous.

The new school at Bella Bella will be inspected in due course in late September of this year. I understand that the junior teacher Miss E. Allen has resigned to be married. If there is a vacancy, may I suggest that Miss Jessop take the Primary Division and the new teacher to be selected take charge of the Senior Division. Only an experienced and well qualified teacher should be sent to Bella Bella.

As Mr. Indian Agent Gillett is now in charge of the Skeena River Agency I feel that it is essential that he should be informed in clear language of the Department's decision to educate the Indian children in Indian Day Schools except where there is a clear reason for them to be sent to a Residential School. In the case of orphans, those with unsuitable home conditions, either through overcrowding, immoral surroundings, those who have done too well at day school, they should have a chance to take Junior High School and a few other special cases, the residential school is an greatly increased cost to the Department is no doubt justified, but in the majority of cases the sending of children to residential schools when the parents can easily support them is a great mistake.

Yours very truly,

Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Mr. Indian Agent Christie's letter 64/7170 of October 24th regarding the overcrowding at the Bella Bella Indian Day School, I may say that I can see no prospect whatever of securing a third teacher, even should the Department sanction the establishment of a third division at this school.

The Bella Bella Indian Day School is carried on under the auspices of the United Church of Canada who, so far, have been unable to secure a second teacher for the Kispiox Indian Day School.

The figures given by Miss How, Principal of the Bella Bella Indian Day School, and by Mr. Christie, are somewhat difficult to understand and I may say that from my experience of the Bella Bella Day School the average attendance is considerably below the number enrolled.

For some time when there was only one class room at Bella Bella, the children were educated on the half day system. The Indian parents somewhat resented this and on the erection of the new Day School, the children were, of course, placed on full time.

I am unable to support the suggestion of Miss How that the congestion in the senior room should be alleviated by placing Grade 2 and 3 pupils on the half day system and I would recommend to the Department the following solution of the difficulty:

The Grade 2 pupils, some twenty odd in number, should be removed from the senior room and enrolled in the junior division. The junior room would therefore become, for some months in the year, overcrowded, the attendance falling away, no doubt, fairly rapidly in the late spring.

Should the average attendance of Grade 1 and 2 pupils in the junior room exceed thirty-five, I would suggest that the
children in this junior division be placed on the half day system as a purely temporary measure until the average attendance again decreased to around thirty-five.

In conclusion I would recommend that the approval of the Department be sought for the putting into effect of the above plan.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

Left for Bella Bella next morning, and visited the two class rooms in the school, and found a good attendance, with the children looking healthy and clean, also the school rooms were in very good order. Visited the hospital, and conferred with the medical Supt. Dr. Darby, on various matters pertaining to the Indian patients in the hospital.

Found the school without water, and made arrangements to have the pipe line checked for leaks, and left at 12.15 for Klemtu, arriving there in a heavy S.E. Gale. Visited School teacher, and the School, and I certainly was amazed at how he had been able to carry on with the stove in the condition it was. The whole top of the fire box was burnt and rusted away, and there were holes through it at all points, so it was a wonder that the school had not been burnt down.

The new stove, and coal had not arrived there at this time, but on my return from the north, I found a New stove and pipes installed, but still no coal, so the teacher had ordered some wood cut and delivered, but this was green and full of salt water, so it had to be cut into kindling wood before it would burn.

Schools; Day.

All schools in operation were visited and inspected. It is a shame that no teachers are available for Kitammat and Bella Coola. Attendance at Bella Bella is fairly good, but I am afraid that after the new year, it will take a slump as many of these people are due to go to Nama Cannery for work. The school at Bella Coola is overcrowded. Repairs have been done at Klemtu and the building at least looks clean inside. It will last until better days come and a proper unit can be put up, with teachers quarters attached. It is suggested that at Kitammat a local Indian with Grade XI standing be appointed interim teacher, to get one room going at least. He seems a fine kind of young man, and he could not be any worse than some white interim or temporary appointments at present in action.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1943.

Schools;

Day schools at Bella Coola, Klemtu, Bella Bella (2 division and the empty schoolhouse at Kitamaat were all carefully inspected. Attendance is not satisfactory at all; Klemtu and Bella Coola have most unsuitable persons as teachers; and the closing of the latter school has been recommended. I am afraid that the School at Bella Bella will suffer a serious attendance lapse. War services take men and women in a wholesale manner from the villages winter as well as summer, and if the war goes on much longer, the entire social economy of these Indians will require serious review. In the old days there were at least six months in which the parents would be home; today in some villages, they are home for two weeks at Xmas or for a wedding or funeral; and children by the score are not attending school at all. It is very moot point in my opinion, as to whether home life in Indian villages will ever return to its former status, and I foresee the possibility of "ghost Villages" not long hence. Just where Councils will fit in to the picture of the future is a baffling problem, and future objectives along these lines will need careful study.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

MARCH QUARTER REPORT

At Bella Bella attendance is good and progress is evident, especially since Christmas when a change of teacher was made in the senior classroom. The enrollment in this village calls for a third classroom next fall and a fourth if children of six years were admitted to school as it is considered they must if Indian children are ever to overcome the age differential of four years noticeable between them and the non-Indian school pupils of the Province.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Dept. Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to yours of March 22nd, file 80-162, please be advised that the Bella Bella Indian Day School is situated on Campbell Island, which is the post office for this village.

From the time of Inspector G. H. Barry, pupils of this Day School have been discharged at the close of term nearest their fifteenth birthday. Miss Phillips, Principal of the school informs me that the Inspector ordered this action to prevent overcrowding, and as the school is still overcrowded the policy has been continued.

For many years this village (second largest in B.C.) has operated with a village council and it is presumed that the Indian Act, Section 185 f. was applied to school attendance. Actually, the village was still under Part I though tacit recognition was given to the Council by the Department.

In the Bella Bella band located on Campbell Island, B.C., there are one hundred forty children of school age (Ind. Act 10.1) as at March 31st, 1946. Of this number, thirty-six are pupils in Residential Schools at Alert Bay and Alberni, leaving an actual school population of one hundred four to be handled by two teachers in a two room school. To ease the situation, children of fifteen years and up have been discharged from school and my letter of March 13th was directed to the Department to clarify the situation and get a definite ruling as to whether or not these children are to be cut off or kept on Family Allowance payments. I do not see why they should be cut off if the teacher, on orders of the Department's Inspector, discharged them from school, but as it is a matter effecting both the Indian Act and the Family Allowance Act, it is considered a ruling should be given.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Since taking over the Bella Coola Agency a careful study of the educational needs and facilities therefore in our Day Schools has been made, with particular attention directed to ascertaining the causes underlying the retardation noticeable in practically all the Day Schools. Irregular attendance is admittedly one of the chief causes of retardation, but this does not answer the problem by any means.

We find generally that Indian children take from two to four years to get through Grade I and into Grade II, by which time they are retarded an average of four years. The age norm for Grade II in Indian schools is eleven years, in non-Indian schools seven years; a differential of four years, increasing rather than decreasing as the average Indian child goes on through the grades.

In my opinion, speaking from a fairly long experience in Indian education, an essential step in any effort to reduce this age differential is to lower the compulsory school admission age for Indian children to six years from the present seven; vide Indian Act 10.1. It is true that under Section 185.f Indian children of families operating under Part II of the Act may start school at six years, but few if any bands in Bella Coola operate under this Section.

It may also be said that Section 10.1 does not bar Indian children of six years from attending school, in practice however it does. Most of our Indian schools are overcrowded and few of our teachers permit Indian children to register before attaining their seventh birthday. A child of six years is more adaptable to primary education than a child of seven. The courses of study are based on the minimum age for non-Indian children, and it is my conviction that six year old Indian children would do better in Grade I than would seven year old youngsters with wider life experience but less training in the use and purpose of such experiences.

I would like to see an experiment made in this matter and would select Bella Bella for such an experiment. There we have a two room school. The basements could be floored and adapted to the higher grades and a classroom made available for six year olds, of whom there would be enough to form a class.

In Bella Bella we have an outstanding teacher for such an experiment in the person of Miss E. M. Phillips with whom I have discussed this matter at length. I believe she would take such a class and I also believe the parents would support this venture if it were put up to them properly. The results might be of very real value to the Department, and the children would certainly gain by such an experiment.

Would you put this matter before the Department for consideration and if they are interested, I would be pleased to go into a great deal more detail.
At Bella Bella the experiment would require (a) another teacher and salary at $1,000.00; the lining and equipping of another classroom, say $350.00 and school supplies for same. Present day trends among non-Indian children indicate a growth of kindergarten schooling in five year olds in even kindergarten age. An earlier start in regular school life among Indians is urgently needed and would, I believe, remove many of the difficulties faced in trying to keep the interest of the older children in the higher grades.

I am convinced that the chief reason that Indian children do not enjoy school or studies is that they are out of their element. By no stretch of imagination could a white boy of twelve retain interest in the course material of Grade III, and neither can Indians.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
With reference to your letters of the 6th and 10th instant requesting authorization for extension of the enrollment of pupils at the Bella Bella Indian Day School to include a pre-school class of six-year-old children and some primary repeaters, at an estimated cost of adopting one of the existing semi-basement classrooms of about $350.00 and the salary of an additional teacher, I would advise that such applications should include a school survey of the Band showing those of school age and pre-school age.

Miss Phillips, the teacher, called here just as I was writing the Department in the matter and informed me that the proposed class would not be a pre-school project but would deal entirely with those of school age in the primary group and if such is the case we should certainly have a definite survey showing why this group cannot be provided for by the primary teacher as at present we have no actual figures before us, your letters being in quite general terms.

In discussing the question of pre-school education you touched on a subject giving us considerable concern and one that we hoped would be fully explored by an Indian School Inspector. There are, no doubt, a number of factors contributing to the general retardation of Indian children and their consequent failure to keep pace with the white schools, including indifferent attendance, which again might result from lack of interest due to the length of time spent on primary work. I am satisfied that the Indian intelligence quotient is comparable with that of white children, particularly if the environmental and language factors are considered, but as the standard tests such as the Stanford-Binet are not applicable owing to the language problem, and those that are such as the Rutter-Intonson Performance Scale are not familiar to our teachers we appear to still lack the essential data on which to base an opinion.

If you wish to pursue the question of the pre-school
class further I would request your report giving fairly close detail as to the expected attendance. You should also deal with the problem of the accommodation of any additional teachers required.

Indian School Grading in General

If the standing of Indian children is to be equalized with that of white children from Grade II and up, (taking into account that the Indian children begin school at seven years and are in Grade I for two years) then, of necessity, somewhere from Gr.II-VI (or up) an Indian child will have to cover 4 years work in 2 years.

In a small percentage of cases where the child's attendance and ability are very good, and in cases in which the teacher knows the child (his ability and willingness to go ahead) from having already taught him and observed him. It is possible for the teacher to work that child up to a white school grading.

But, in class rooms in which teachers are new each year and especially those in which the teachers are new to Indian school teaching it is not to be expected that the children can accomplish more than one grade per year (this is not expected of white children) especially when a classroom is overcrowded (or in the other extreme when a child is "out" of school, getting native foods, or sick, or for other reasons).

The language difficulty has to be continually taken in to account.
If each grade, from II/VI requires one year's attendance and work, then the two years must be cut down before Grade II is reached.

If a preparatory class were introduced for six year olds and five year olds, to be a one year course or two, then a child would be prepared to enter the formal teaching of the primary room (i.e., to deal with the printed English word) at the age of 6 (or even 7) and to cover Grade I (B and A) in one year because the socialized atmosphere of the "kindergarten" class would build up a knowledge of English required as a basis for IB work, which a very small percentage of Bella Bella children possess upon entering school at present in ID. (I made a survey for Inspector Thorsteinsson on the total English vocabulary of children entering school and it was surprisingly low.)

Present desk capacity is thirty-five in the senior room and thirty-five in the Junior room, and average attendance of 75% will keep both rooms filled. Present attendance trends are upward and a third classroom is indicated for Alert Bay by 1947 at the latest. One of the basements will have to be tiled and floored and an oil heater put in as the furnace will not take adequate care of the heating of this room. New blackboards and primary tables and seats will be needed as well as cupboards, teacher's desk, etc.

It is possible that the teacher could be accommodated in the Nurses' Home and students are being directed to this end. If so, rental would be charged and an adjustment in salary required. She could board either with the other teachers or at the Hospital.

It is recommended that the additional room when sanctioned be used as a Primary Classroom limited to twenty-five pupils.

An alternative scheme to using the basement room would be the rental of the Band Hall from the Council for a period of two years or until materials are in good supply. To put a primary room in this Hall would only require blackboards, teacher's desk and chair, tables and seats for children (to be made like those in the primary room at Alert Bay Residential School) and fuel, in addition to teacher's and janitor's wages. I am uncertain as to rental etc. and will report later. If this room could be secured for this fall, I would recommend this be accepted and converted to a classroom at once.

I am forwarding herewith for your information a copy of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letters of April 8th and May 8th in connection with the proposed extension of the enrolment of pupils at the Bella Bella Indian Day School, together with a copy of my letter of April 20th in this connection to the agent.

It will be noted that Mr. Anfield in his letter of May 8th recommends that the proposed plan involving the admission of six year old Indian children be deferred until the new agent has been appointed and also gives further information which indicates that it will be necessary to provide a third classroom at Bella Bella this year. The agent's comments with respect to this third classroom are somewhat ambiguous, but he apparently intends to make enquiries as to the possibility of securing, on a rental basis, the use of the Band Hall for a period of two years, or if funds and material can be secured, for the construction and equipping of the third classroom in the basement of the present school. Nothing further can be done in this matter until we hear from Mr. Anfield whether or not the Council will be prepared to rent the Band Hall, but in the meantime it would appreciated if the Department would advise if funds could be made available for payment of salary for a third teacher and for equipping and operating a third classroom.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The teacher was found to be in a state of extreme mental tension. She accused the Principal, Miss E. Phillips, of attempted assault on her person in the teacherage at night, and showed me several highly irrational letters written by her prior to lawyers in Vancouver. A careful check was made with Dr. Darby and the Matron of the Hospital as to condition between the two teachers. As Mrs. Macdonald was anxious to leave as soon as possible and having in mind a letter to her from the United Church Mission Supt., and shown to me by Mrs. Macdonald which letter informed her that she would not be returning to this School for further employment, I accepted a written resignation from Mrs. Macdonald, effective this date, and gave her permission to leave immediately. I called the pupils of the senior room and informed them the senior room was closed for the term as from this date.

It is recommended that the resignation be accepted and Mrs. Macdonald paid for only two-thirds of the month of June. The resignation is attached herewith.

MEMORANDUM TO: Major D. M. MacKay - Indian Commissioner
FROM: R. F. Davey - Inspector of Indian Schools

Miss E. M. Phillips, Junior Room teacher at the Bella Bella School called at this office on January 2nd and requested that an increase in her salary be considered.

In estimating Miss Phillips' present salary an allowance of $20.00 per month should be made for her share of the living accommodation, heat, and light which are provided for the two teachers at this school. This amount with her basic salary of $125.00 per month is the equivalent of $145.00 per month. Miss Phillips has nine years teaching experience in Indian schools and holds a Permanent First Class teaching certificate for British Columbia and has attended summer courses in Primary Work and Rural Schools. The Basic Salary Schedule for the Province places her maximum at $1650.

The reports on her work by Captain Barry, Mr. Anfield and Mr. B. Thorsteinsson have all rated her work as being very good. Mr. Thorsteinsson considered her "outstanding". He thought so highly of her work he recommended that she visit other Indian schools with the object of her assisting new or inexperienced teachers.

In view of these facts I recommend that consideration be given to increasing Miss Phillips' basic salary to $145.00 per month.

R.F. Davey

Education:

This agency has not yet reached the stage where school facilities are available to all of the children. However, those schools that are available are showing good progress. In one village a two roomed school has been staffed during the past quarter with two teachers who are members of the local Indian Band. The Principal, who is fully qualified from the Provincial Normal School, is doing an especially fine job of teaching. All the while he is foregoing offers of administrative work with the canning companies at salaries running to three times what he is paid as a teacher. This year there are six students from this agency applying for Tuition Grants for aid in attending High School during the next term.

Extract from the Quarterly Report of the Superintendent,
Bella Coola Agency for the period April, May and June 1949.

Education

Attendance at Day Schools while dropping off somewhat is much improved over former years. The school age population of the Agency is 468. There is normal Day School capacity for 150 with an additional 30 accommodated in a rented building. It is anticipated that about 97 pupils in all can be placed in Residential schools next term, about ten under age 16 may attend Provincial schools. This will leave about 151 children in the Agency for whom no educational provision is being made. The need is greatest at Bella Bella where a two roomed school is now several years overdue. The need has grown to the point where a new four-room school unit will soon be needed. Two additional rooms are needed at Kitsamant and an additional room has long been needed at Bella Coola. This latter will still be needed in spite of the fact that a few children have been accepted at the Provincial school. I am advised by School Board that space is available only in the senior grades and there are about 70 native children who must be provided for at Bella Coola under grade six. Cooperation between Indian schools and White schools at Bella Coola has been good. The native children were invited to participate in the Boys and Girls Fair, both in Bella Coola and Ocean Falls. At both points a very satisfactory number of prizes were won by the native children. At the Ocean Falls Fair, a Bella Coola native boy aged 12 was tied with a white boy for the highest aggregate score for the Fair. He won prizes in drawing, two in handicrafts and two in athletics. The native children were notably successful in arts and handicrafts.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant informing the Department of the resignation on account of ill health of Miss Lillian Shore, teacher of the Bella Bella Indian Day School, to take effect on the 18th instant.

In reply I beg to say that the resignation of Miss Shore is accepted. The Department regrets that it is necessary for her to give up her duties.

You may make temporary arrangements for the continuing of the work at this school until such time as the Department receives the nomination of a teacher from the Church authorities. We note that you may be able to obtain the services of a son of the missionary. If so, his services would be satisfactory until the Church authorities can appoint a teacher. We are taking this matter up with the Church authorities and as soon as we receive their nomination you will be advised.

Please inform the Department as to the arrangements you have made, giving the name of the substitute teacher secured by you and the qualifications possessed.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 25th, 1930.

Reverend Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 22nd instant regarding the salary of the teacher at the Bella Bella Indian Day School, I beg to say that the return received from this school showed that the teacher began duties on September 15th and, therefore, one-half month's salary was allowed.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have your favour of the 25th instant (No. 162-3-3) containing the statement that the teacher of the Bella Bella Indian Day School began her duties on Sept. 15th instead of on the 1st, hence the allowance of only one half month's salary.

In reply would say that the statement is quite correct, but I would bring to the attention of the Department the fact as I am advised that the Indians and their families did not return from the canneries till about the middle of September and the School at Bella Bella could not be opened until then for lack of pupils. The teacher was on the ground by the first of the month and ready to open the School. I may further state that we have paid the teacher her salary for the full month as agreed and would, therefore, ask the Department in view of the circumstances to reimburse the Home Mission Board for her salary for the first half of the month of September.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Ottawa, June 13, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada have arranged for the transfer of Miss M. Gingrich, at present senior teacher at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School, to take up duties as teacher at the Bella Bella Indian Day School for the coming academic year. The Department is approving of this proposed transfer and will allow Miss Gingrich salary at the rate of $105 per teaching month - the same rate as she is at present receiving at Fort Simpson. I have to request that, when Miss Gingrich takes up duties at Bella Bella, you will give her every assistance you can in her work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, September 12, 1931.

Sir:

I have to request that you will give Miss Green any assistance you can in her work at this school, where it is hoped she will meet with every success.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Mrs. Berger:

This is in reply to your letter of February 25, 1970 which was forwarded to us from the Regional Personnel Adviser for B.C.

The Civil Service Superannuation Act became effective in 1924. Teachers were not eligible to contribute to it and consequently were not entitled to a pension on retirement. Since 1947 teachers who held a permanent teaching Certificate and who had at least two years successful teaching experience were allowed to apply for permanent status and be designated as permanent employees for purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act. With the coming into force of the Public Service Superannuation Act on January 1, 1954, all teachers employed on a full-time basis are eligible to contribute to the Public Service Superannuation Fund.

I hope the above information will prove satisfactory to you.

July 10th 1899

Mr. Vowell,
Supt. Indian Affairs
Victoria B.C.

Dear Sir,

You are aware of the fact that the Bella Bella Indians are moving from their present village to a new site two miles further north. This move has been undertaken after much deliberation and was necessitated by the increasing population of the tribe, the limited space on the old site preventing proper sanitary arrangements and therefore harbouring disease and hence the land available to enlarge the old village site was held by a white man who put such an exorbitant price on the property that the Indians could not consider its purchase. The new village site is an excellent piece of ground and is quite adapted to the growing needs of the Indians.

About twelve new homes have been erected and a substantial wharf built and if the fishing season turns out a financial success the greater number of the people should move this fall.

The Methodist Church will be forced to build a new house for the Medical Missionary at the new site and will also have to rebuild the church. This will entail considerable expense.

It is felt that, under the circumstances, the...
the Government should be applied to in reference to a grant for a new day school. The attendance at the school is increasing and as there are now nearly sixty children of school age on the reservation and every prospect that this number will be increased in the near future, a substantial building should be erected properly equipped to meet the growing needs of the place for some time to come.

The Missionary Society of the Methodist Church will have to improve the character of their buildings at the new town and the expense to them will be great as it is.

The Indians are not in a position to do the work unassisted as they are taxing their finances to the utmost limit in trying to improve the character of their new dwellings.

The new town when completed will be a credit to the Coast and we would make request that a grant of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) be made by the Government to erect a school which will be in keeping with the needs and conditions of the case.

Yours respectfully,

Signed: R.H. Large M.T.
Medical Missionary
Sir,

I have the honour to forward herein in duplicate an application in behalf of the Bella Bella Indians from the Reverend Mr. George M.R. Missionary at the settlement. He much needed help toward the erection of a school house at their new village site. It now seems quite evident that these Indians are moving their village to the new location. To them this is an enormous undertaking and shows their determination to better the condition of themselves, and more especially their children and future generations.

It is an enterprise that will tax their best energies for several years to come. I think however that in the nature of things the whole population will not have left the old village for several years yet but that the majority of families will do so within two years time. I believe therefore a less extensive school building than that contemplated by Mr. George would suffice at first; that a five hundred dollar school building be erected at the new town as soon as may be under conditions which would admit of its enlargement afterwards so as to accommodate the children of the whole population.

In behalf of the Bella Bella Indian band I would respectfully suggest an appropriation of five hundred dollars for school purposes.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A.W. Vowell Esquire
Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr. Vowell,

In reply to your communication of June 26th referring to the Bella Bella School building. I was informed by Mr. Agent Todd by letter which I received June 8th that a grant of £400.00 had been made by the Dominion Government towards the new School at Bella Bella & that all Vouchers for material, labor etc should be forwarded to him so that they might be in by June 30th. I am sorry that I have not been able to do this, much as I desired it. I left Bella Bella for Rivers Inlet about the end of May so that Mr. Todd's letter came to me after I had left Bella Bella.

I could not go down to Victoria to purchase the materials as I was very busy with Hospital work besides the same boat on which the letter came brought the report of the outbreak of smallpox at Nass River & from that time to the present I have been kept so busy with caring for the sick, vaccinating the Indians and other duties that I have had to leave such necessary work undone. I thought it unwise to order materials to be shipped to Bella Bella to lie on a wharf, that has not as yet even a freight shed, for over two months.

The Indians were all leaving for the Canning centres and I could not get any one to work at the building nor...
nor could I go to superintend the erection myself, so that
the materials would have remained on the wharf till my
return about the latter end of August, exposed to the
weather & to the pilfering of any chance wayfarer.

Mr. Todd kindly purchased some of the rough lumber
but I wrote to him that it would be impossible for me
to make the other purchases within the prescribed time
limit.

I very much regret the inconvenience to your
Department that this course will occasion, but it was
impossible for me in the limited time given to do any
thing different.

I sincerely hope that the facts above stated will
permit of the grant being at our disposal by the end
of August when I will have returned to Bella Bella, &
will then be able to order materials and superintend
the erection of the building.

Yours Truly,

R.W. Large.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Secretary:

It is to be regretted that the grant for the Bella-Bella School for building purposes was allowed to lapse. From a perusal of Mr. Vowell's letter of the 7th instant one would form the impression which, of course, it may not be intended to convey, that it was through some fault of the Department that Dr. Large was not able to use the grant. I think it best, therefore, to point out that so far as Mr. Vowell and those interested in the Bella-Bella School are concerned the amount has been available since May 28th, 1900.

This item was included in the main Estimates for 1900-01, and was shown in the detail of the day school vote. Mr. Vowell acknowledged the receipt of the detailed Estimates on the 28th May, 1900, therefore, the whole summer of 1900 went by without any action being taken. Mr. Vowell states that our letter of the 15th May last was the first intimation that Dr. Large had that the amount of the grant should be used for the construction of the school at the new town site. This seems very strange because in the manuscript Estimates which Mr. Vowell forwarded on the 14th Nov. 1899 he pointed out in asking for this grant of $400.00, that the building was to be at the new village site. Sir,

I have to report that the Indian Village at [redacted] was visited on March 20th. The day school here is kept in an old building, rented by the church. The Indians have been here for years, and the roof is leaking. The size of the school room is about 12 x 15 ft., containing 30 sq. ft. rooms, with doors for the boys' and girls' rooms. The number of children attending school are in the vicinity that the Indians attend residential schools.

It will thus be seen that the school room is too small, there being not enough seats, and too many children for one teacher to educate properly. Two or three new pupils are expected next year, and the tax going out.

To remedy these conditions it is recommended that a new two-roomed school building be erected, with new windows and shutters, so that a teacher can teach on one side and a child on the other, from October to March (final) sufficient shelter of desks should also be provided.

As last year's expenses is placed the sum of $600.00 for a new day school with teacher's residence at [redacted]. The day school building has to be done, though ready enough for the purpose, but is not suitable. The teacher is doing another living in the mission house. If the church intends to keep this up there is no such great need for a teacher's residence.

In view of what is stated above, and the fact that it is now so difficult to keep a teacher, the relief work is greatly needed. The Indians are in need of the work; I am sure they would be glad to be employed. New day school building will be built on [redacted] along the road, and the combined cost may not exceed the sum of $600.00.

Copy of this letter is being sent to Capt. [redacted], Inspector of Indian schools, for his attention and observation.

Ottawa, January 13, 1934.

Sir:

I have your telegram of yesterday's date, reporting the damage incurred by heavy snow to the woodshed at the Bella Bella Indian Day School and requesting authority to rebuild, at a cost of approximately $50.

Our appropriation for unforeseen expenditures during the balance of the present fiscal year is extremely limited. It is considered that the teacher or yourself should have foreseen the danger of the building collapsing from the weight of the snow and arranged to have same removed. At other schools, this work is considered part of the janitor's duties; but, as the teacher at this school is paid for janitor services, it is thought that she could have arranged to have the older boys or Indians remove the snow.

As it appears, from your telegram, that the rebuilding of the woodshed is necessary, you may include an expenditure not exceeding the sum of approximately $50 in the purchase of the material required and the labour in carrying out the work, at as early a date as weather conditions permit. Any materials required should be purchased from a firm on the list to receive consideration, and the labour, as far as possible, should be performed by Indians. After the work has been completed, please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, in the usual manner, covering the expenditure incurred. The Department would request that the accounts be received before our books close at the end of the present fiscal year, viz.: March 31st, next.

I would request, further, that you give attention to the removing of snow from the roofs of any of the school buildings where damage is likely to occur and arrange to have this work done.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Fougner:

I would be very grateful if you could arrange with the Department to have the Bella Coola Indian Day School provided with suitable lighting as I find that under the present half-day system the schoolwork extends into the late afternoon at which time the school becomes too dark to carry on the work.

As my reports show, I have seventy pupils enrolled who attend fairly regularly during the winter months. As I can only seat thirty-six at a time it is necessary to take half of the class in the morning and half in the afternoon. By three o'clock it is dark, giving the higher grades only two to three hours schooling each day.

An electric lighting system could be installed from the hospital engine for ten dollars ($10) and the cost per year for upkeep would be fifteen dollars ($15). It would mean a lot to the older children who are quite bright and who would then be able to have an extra hour each afternoon.

As an alternative, two gas lamps could be purchased at about fifteen dollars ($15) and there would be the extra cost of generator, gas, matches, etc. This would not be as safe an electric light, nor as convenient, and for the longer run would probably come to about the same expense. However, we would be glad to have either one if the Department will supervise it.

This suggestion has been approved by the Acting Commissioner, Mr. J. C. Terry, and by Captain O. H. Berry, Inspector of Indian Schools.

Hoping that this letter will receive your early consideration,

Yours respectfully,

(Miss) Florence Levy

Dear Sir,-

Regarding Day School at Bella Bella,

As I understand that the building of a two room school has been recommended to the Department, I would like to state that I am very much in favor of such a thing and I hope that it will be possible for the Department to go ahead with it in the near future.

Having been here for twenty one years, I feel that I know local conditions and that with the limited opportunities for employment away from the village, that the people will be just as much at home in the future as they have been for the last few years. Some time ago, the attendance was very poor during most of the school year because the people were away from home. Now, as has no doubt been self evident, the children have been attending very well, and are increasing in numbers so that only a portion of them can be accommodated in the present school and the teacher has had to have half day classes.

This of course cuts down the chance each child has to get ahead, and with the shortened term due to late return from the canneries etc., the child cannot advance as rapidly as he should. In addition, there is the extra strain on the teacher of having to handle approximately twice as many different children each day, as she would have with one lot only.

Thanking you for your consideration and for forwarding this to the proper authorities, I am

Yours faithfully,

Sir:

I beg to report that in former years when Indians were often employed at work away from their reserves they generally took their families with them. The result was that the day schools were poorly attended, and there was ample room for the children in the villages where Indians stay in their villages for want of employment outside, with the result that the children attend the day schools, and there is not room for them all. This will likely also apply to the future.

Bella Bella has an Indian population of over 400; the pupils on the register of the day school were, last quarter, 35. The school building here is old, and so small that some of the children attended in the forenoon, and the others in the afternoon. A great number of the children of this village are also at the residential school at Alert Bay.

A new two-room school building is required in this village. The old building could be used as a playroom during recesses in rainy weather. The cost of a suitable building, with a wood-shed, should be about $800.00. I inclose letter on this subject from Dr. C. J. Darby, Superintendent of the hospital at Bella Bella.

Yours obediently,

Sir:

With reference to letter No. 162-3-5, dated July 3, 1935, I beg to remind the Department of the need of a new two-roomed day school at Bella Bella. The present building, built before my time in office, some 30 or forty years ago, by the Church authorities, is too small to accommodate all the pupils; and the number is too great for one teacher to handle. Last quarter the enrollment was 62, average attendance, 50. The number will increase in the future. A large number of children from this village are in residential schools.

In this year's Estimates I placed the sum of $3500.00 for the purpose of erecting a two-roomed school at Bella Bella. Indians could do the work under a white foreman, when they are not fishing at the canneries. The main fishing season takes in the months of July & August. Two outhouses, and a shed for wood and coal would also be required.

The school is a very old building and will need to be replaced just as soon as funds can be provided for this purpose.

It is proposed I understand to use an Indian Band Hall as a second schoolroom for the SENIOR PUPILS. The Indian Agent has shown me this Hall, and I am prepared to recommend that the Indian Agent's plans be sanctioned.

The Hall in question is about 36 ft. by 26 ft. There are ten windows well set up on the floor. The sides inside are lined with shiplap, and the floor is good. The ceiling is high being 13 ft. above and 15 ft. to the top of the covered part.

Two toilets and a washshed will be required and these are estimated by the Indians to cost the sum of $30.00. A new circulatory heater to burn wood is necessary now in the present school, but if the suggested plan of renting a Hall is carried out a second circulatory heater will be required. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of June 28th, I beg to report as follows.

There are approximately seventy-five children of school age at Bella Bella. There were sixty-three on the roll last year. It is possible that six or seven of these will be transferred to St. Michael's School at Alert Bay, but there will be at least fifteen beginners.

As the school is on the half day system at present, progress is anything but satisfactory. I have visited this school each month and there has been very little progress shown. As the Department could not see its way to building a new two-room school this year, I recommend that a building belonging to the village Band be rented and used as an additional school room. The extra expense, apart from the teacher's salary and cost of desks, will be as follows:

- Rental of building, 6 months @ $10.00...$60.00
- Blackboard, axe, chair, table etc.............$5.00
- Heating stove.................................$5.00
- Firewood, 6 cords @ $10.00..................$60.00
- Erection of woodshed and toilets.............$50.00

I would suggest that the second teacher be engaged for nine months only, beginning in October, owing to the fact that a number of the children will not be in the village until that time.

In my letter of August 4th last, when I made recommendations similar to the above, the rental of the building was given as $5.00 per month, and the Indians were then willing to erect the building free of charge. This year, however, they could not get the same terms. The reason for the change may be that a new committee is looking after the building, and I insisted on some improvements on the building. I consider that ten dollars a month is a reasonable charge. It is understood that all furnishings, including blackboard etc., will be transferred to the new school when built.

Dear Sir,-

Re: Proposed two-room school, Bella Bella.

Your Letter No. 162-3-5, Oct. 18th.

I submit the following information and recommendations, answering questions as numbered in your letter.

(1) Provision should be made for seventy-five children.

(2) Site approximately 120 ft. by 120 ft. (larger if necessary) available without having to be purchased. Land is two feet above solid rock, fairly level. It will cost about one hundred fifty dollars to clear land of trees and stumps and do some blasting to make it level. Building should face east.

(3) It would be advisable to provide living quarters for the teachers, attached to the south end of the building.

(4) Drinking water can be obtained from the village main. Approximately 500 feet of pipe will be required.

(5) I would recommend construction by day labour, with a white foreman and Indian carpenters.

(6) I would suggest a full cement basement above ground level. If an opening is left unsealed, about twenty feet or more it would provide a place for the children to play in wet weather. A rough sketch is enclosed.

I would suggest that a large cupboard be built in each classroom for books and supplies. Two cloakrooms should be provided with a wash basin in each.

A belfry is necessary. The bell can be taken from the old school.

Two outside toilets will be required, for the school, and one for the teachers' residence.

The teachers' quarters should contain a kitchen, living-room and two bedrooms, also bathroom.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39, provision is being made for an amount of $9,000 in the construction of a new day school on the Bella Coola Reserve, Bella Coola Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia.

2. In addition it will be necessary to provide living quarters for the teachers. As there will be two teachers in charge of this school, two bedrooms will be necessary.

6. The water can be obtained from the water main in Bella Coola Village; approximately 500 feet of pipe will be necessary to pipe water to the school. A sink and pump should be installed in the school.

I would appreciate your submitting for my consideration a sketch plan of a building that you consider would be suitable.

I am forwarding herewith a set of blueprints in duplicate of revised sketch plans of the above building.

Director.
Dear Sir,

Kindly advise if it is the intention of the Department to build a new school at Bella Bella this year. If it is, I would suggest that the site be cleared immediately as the work will help lessen relief. I have had a number of requests recently from Bella Bella Indians for relief, and I see no prospect of their earning anything by fishing until July first.

I estimated in a previous letter, that $150 would be required to clear the site for the new school. If the above meets with the Department's approval, I would suggest that a cheque for $125 for labour be sent me.

If blasting powder has to be purchased through the Department's purchasing agent, I may say that the only firm in Vancouver from whom it can be obtained is the Canadian Industries Ltd. I believe however, it would be better, as only a small quantity is needed, and as it is not possible to have it brought in on the regular passenger steamer, that I be allowed to purchase the powder at Ocean Falls where they usually have some on hand. On May 19th I sent the following telegram to the Department.

"Reference your one sixty two three five April twenty eight already used one hundred twenty five dollars stop On account unforeseen difficulties in clearing site will require further two hundred and fifty dollars for labour to make ground ready for building kindly advise."

I may say I had thirteen men under the supervision of Mr. Levelton, clearing the site for the proposed new school at Bella Bella. This work cost $124.80. The muskeg was deeper than I had anticipated and under the muskeg were boulders instead of bedrock as I thought. Dear Sir,

By letter No. 162-3-5 of June 2nd, I notice the size of the proposed new school at Bella Bella will be 54 by 43 feet. I would gather from this that the teachers' residence cannot be on the ground floor.

If the residence is to be above the school, a pump and storage tank will be necessary, as there is not sufficient pressure in the main to raise the water above the ground floor. I would recommend a 100 gallon galvanized storage tank to be placed under cover within the building.

I think it possible that a hydraulic ram type of pump could be used, and I am today writing Mr. Webb for his advice.

In previous correspondence I stated that a pump and tank would not be necessary, but at that time I was of the impression that the teachers' residence would be on the same level as the school building.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

May I draw your attention again to the fact that under the circumstances existing in this village the children are not receiving a very good education. I think you know that the school is too small and that you have made provision in the estimates for the erection of a new building, which will no doubt be a very fine addition to the buildings which you have at the coast. In the meantime, however, the children are suffering. The teacher is trying to teach two schools at the same time - one in the forenoon and the other in the afternoon.

Would it be possible, in the meantime, to set up school in the church hall, to take care of the second room until the new building is completed? I do not know what the church authorities would want, but I think that possibly $10.00 a month would cover the expenses of this, and the new desks, blackboards, etc., which would be necessary, could easily be transferred to the new schoolroom when it is ready, at whatever time in the future, near or remote, that may be. Would you be good enough to give the matter your best attention and see what can be done? Dr. Osterhout is very anxious to see these children get a good education, and, as you know, they are above the general average of the native population throughout the country.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Cochrane:

I have your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the Bella Bella Indian Day School.

I note the suggestion of Rev. W. R. Welch and would point out that it has not been our policy to make the installations mentioned in all Indian Day Schools. You can readily realize that such equipment is expensive to install and usually means continued expenditure to operate. The Surveys & Engineering Branch advise that in order to keep within the amount provided in the current year's appropriation for this building it would be impossible to provide such an installation at the Bella Bella School.

However, I am requesting them to install a chemical toilet in the teachers' living quarters.

Sir:

RE: WATER SUPPLY FOR BELLA BELLA DAY SCHOOL

An examination of the availability of water supply for this institution was made on December 21st during a visit to Bella Bella Indian Village in connection with the school construction.

Attached hereto is a sketch showing the location of the old and new schools and the pipe extension which would be required to furnish water to the new school.

A pressure gauge attached to tap at Point "A" on sketch showed a reading of 24 lbs. per square inch equivalent to a static head of 55.8 feet. When this reading was taken, several outdoor taps in the village were open and a 2" iron pipe at the north end of the village was leaking badly at two or three points.

Levels to the school site show that the kitchen tap at the school will be 27.75 feet higher in elevation than the tap at Point "A". This leaves a static head of approximately 28 feet for outlets on the ground floor of the school. This should provide a flow of about 9 gallons per minute, assuming that leakage losses from the main pipe are no higher in the future than at time of examination. Elimination of some of these losses would no doubt provide sufficient head to

G.E. Webb, Eng.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water and Power Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
carry water into the upper floors of the building if this should be required.

The proposed pipeline extension starts at the end of a 2-inch wood stave pipe now in place, paralleling the boardwalk leading from the main street to the church, continues in the same general direction for about 70 feet, then turns north and west as shown on the sketch about 243 feet further, entering the school wall at this point. The first 100 feet of the extension will be 2-inch wood stave pipe, the remainder will be 1" galvanized wrought iron pipe. From the west side of the muskeg area shown on sketch to the school it would not be possible to place the pipe in trench without dynamite. It is intended that this section of the pipe should be laid on the rock outcrop and covered to a depth of two feet with material already excavated from the school site. This should be placed carefully and the finer material selected so as to give better insulation against frost. Pipe laid in trench should be buried to a depth of two feet.

A half-inch iron pipe leads from the end of the 2-inch W.S. pipe now in place to the old school. This is leaking at the stop and waste. The necessary repairs should be made in order to supply water to the old school until the new school is ready for occupation, after which it should be cut off from the line.

Provision is made for the installation of a Total Eclipse self-draining tap outside the new school. This tap should be placed in such position as not to interfere with a driveway lead-
ing to the fuel room at the rear of the school. A stop and waste valve is to be installed outside the school wall.

The installation is estimated to cost $216.90. Details of this estimate are appended hereto.

Your obedient servant,

A.L. McNaughton

Dear Sir:

I am advised by Major MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, that it is not the Department's policy to have toilets and running water in the Indian Day Schools. This was in reply to a telegram sent to the Department by Major MacKay subsequent to my interview with the Commissioner in Vancouver.

What I had in mind chiefly was toilet and bath facilities for the teachers' residence at Bella Coola. While this may be a wise policy in so far as the school itself is concerned, I feel that it is a little short of a hardship that the teachers should not have these conveniences, particularly when some of the Indian homes nearby are equipped with such facilities.

The chemical toilet is anything but satisfactory, as it will require frequent cleaning. I note the plans calls for a pit placed under the sink for drainage. This will require attention daily. I think it should not be expected of the teachers living on an Indian Reserve with various unavoidable privations to do without such everyday necessities, as bath, proper toilet, and sink facilities where they can be readily installed with running water available, for an outlay which would cost as follows:

- Septic Tank with necessary fittings, including Soil Pipe from bathroom to tank, etc. $150.00
- Toilet, wash basin, bath, hot water boiler. (Approximately) $75.00
- Installation of toilet, bath, etc. $10.00
- Total. $235.00

I trust that the Department will reconsider their decision, and allow installation of these facilities in the teachers' residence.

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.
Three schools were visited during the month, and the attendance was excellent. I found it necessary at Bella Bella to change Miss Jessop to the Junior room, and put Miss Allen in charge of the Seniors. Good progress is being made in constructing the new school at Bella Bella.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Re - Bella Bella Indian School, B.C.

In a letter, dated June 29th, Mr. C.E. Webb reported a wall leakage in the above school at a point where the concrete foundation wall received the frame superstructure.

Mr. Webb reported further in a letter, dated July 4th, that the contractor on the school had, without expense to the Department, caulked the joint referred to with a cement and plaster of Paris mixture which had apparently closed the joint satisfactorily. In his letter, however, Mr. Webb recommended that, owing to the heavy and violent rainfall experienced in that area, gutters, rainwater leaders and a weeping tile drain should be provided and that the pitch waterproofing on the basement walls should be extended from grade to top of concrete.

Mr. Webb has secured a price from Mr. Currie, the contractor who built the school, covering all the items as follows:

1) 5" wood gutter and 5" galvanized iron down pipes on main eaves.

2) 4" wood gutter and 2" galvanized iron down pipes on eaves at entrances.

3) 4" tile drain connected to down pipes carrying roof water 10'0" away from building at two lowest points.

4) Two coats of hot coal tar pitch from present point to top of concrete walls of workshop, fuel room and sewing room.

5) Gutters and down pipes to be given two coats of paint to match other work.

The above five items to be executed for the sum of Three Hundred and Eighty-six Dollars ($386.00).

In connection with the items included in the estimate, I may say that in view of (a) the recent decision of the Department to install drainage in Indian Schools and (b) the particularly heavy rainfall in the Bella Bella area, it is felt that the drain and gutters
