PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Dear Sir:

I have received from Mr. Indian Agent Christie, of the Bella Coola Agency, a request to expend $200.00 in clearing and draining the grounds surrounding the new Indian Day School at Bella Bella. This School was recently visited by the Inspector of Indian Agencies and he informs me that the grounds surrounding the building are in an extremely bad condition, being full of large holes, mud, water, heaps of excavated rubbish and dangerous snags, and that sooner or later a child will receive serious injury unless the ground in use is cleared up.

He also points out that, for some unaccountable reason, no connecting door has been installed in the corridor outside of the classrooms and, at present, each room has only one exit to the outside and, if it is required to proceed from one room to the other, it is necessary to descend a flight of stairs, go outside and climb through mud holes, etc., to the other side of the building; and then ascend a similar flight of stairs to the classroom that adjoins the other. In the absence of outside fire escapes, these classrooms would be cut off if a fire broke out near one of the staircases, which lead down to the teachers' quarters, but that installation of the door would make the other entrances available to both rooms. If the door and frame were supplied at a cost of approximately $10.00, it could no doubt be satisfactorily installed by a local Indian carpenter at a labour cost of $15.00 or a total of $25.00, and I would recommend that this be done.

The Inspector reports that the paint work on this building is, in his opinion, far from satisfactory and it would appear that very poor quality paint has been used. That used for the roof has washed down and stained the walls. The outside wall paint is blistered. The paint on the basement floors will never dry sufficiently to permit the use of these two large rooms and should be removed and redecorated with the

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
proper material. Some caulking with pitch has been done on the outside of the building where the frame construction rests on the concrete foundation and, due to the fact that there was no overhang of the siding, water leaked into the basement, a condition that has not yet been entirely remedied. The application of this pitch has been done in a slipshod manner and smeared up the wall to an unnecessary extent. Common iron hinges have been used on the outside doors with the butts on the outside and are already rusting and untidy.

I enclose a rough sketch showing where the door is required and photographs of the School, from which it will also be observed that portions of the scaffolding were not even removed to complete the painting and which also show the other items referred to.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa,
December 27, 1939.

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Bella Bella Indian Day School

The following letter has just been received from Indian Commissioner Mackay:

"The Inspector of Indian Agencies recently visited this school and points out that, for some unaccountable reason, no connecting door has been installed in the corridor outside of the classrooms and, at present, each room has only one exit to the outside and, if it is required to proceed from one room to the other, it is necessary to descend a flight of stairs, go outside and climb through mud holes, etc., to the other side of the building and then ascend a similar flight of stairs to the classroom that adjoins the other. In the absence of outside fire escapes, these classrooms would be cut off if a fire broke out near one of the staircases, which lead down to the teachers' quarters, but that installation of the door would make the other entrances available to both rooms. If the door and frame were supplied at a cost of approximately $10.00, it could no doubt be satisfactorily installed by a local Indian carpenter at a labour cost of $15.00 or a total of $25.00, and I would recommend that this be done.

"The Inspector reports that the paint work on this building is, in his opinion, far from satisfactory and it would appear that very poor quality paint has been used. That used for the roof has washed down and stained..."
the walls. The outside wall paint is blistered. The paint on the basement floors will never dry sufficiently to permit the use of these two large rooms and should be removed and redecorated with the proper material. Some caulking with pitch has been done on the outside of the building where the frame construction rests on the concrete foundation and, due to the fact that there was no overhang of the siding, water leaked into the basement, a condition that has not yet been entirely remedied. The application of this pitch has been done in a slipshod manner and smeared up the wall to an unnecessary extent. Common iron hinges have been used on the outside doors with the butts on the outside and are already rusting and untidy.

"I enclose a rough sketch showing where the door is required and photographs of the school, from which it will also be observed that portions of the scaffolding were not even removed to complete the painting and which also show the other items referred to."

I enclose, for your information, the photographs of the school and the rough sketch which accompanied the Indian Commissioner's letter.

May I point out the impossibility of providing maintenance costs if newly erected schools are left in the condition mentioned in the Commissioner's letter. I should also appreciate it if you would let me know what steps can be taken to prevent such a recurrence in future.

I shall await your reply before authorizing the Agent to incur the expenditure required for installing a door between the two class rooms.

Acting Director.
The basement window in the new school at Bella Bella was broken during the Christmas Holidays by some school boys and an rance was made several times afterwards, and various articles and school supplies were stolen. The parties responsible will be brought before a Juvenile Judge at an early date. There seems to be a general lack of parental discipline at this village which is making it difficult for the school teachers who are getting very little cooperation from the parents. The agent called a meeting in the Community Hall at which the majority of the parents and children were present, and the seriousness of this situation was discussed. The Indians were very emphatic in their request for a male principal at this school, capable of teaching manual training.

The two basement rooms of the Bella Bella school are still unfit for use since the paint has not dried, and there is no indication that it will ever do so. I would suggest that this paint should be scraped and the proper material applied so that these rooms can be used for manual training etc., and also for play rooms for the children during the rainy spells.

On my last visit to the school, Miss Jeffers was sick, and consequently the senior pupils were not present. With the connecting door in the partition on the landing, it would be possible for one teacher to supervise both rooms in an emergency.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
January 18, 1940.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Bella Bella Indian Day School

In connection with your memorandum of the 3rd instant regarding the above with which you forwarded a letter and photographs from the Acting Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, I may say that we have also received a communication relative to the same project from Mr. Webb. The latter has forwarded with his letter copies of a letter to the Indian Affairs Branch from Indian Commissioner MacKay regarding the School, together with a report from Engineer Ramsden who supervised the erection of the building.

For your information, I am transmitting herewith a copy of the following documents:

(1) Letter dated December 29th, from Mr. Webb to the undersigned.
(2) Letter dated December 14th, from Indian Commissioner MacKay to Mr. Webb.
(3) Memorandum dated December 29th, from Engineer Ramsden to Mr. Webb.
(4) Memorandum dated December 27th, from Acting Director, Indian Affairs Branch to Mr. Wardle with photographs.

You will observe that Commissioner MacKay calls attention to the following:

(1) There is no communicating door between boys' and girls' accommodation on the classroom floor.

(2) Caulking and waterproofing carried out last summer, after the completion of the school, have not eliminated evidences of dampness in the basement.

(3) Poor quality paint has been used on both the exterior of the building and the basement floors. Shingle stain has washed down from the roof and stained the paint on exterior walls.

(4) Door hinges are rusting because of inferior quality.

(5) Portions of scaffolding used by the Contractor in painting have not been removed.

(6) The grounds generally surrounding the School are untidy and require grading.

Dealing with the items in the above order, I may say that:

(1) When the plans were being prepared for this School Mr. Dudley informs me that Mr. Hoey and Mr. Phelan stated to him verbally that there was to be no communication between boys' and girls' classrooms. Communication was to be provided between these areas------

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
areas for the teacher through the teacher's quarters.

(2) To eliminate dampness in the basement caulking and waterproofing was carried out during the past summer along with the installation of gutters and extra drainage as recommended by Mr. Webb on July 10th last. As the results obtained do not appear to be completely satisfactory Mr. Webb advised us on the 7th ultimo that he is carrying out an inspection of the building to determine the cause of dampness and will report to this office. This report has not yet been received.

(3) It would appear that painting of floors was carried out in the basement while dampness was still present, thus preventing adhesion between paint and concrete. It will be necessary to eliminate dampness entirely before a permanent correction of this fault can be effected. This is contingent upon Mr. Webb's report. The remaining paint items, which appear very minor, will be dealt with in the same report.

(4) You will observe that Mr. Ramsden's report states that brass coated hinges were installed as specified.

(5) The portions of scaffolding as shown on attached photographs are insignificant.

(6) The suggested improvements to the School grounds in general is a matter under the jurisdiction of the Indian Affairs Branch.

In connection with the subject matter of this memorandum we would point out that on November 14th last Mr. Webb advised us that he had received the Contractor's account for items authorized by letter of August 29th last but owing to reports which he had received indicating that the measures employed to ensure a dry basement were not completely satisfactory, he was not passing the account for payment until an inspection had been made.

When the engineer's report is received from Mr. Webb we will advise you further.

Would you kindly return the attached photographs to this Service when they have served your purpose.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.
February 15, 1940

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

In your memorandum of December 27th you quoted from a letter received from Indian Commissioner MacKay relative to the Bella Bella Indian Day School, which was built by contract during the past season.

The various points mentioned by Mr. MacKay have been investigated by our Chief Engineer, and I am forwarding herewith, for your information, copies of memoranda received from him, dated January 18th and February 5th last. I think these two memoranda cover all the points referred to by Mr. MacKay.

Certain defects in the building are due to poor work by the contractor and the necessary action is being taken by our officers to have these remedied. There is an amount still due the contractor for work done on the building and he is being advised that final payment will be withheld until all work has been completed in accordance with the specifications.

You will note that some of the other items of work mentioned by Mr. MacKay as being necessary were not done because of decisions made by officers of your Branch. Direct communication between the boys' and girls' classrooms is one of these items. If this communication door is now considered necessary, there is no reason why it should not be put in.

Director.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Bella Bella Indian Day School.

Further to my memorandum of the 18th ultimo in connection with the above, we are now in receipt of a report by Engineer McDonald dated the 8th ultimo, forwarded with Mr. Webb's covering letter of January 22nd last.

For your information I am forwarding herewith duplicate copies of the following documents:

(a) Mr. Webb's letter of the 22nd ultimo to this Service,
(b) Mr. Webb's letter of the 12th ultimo to the Contractor,
(c) Report by Engineer McDonald.

You will observe that the matter of dampness in the basement has been thoroughly investigated by Mr. McDonald who has determined definitely by tests that water does not enter the basement through concrete foundation walls or floors, and that if at any time water entered the building at the top of the foundation wall, the work carried out during the past summer has remedied the condition.

In view of the engineer's findings, it is difficult to understand the significance of the third and eighth paragraphs of Mr. Webb's letter of the 22nd ultimo to this Service, or of the statement in his letter to the Contractor under date of the 12th ultimo, which was forwarded of course before he had received Mr. McDonald's report.

REPORT ON
INSPECTION OF BELLA BELLA SCHOOL,
BRITISH COLUMBIA

With reference to the above, I wish to report
that on the 18th ultimo I visited Mr. Webb in Vancouver
and reviewed the items reported in a letter from Commis-
sioner MacKay dated December 14th, 1939. It was explained
to Mr. Webb that the inspection was being carried out with
a view to determining the reason for such reports.

Mr. Webb was informed that, as stated in a letter
from the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Ser-
vice, dated February 23rd, 1940, it was felt that several
of the defects mentioned by Commissioner MacKay, in con-
nection with the school, should have been detected through
inspections carried out by his staff during construction and
remedied before the building was accepted as complete.

Mr. Webb replied that short of having an engineer
remain constantly at the school during construction, he felt
he had given as much attention to supervision as was possible
with the staff at his disposal, particularly since the site
was 40 hours' steamer's drive from Vancouver. He stated that
supervision had been constantly maintained while concrete
was being poured, (which statement is supported by his letter
to the Chief Engineer dated June 27th, 1939), and that four
subsequent inspection trips were made during the remainder
of the construction period.

It was pointed out to Mr. Webb that supervision,
as demanded by the peculiar requirements of each job, was
necessary at all times, and that if it became apparent that
such supervision could not be supplied from field offices,
other arrangements would be sought for, or instructions from
Ottawa. Mr. Webb was also advised that authority vested in
field officers included the right to challenge the suita-
bility of sites selected by Indian Agents for schools where
conditions indicated that the use of such sites might cause
trouble in the future.

I arrived at Bella Bella at 3.30 A.M. on Friday
the 22nd ultimo and carried out a thorough inspection of
the school on that day, paying particular attention to the
following points which had been reported to this Service.

(1) Condition of paint work in basement
work rooms.

(2) Condition of exterior paint work.

(3) Presence of water in basement work
rooms.

(4) Untidy condition of site.
Dealing with the various items in the order given above, I may say that I found conditions to be as follows:

(1) Basement Work Room Paint Work

Paint work in the basement work rooms was exactly as described in complaints received from Dr. Darby, Hospital Superintendent at Bella Bella, and Indian Commissioner MacKay. I found that the paint used was lead and oil floor paint of the same type as specified. This had been applied to concrete not thoroughly dry and which was exposed to running water through wall leakages immediately after it had been applied. Paint from the walls had been washed down to the floor where it had emulsified, as had also the paint applied to the floor. Traffic over this emulsion had broken the pigment film and patches of free oil were visible over most of the floor area. It is possible that this free oil might have been mistaken for water in some of the complaints registered.

It was obvious that the condition would not improve until the paint had been removed, the affected areas thoroughly cleaned and new paint applied.

(2) Exterior Paint Work

The exterior paint work was examined regarding reported blistering and staining. I was unable to discover any blistering but observed that where water had dripped from the sloping roof over both entrances, the adjacent wall paint had been discoloured. Upon investigation I was able to establish that this discolouration was not stain from the shingles but a dirty deposit carried down from roof surfaces above, before the installation of gutters and down pipes, and which was removable when washed.

(3) Water Penetration

When I visited the school there was no evidence of water in the basement, and while rain fell frequently during my stay, no infiltration was observed. I am convinced that at no time has water entered the building through concrete walls or floors, and while the interior of the basement concrete walls show water stain, it was not possible to determine definitely where such water could have entered. However, I am satisfied myself that since the application of additional pitch waterproofing, which was applied from grade to top of the concrete basement walls during last summer, no water has entered the building at the junction of concrete and frame walls.

I may say that I observed the points at which Engineer McDonald, of Mr. Webb's staff, found that water could enter the frame walls, and believe that if water still enters the basement, it is being admitted at those points, and possibly at the junction of the sloping roof over the south entrance with the adjacent walls as well. This could only be proven during a heavy driving rain or by means of a hose test, such as was carried out by Mr. McDonald on December 31st last, and described in his report dated January 22nd, 1940, a copy of which was forwarded to our...
Director with the Chief Engineer's memorandum of February 5th last.

An examination of the siding disclosed that, while siding as specified had been used, the type called for in the specification should not be used again for work in British Columbia. The siding used and specified is a "lap" siding, especially laid to provide a rain seal at the lap, restricting the lap to 1/8" instead of 1" which is considered the minimum advisable. While I was unable to discover any point where I considered water might be entering the wall, due to the reduced lap, any shrinkage or warping in the siding would create openings through which a driving rain might penetrate. No warping is evident, however, and it is felt that if the various spots now marked, were caulked with an approved compound and sealed, and the same treatment applied to the junction of the sloping roof over both entrances, with adjacent wall surfaces, the penetration of water would be eliminated.

It is recognized that during construction, Mr. Webb reported that water was entering the building at the junction of concrete and frame walls and that some attention was given to correcting the defects. In view of subsequent developments, however, it is considered that the admission of water was not thoroughly investigated. Reports on the condition prevailing were accepted from the Hospital Superintendent, who could not be expected to arrive at correct technical conclusions. If the engineer supervising the work had made every effort to eliminate leakage while the contractor was still at Bella-Bella considerable inconvenience might have been eliminated.

(4) Site Conditions

Upon seeing the site I was forced to admit that in the immediate vicinity of the school, it is in a deplorable condition. Nevertheless the objectionable features pointed out by Indian Commissioner MacKay are no fault of the Contractor.

The actual portion of the site occupied by the school was cleared of brush and boulders by the Indian Agent previous to the commencement of construction operations. Stumps and boulders are in evidence adjacent to the building which is located on a rock ledge covered with from two to four feet of muskeg soil. The site in rear of the school building rises gradually and rock outcroppings at the front of the site have resulted in the building being set in a depression. The gradual erosion cut by the Contractor prior to completion of building operations has been saturated with water draining into this depression from the adjacent muskeg and is being retained by the bed rock below. The resultant mud holes have necessitated the laying of rough plank walks, which, while unsightly, are nevertheless quite necessary.
After visiting Bella Bella and before leaving Vancouver, I advised Indian Commissioner MacKay that, in my opinion, the site was badly chosen. He informed me that it had been considered the best available at the time of selection. In connection with the Commissioner's report that the site was untidy, I explained to him that references in his report, regarding responsibility for these conditions, were not altogether accurate, in that I could discover no building rubbish or material, left by the contractor, and that existing and future conditions were the responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch.

It is confirmed that existing faults in connection with basement painting and infiltration of water are the responsibility of the Contractor, and in a letter from Mr. Webb dated February 26th, 1940, the Contractor, John Currie and Son, of Prince Rupert, British Columbia, was so advised, and he has since intimated his intention of making good all defects at his own expense.

We have been advised by Mr. Webb, in a letter dated the 4th instant, that the emulsified paint in the basement has already been removed and he is being advised that the balance of the work must be carried out at once.

It is pointed out that during the summer of last year, extra items considered necessary to rectify the dampness in the basement, were carried out at a cost of $286.00 by the same Contractor who built the school. Payment for this work has been deferred until such time as the defects referred to in this report have been made good.

It is recommended that when advice is received that the Contractor has completed the work still necessary, and while he is still at Bella Bella, Mr. Webb be instructed to carry out a thorough inspection of the school, to establish that the building has finally been made weatherproof.

In addition to the work still necessary at the school, in connection with the building proper, the site requires further clearing and grading which may involve some blasting before it can be considered at all presentable.

It is recommended that an additional 15'-0" strip be cleared at the rear and two sides and the sufficient of the rock outcroppings at the front of the building be removed to allow grading to a continuous slope away from the school in an easterly direction. It is estimated that this additional work would involve an expenditure of approximately Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00).

Architect,
Engineering and Construction Service.

Ottawa, Ontario,
April 30th, 1940.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Indian Day School, Bella Bella, B.C.

As instructed I arrived at the school on Sunday afternoon, August 18, in company with the contractor, John Currie, Esq., and immediately inspected the building.

The following is a report of the condition of the basement floors and siding of the building as found, and the repairs carried out. This inspection was made over a period of seven days, August 18 to 24 inclusive.

Water Conditions.

The following rainfall data were obtained from the Meteorological Service of Canada, records made by W. R. Welch, Esq., of Bella Bella and illustrate the severe conditions obtaining in this locality even in the height of the summer season. In July, 1940, 6.91 inches of rain had fallen and in the seventeen days of August preceding my visit the following is the daily record:

| Aug 10| --                |

That is a total of 9.17 inches in eighteen days.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water and Power Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
Condition of the Concrete Basement Floors on August 18, 1946

The weather on August 18 was fine and warm and had been so for the four preceding days. Due to the heavy rains falling prior to August 14 and in spite of the hot weather following, the ground generally was very damp. Surface water showed six feet to eight feet away from the school on the north and west sides. Small trickles of water were observed to be coming from the drain outfalls indicating a continued subsurface drainage from the higher ground surrounding the school.

In the north basement room there was no visible moisture on the floor but in the south basement room there was a small amount of water in the southwest corner extending along the west wall for five feet. The water on the floor was dark brown in colour with no distinguishable odour. I believe it was stained by some cedar boards, used by the school, which were lying in it.

However, under a three-foot by six-foot piece of painted wall board which was placed in the middle of the south room floor in June, the concrete was noticeably damp and the same condition was observed under some small pieces of wood in the south room.

The walls all appeared dry and gave no indication that water had been running down them.
Test carried out to determine whether the concrete was in a fit condition to paint.

The water in the south room was wiped up and the floor cleared of stored material and rubbish. In thirty-six hours all traces of dampness had disappeared. The General Paint Corporation of Vancouver, who supplied the concrete paint which was to be used on the floors and made up according to the specification contained in Mr. Mills' letter of May 22, 1940, informed me that unless the floor was absolutely dry and could be assumed to remain that way, it was unsafe to apply the paint. They further suggested the use of a test for moisture, calcium chloride covered by an inverted watch glass which was to be sealed to the floor with putty.

Two tests were conducted in each room and it was found that in all cases the calcium chloride drew considerable moisture from the concrete slab in places where it appeared absolutely dry.

In addition, a test drill hole was made in the concrete where the water had been on the floor in the south room and showed that although the surface was dry, there was still moisture in the interior of the slab.

Repairs carried out by the Contractor.

The contractor carefully puttied all visible holes and cracks in the siding giving particular attention to areas around the window frames, and the junction of sloping roofs and walls. The material used was a caulking compound supplied by...
the General Paint Corporation of Vancouver. Two coats of paint was applied to the work and a complete coat of paint was given to the south side of the south room.

Further Tests on the Repairs Made.

When the paint had hardened, I tested all the exterior wall surfaces of the basement rooms and the entrance doors and furnace room roofs with a hose. No water was found to enter the building, although this was rather an extreme test.

Recommendations.

In view of the conditions found I instructed the contractor not to paint the concrete basement floors and following the instructions of Mr. Mills' letter of August 6, 1940, the materials, three-one-gallon G. P. cement floor primer and three-one-gallon G. P. cement floor paint, dark grey, were left in the north basement room for the school authorities.

The floor is entirely serviceable as it is at present and in view of the evidence that the concrete slab is moist through capillary action, I would suggest that the floor should not be painted at any time. The contractor and the General Paint Corporation both inform me that a slab which appears dry but has water underneath it, will, when painted, draw moisture from below and will never be as satisfactory as a floor without paint.
Since I was unable to detect any leaks subsequent to the repairs, and as I observed that the concrete floors are now serviceable, I recommend that the sum of $366.00 be now authorized for payment to the contractor. This was the agreed price of the gutters, downspouts, drains, and concrete wall pitching authorized in Mr. Mills' letter of August 29, 1939 and carried out in October of that year. This work was reported as satisfactorily done by Mr. McDonald in his memorandum to you dated January 8, 1940, with the exception of some exposed drain tile which I found to have been satisfactorily covered by the contractor earlier this year. As requested by Mr. Buck, the basement window sash had been eased and were again eased. This will doubtless have to be done again by the school authorities as it is not safe to ease the woodwork very much at a time otherwise leaks will develop.

Your obedient servant,

H. T. Ramsden.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir;-

Recently while visiting the Bella Bella Indian Day school, the teachers complained about the limited cupboard space, for the storing of school supplies, of which there seemed to be quite a large stock, and they suggested that a cupboard be built in one of the basement rooms, large enough to take care of these supplies.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

Left for Bella Bella, and again went to school, found that nothing had been done about the water, so finally got a young man to dig up the automatic Hydrant which had been broken, and a new one was to be put in. Have since heard from Dr. Darby, that this work has been completed and the teachers were able to get water outside of the building but only occasionally out of the tap inside, as there does not seem to be enough pressure to bring the water to this higher level, except in the mornings when a lot of the village taps are closed.

T.A. Levelton,
Acting Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

Left for Bella Bella next morning, and visited the two class rooms in the school, and found a good attendance, with the children looking healthy and clean, also the school rooms were in very good order. Visited the hospital, and conferred with the medical Supt., Dr. Darby, on various matters pertaining to the Indian patients in the Hospital.

Found the school without water, and made arrangements to have the pipe line checked for leaks, and left at 12:15 for Klemtu, arriving there in a heavy S.E. Gale. Visited School teacher, and the School, and I certainly was amazed at how he had been able to carry on with the stove in the condition it was. The whole top of the fire box was burnt and rusted away, and there were holes through it at all points, so it was a wonder that the school had not been burnt down.

The new stove, and coal had not arrived there at this time, but on my return from the North, I found a new stove and pipes installed, but still no coal, so the teacher had ordered some wood cut and delivered, but this was green and full of salt water, so it had to be cut into kindling wood before it would burn.

T.A. Levelton,
Acting Indian Agent.
Campbell Island, B.C.

It is recommended that an accountable cheque for $100.00 be forwarded to take care of 160 hours labour @ $2.50 required to complete a truck road around the Bella Bella Indian Day School, Campbell Island, B.C.

F. Earl Anfield,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

I have your letter of the 1st instant, in connection with the proposed installation of a telephone in the teacher's residence at the Bella Bella Indian Day School.

It is not our general practice to supply a telephone at a teacher's residence, but, in view of the unusual conditions mentioned in Indian Agent Anfield's letter, it has been decided to approve the installation of a telephone at the Bella Bella teacherage, at a cost of $87.00.

It is understood that this will be the only charge in the matter and that neither service nor further material charges will be submitted to the Department.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letters of May 7th and 27th in connection with the proposed installation of a telephone at the Bella Bella Indian Day School teacherage.

Although I am of the opinion that there are many teachers in the province in more isolated places than Bella Bella, with even less protection available, in view of the Agent's comments with respect to the increasing use of liquor by the Indians of Bella Bella and the unfortunate position the Department would be in if the teachers were involved in any incident as a result of this now that the proposal has been suggested, I would recommend that if funds are available an expenditure of $87.00 be authorized to cover the cost of installation.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Major D. M. Mackay, Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver.

Re yours of May 14th, file 2-11-4, dealing with a recommendation that the Department pay the cost of material and labour for the installation of a telephone from the Bella Bella Hospital to the teacherage at the Indian Day School, it is my definite understanding that this will be the sole charge in this matter and that neither service nor further material charges will be submitted to the Department.

The phone would be hooked up for immediate response at night by the nurse on duty at the hospital who could connect the call to Dr. Darby's bedside. Should the alarm be one of fire, the nurse would at once ring the fire alarm to the village. Should the alarm be an attempted breaking and entry to the teacherage both Dr. Darby and the Hospital Janitor and Engineer would be available to proceed to the teacherage in a matter of minutes.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Bella Coola, B.C.
May 7th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Last fall Miss Phillips, teacher at the Bella Bella Day School occupied the teacherage alone and the necessity of this with one or even two women is a worry in a village where drinking is on the increase as it is in Bella Bella.

I have discussed the matter on several occasions with Dr. Darby and it is agreed that the solution lies in the installation of a phone to hook up with the system at the Hospital. Dr. Darby is now overhauling and replacing much of his phone system connecting the hospital with the Mission House, Nurses Home, etc. and I asked him to give me a bid on the required equipment and labour to link our teacherage with this system. Enclosed please find a bid on material and labour in duplicate, totalling $87.00 which may be shaded a bit when the work is done.

It is considered necessary that this phone should be put in and it is recommended that the bids attached be accepted unless the Department wishes to issue a Purchase Order and buy and ship the materials direct.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Bella Bella Day School

Regarding the urgent need for supplying two more class rooms with quarters for two teachers as early as possible, several alternative ideas have been investigated and discarded as impractical. There remains the proposal for moving and converting the building from the Bella Bella Air base to the school site.

Attached is a summary of approximate costs, based on the suggestion from your office that the Bella Coola Loggers tractor might be used. This is very tentative since I do not recommend the absence of this tractor from the logging operations at Bella Coola during the period this fall when labor for the project will possibly be available here. However although I have not found a suitable power unit elsewhere, I am assuming for the purpose of these calculations that some unit might be located in an area as accessible as Bella Coola.

Regarding the tug, it is proposed to try to secure one of the Bella Bella seiners which would necessitate their foregoing a month of seining in southern waters. The figure quoted would be merely cost of operation and I would not have quoted so low a figure had not one of the seine owners intimated that a boat might be provided locally at about that figure to help the project. A small commercial tug would cost at least twice the amount quoted and we would probably not get as good cooperation from the crew in catching tides, etc., which would probably increase the time required. The tug time is calculated on the basis of going out to pick up the power unit, returning with it and standing by during the whole moving operation, then returning the power unit and float.

The plan of the move briefly is to cut the building into three sections, cross the channel with one at a time and take each section up to the school site before returning for the next. This will be necessary if only one sleigh is used.

I may say that the moving time is calculated on the basis of reasonably successful operation. Should a serious delay occur and the part from the beach to the school site presents several hazards which might cause trouble, then with the tug, tractor and crew standing by the daily time loss would be about $155.00 without possible cost of breakages and repairs.

I am presenting this plan in a tentative form because I do not believe it is practical to spend the amount indicated on a building which when finished can have only a make-shift usefulness. In view of the likelihood that it would be nearing Christmas before it could be done even at such a cost I believe the possibilities of new and permanent construction should be reviewed before the use of a temporary building is further considered.

May I stress again the urgent need for this accommodation and point out the very serious loss in academic knowledge that the Bella Bella children are suffering, which may result in many people having to face problems of readjustment owing to a sense of frustration from having been deprived of normal education. The loss in life efficiency to the Bella Bella Band of Indians and to the Dominion of Canada should also be remembered.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6385, File 802-5, part 3)
I therefore recommend that immediate steps be taken to provide two new and permanent classrooms at Bella Bella with quarters for two teachers.

Re: Bella Bella Indian Day School

While at Bella Bella on February 25th and 26th with School Inspector R. F. Davey, we made a complete survey of the buildings at the Shearwater Air Base in order to ascertain if there was suitable structure for use as an extra school building at the Bella Bella Reserve.

After inspecting several, we decided that building No. 5, formerly N.C.O. Quarters and listed on the building plan as No. A-S-23-2 would be almost ideal for use as school building. This building is 22' long and 23' wide, height from floor to plate 8' and floor to ceiling 10'6". The exterior is shingled over shiplap; inside is lined with fir 3/ply over shiplap on walls; ceiling-beaverboard and insulated with rock wool. Floors are veneer 3/ply over shiplap and covered with battleship linoleum. I understand Inspector Davey has submitted tracings with his report. These show the partition of the building at present and the proposed changes which we consider would be advisable to make.

The necessary changes are as follows:

1. Partition building in three main sections. A classroom at each end with teacherage in center of building.

2. Classrooms: Length 28', width 23'. Windows to be placed on west side of the rooms, providing proper lighting and excellent blackboard space.

3. Halls: Length 13', width 4' providing cloakroom space - with both walls available for hooks.

4. Entrances: Glass doors - providing light to cloakrooms. It is suggested that an entrance from the teacherage be provided into each cloakroom.

5. Teacherage: A living room, kitchen, two bedrooms and bathroom to be provided. Approximate size of rooms:

   Living room 16' x 13'
   Kitchen 12' x 13'
   Bed rooms 12' x 10'
   Bath room 7' x 10'

This teacherage should be equipped with adequate plumbing and properly furnished.

6. Heating: The building is heated by an oil unit which goes with the building. In addition there is an oil-burning hot water unit complete with 40 gallon tank. It is thought that these units could be placed in the same room which is 10' x 5' and considered large enough to house both. There are oil tanks outside the building and I surmise these would be included in the purchase price.

7. Site for building: It would appear that the best site for the proposed new school would be on the west side of the playground and north of the present building. This would give ample light from the west for the classrooms and the front of the teacherage would overlook the village and the waterfront.

(over)
8. Moving: No difficulty should be encountered in moving the building from the Air base. A problem confronted us as to how it could be brought ashore at Bella Bella village and taken to the proposed site. However, after considerable survey of the situation we found that the best route would be immediately south of the hospital - across the roadway and from there no difficulty should occur. I did not approach the Bella Bella head men on the matter, nor will I until such time as the approval of the Department is obtained.

It would appear that the work should be done by contract since it would not be advisable to attempt it with local labor. A contractor could best ascertain how it should be divided for moving.

9. Costs: I am not in a position to place an exact value on the building, but realizing that most likely it would eventually be sold for salvage purposes, and in the meantime deteriorating in value, it would appear that the War Assets Corporation should be willing to place a reasonable price on the building especially to a branch of the Federal Government. I would suggest that the amount not exceeding $2,000.00 be offered; such price to include all heating units, oil tanks, fixtures and plumbing as the building now stands.

10. General: Should this building be purchased and moved to Bella Bella, for school purposes, it is to be pointed out that it would take care of present needed school accommodation only and that in the very near future, consideration be given to the construction of a suitable permanent building to provide for at least five if not six class rooms. In the event of this being done, the building which it is now proposed to move from the Air Base could be adapted for living quarters for a staff of five or six teachers.

D. Children seven years of age in 1946 have not been admitted due to lack of accommodation and a number of fourteen to sixteen year olds cannot attend for the same reason.

The number, thirty-five, of Bella Bella children attending residential schools seems to be out of all proportion. If adequate school facilities were available at Bella Bella, the majority of these children could and should remain in the village and attend the Day School, thus giving opportunity for more deserving cases to attend the residential schools.

There should be a four-room school at Bella Bella, with seating space for approximately thirty-five children in each room. This would mean accommodation for 140 which even then would be seventeen below the actual number of school-age children in 1946.

It is my considered opinion that the school situation at Bella Bella is sufficiently serious to warrant complete reconsideration of any proposed use of a basement room. Use of such basement rooms would not allow for more accommodation than is necessary for fifteen to twenty pupils. The proximity of this room to the furnace room would not, in my opinion, be in accordance with safety regulations more conducive to healthy school-room conditions.

I am strongly averse to the use of the basement as a classroom and do not consider the expense involved in the proposed conditioning of the basement as a worthwhile step towards remedying the lack of school facilities at Bella Bella. The use of the basement rooms as class-rooms will eliminate any indoor recreation space which in this climate is essential in the Day schools.

I did not have an opportunity of inspecting the Town Hall, but will do so at the earliest possible time. However, from what I saw and know of this hall, I do not believe that the light is satisfactory and being immediately adjacent to the Bella Bella Town Hall which is used during the day on numerous occasions, would be subject to external disturbances.

As a result of reviewing the situation as it now stands and considering the serious problem which exists, I herewith submit my suggestions.

E. Plan 1

That the blue prints of the Bella Bella Day School be submitted to a qualified architect in order to ascertain how two additional classrooms could be provided by a wing being built on the present building. In this respect provision must be made to provide living accommodation for two more teachers.
My own ideas in this respect are as follows: (See tracings)

The duplication of the main part of the present building in place of the teachers residence as now laid out would provide the two extra classrooms so badly needed and would permit of living accommodation necessary for four teachers. The entrances would remain the same and common cloakrooms provided for each of the two sets of rooms.

The furnace would be sufficient to heat all four rooms and the residence. In this proposed plan all the teachers accommodation would be on the main floor, consisting of living-room, kitchen and four bedrooms. Approximate size of each room would be - Living room 16 x 21; Kitchen 9½ x 21; providing space for Dining Room; each of four bedrooms 12 x 10. Complete plumbing facilities should be installed.

Plan II Only if basement rooms must be used.

Since the use of either or both of the basement rooms as they are now will not provide the actual necessary accommodation it would be necessary for these two rooms to be enlarged as follows.

South basement room: (As per attached sketch)

The end (south) wall be removed and the room extended twelve feet. A partition be built at the opposite end making corridor to be used as a cloakroom. The present room is 21' x 20' and with the change suggested will make a school room 21' x 29'. There is a nine foot ceiling clearance and excavation necessary to enlarge the room would be to the depth of approximately two feet. An exit should be provided at the south end providing ample safety. This expansion will not affect the lighting of the upper cloakroom and windows on the west side of the Eaves windows now in the south basement wall could be used in the west wall providing sufficient day light. Double flooring should be laid on 2" x 6" timbers to raise it off the present concrete floor and the walls suitably lined.

North Basement Room

Extended in similar manner. This plan would not allow for any additional living accommodation for two more teachers. This problem must be considered when any change is made.

Heating F.

The present furnace would not adequately heat the basement rooms unless this system was re-arranged. The only other alternative would be the installation of oil heaters in each room.

G. I fully realize that either of the above plans would involve considerable expense but if proper school facilities are to be provided at Bella Bella, plans must be considered now for some permanent construction. Any temporary arrangement will by no means solve the problem. I most definitely favor Plan #2. In view of the evident increase in pupils in Bella Bella, I urgently recommend that the question of school accommodation be completely re-considered with the view to providing the necessary space at as early a date as possible.

Under date of May 20th, 1946, I wrote you in connection with additional classroom accommodation required to accommodate the school-aged pupils at the Bella Bella Indian Reserve and subsequently received authority for various expenditures necessary for establishing a classroom in the basement of the present school building or otherwise converting the Band hall for classroom purposes. Due in part to difficulty in securing material and labour and also by reason of the transfer of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield to Prince Rupert, the proposal was not proceeded with prior to the end of the fiscal year. In February last School Inspector Davey visited Bella Bella and during the course of his visit inspected some of the buildings at the Bella Bella Air Base with a view to ascertaining whether there would be one suitable for school purposes at the Bella Bella village. Inspector Davey found that two of the buildings at the Air Base would be suitable as to size and construction for two additional classrooms and living quarters for two teachers, but we have since found it almost impossible to secure any information with respect to the cost of moving these buildings to Bella Bella and preparing them for school and teachers' use. July 2, 1947.

In view of the exorbitant estimated cost of moving the building to Bella Bella and preparing it for school use, reference Mr. Pruden's letter of June 7th, and as the Surveys and Engineering Branch have been successful in making arrangements for the removal and reconstruction of buildings at the Port Hardy Military Camp at a reasonable cost, I am of the opinion that it would be advisable to have the Surveys and Engineering Branch investigate and report on the advisability of transferring buildings from the Bella Bella Air Base to the Reserve for school purposes or otherwise the possibility of adding two additional classrooms with teachers' quarters to the present school building.

It is observed from Mr. Neary's letter of February 4th, 1947, File 1-1-5 (W.T.l) that no specific provision was made in the current year's program for school construction at Bella Bella, but it is considered that we should in any case ascertain the best method of meeting our school requirements at this point, and that if the proposal is found to be feasible and economical steps should be taken to acquire the air force building.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: School Building for Bella Bella.

As instructed, I visited Bella Bella Air Base on August 24, 1947 accompanied by Mr. Pruden, Indian Agent. Subsequent visits were made on August 26 and 31.

Mr. Coleman's letter of August 9, 1947 gives the size of the building as 92' x 32' by 10'6" ceiling; the building shown to me by Mr. Pruden is 90' x 24' by 11 ft. ceiling. It is shown as Building 5 on Ground Service Plan, Bella Bella - Dwg. W.6026-2, WAC Dwg. No. SS 26-3-36. Department of National Defence Air; Western Air Command; Construction Engineering.

A description of the building is as follows:

(See also Sketch 'A').

Floor 90 ft. by 24 ft. wide.

The floor joists rest on three sills running full length of the building. The sills are on concrete posts. The joists are 2" x 8" No. 1 Common Fir in first-class sound condition. They are spaced at 16" centres.

On the joists are laid 1" x 8" No. 1 Fir shiplap at right angles to the joists. The material is sound and first-class condition. It is assumed there is a layer of tar paper between this shiplap and the 3-ply Fir floor of unknown thickness. The 3-ply is covered with linoleum, some of which is 'Battleship type' and some of poorer quality. The poorer quality is of little value.
Walls The outside walls are as follows, describing from the outside to the inside:

1st 3X No. 1 shingles coloured dirty green.
2nd A layer of tar paper.
3rd 1" x 8" No. 1 Common shiplap Fir, layed horizontally.
4th 2" x 4" Studs of No. 1 Common Fir.
5th 3/8" Gyproc nailed to studding.
6th 1/4" Fir 3-ply nailed over the gyproc.

The plywood for the most part is stained a light brown.

Roof The roof is 2" x 6" No. 1 Fir rafters with tie brace of 2" x 6" and braced with 2" x 4" No. 1 Fir. The rafters are spaced at 24-inch centres.

See also section 'X-X' Sketch 'A'.

Over the rafters is 1" x 8" shiplap No. 1 Fir layed tight, i.e.

It is assumed there is a layer of tar paper between shiplap and the 3X No. 1 Cedar shingle roof. The shiplap and rafters are in excellent sound condition.

Ceiling The ceiling is of a composition board 1/2" or 5/8" thick. It is apparently a laminated material and appears to be denser and stronger than Donnaconda or Ten Test. I do not know the trade name or type of this material. The ceiling is insulated with a layer of rock wool or similar non-vegetable material.

Fixtures Plumbing fixtures include:

2 Wash basins of good make, one slightly chipped, on edge.
2 'Standard' water closets.
1 Urinal
2 Sinks without back
Fixtures (Cont'd.)

1 'Duo-Therm' Model 240, Type M-AW21, Max. flow
13 gallons. Serial No. S19469 water heater
with a 75-gallon storage tank. The unit has
an oil burner of the pot type.

Some 4" C.I. drainage (sewage) pipe (soil pipe)
1/2" and 3/4" galvanized iron pipe.

Heating Equipment

1 Hot air furnace with circulating fan.
Automatic oil fired with Thermostat control.
Furnace by Holmes Heating Service and is No.
77 CJW. (The figure 7 may be a 3 or 7).

Lighting Fixtures Consist of 7 centre lights, 5 of
which have bowl shades and lights in each room. There
are at least 10 double outlet base-board plugs and
several wall standard toggle switches and covered copper
wire.

There is a fireplace and brick chimney at
one end of the building. A single-flue brick chimney
for the water heater, and a single-flue metal pipe of
the Yukon type for the furnace.

Moving the Building

It is not recommended that the building be
moved whole or in large sections. The difficulties and
costs, plus the many possible contingencies are too great
to warrant an attempt.

The building is now situated at an estimated
elevation of about 140 feet and some 500 feet from the
sea, or by paved road about 900 feet from a seaplane slip
into the sea. Thus the route to a scow on the slip would
not be too difficult if power, tackle and experienced movers
were available. It is necessary to tow on suitable scow
three miles to Bella Bella Indian Village.
From the shore at the Indian Village the real difficulties are encountered. It would be necessary to drag up-hill some 60 feet elevation at a distance of 1100 to 1200 feet over steep ground, muskeg, and rock outcrops. It would also involve shifting two electric light poles, 30 feet of wooden roadway, and cutting much brush.

It would appear that the best method to follow in transferring this building would be to disassemble to individual pieces of raw material, truck all material to the wharf or to the seaplane slip at the air base, then load on suitable scow and transfer to Bella Bella Indian Village Wharf. It will be necessary then to truck material to school site about 1100 feet.

The amount of care exercised in dismantling the building would determine amount of raw material obtainable. When a building is dismantled to raw material it is suggested that in re-building to a new school a standard school plan should be considered, thereby obtaining a building to the best advantage for the purpose.

As the time before mail collection is limited, further information on this project will follow in the next mail.

There is one factor, however, in building a school at this village which would be encountered in using either new or used material, and that is a new plank road about 350 feet would be required to transport goods, as present roadway from main road to school grounds is rotted beyond repair and could only carry a gross load of about 600 pounds.

A. Unsworth.
